I am a fan of mafia games, empire building and tactical battle. This game should be a home run for me but it is just ok at this point. I think this game has a lot of strong foundation to it and I like how things interact with each other in a balancing act.

few things I really think would help.
1. If your guys uses a bandage in a fight and you have bandages in storage it should auto refill it. Zero fun micro managing stuff like that.
2. I am a gangster not a hobbo. There should be 4-5 taxi cab in each area. Waiting a minute while your guys slowly walk across a zone is very fun. Or allow you to have different speeds to move at. game speed x2 or x4 option.
3. If you have a healer in your group, it should heal everybody up post fight. It is something you can do manually. why make people waste time doing it? waste of time and no fun.
4. The minor factions are a cool addition to the game. Something I havent seen in other similar games. The issue is they are dumb and you just focus on them to build your empire. Especially on harder levels they should be getting protection from the bigger factions so they are just not free buildings.
5. Having a guy assigned to each area of town is a cool touch as somebody who over sees it but once you have 5-6 safe houses that is half your army out of the fight. I would rather see like your boss can have two named guys with him and then has to fill out with the generic thugs. Your underboss can have up to one other named guy with him and then generic guys. The rest of your dudes just get generic guys. It would allow you then to have effectively a handful of crews in town who could all be doing their own thing. Right now I just have a big mob of guys going around to take ♥♥♥♥. It is such a pain in the ass to reassign people to zones that I tend to ignore the bonus and dont have people in them because I would rather having the really tough fighting group.
6. The npc AI is really bad. far too often they have a shot but instead waste movement and get no shot off. Or they move into position then reload. If they need to reload that should always be their first action then decide to shoot or move to cover.
7. The other factions dont seem to buy many of the NPC, and the ones they have I dont ever see. If you have eyes in a zone it should show you on the map if a named guy is moving around with a crew so you could see an ambush coming or ambush them on the street. I have a feeling they just end up sitting in safe houses so add really nothing to the game.
8. The quest log view needs to be upgraded. Only showing one quest at a time is a pain. No reasons you could not have color coded markers for quests so you could see several on the map at a time. Otherwise you could be standing by a quest guy and not even know it because that quest is not your one of focus.
9. Police and Bureau having more of a presents in the game outside of random raids. They should have buildings to mess with. Agents on the street that go at you more, and you can go at them.
10. when I am at war with a faction there is a real disconnect between the war. It is only really attacking their buildings random or they randomly attack yours. More of that fighting happening on the streets would be cool. Being able to have patrols in areas you control. Being able to ambush their patrols etc. The fighting on the streets is going to bring down heat from police which would lead to them having more patrols and starting to shake down local rackets .
11. Instead of having Chicago police, having police by area of town. You may have strong influence with little Italy police but that doesnt mean you would have that same influence in Chinatown.
12. Having either two entrances to come into the safe house from or starting on the street and having to fight into the safe house. I actually like the second better. Currently you are just clumped into the front door and if they have NPC that go early you get grenades dropped on your full group. No real tactical aspect to this. just luck of the draw of who goes early and if they are in grenade range of your party. If you have to start on the streets behind cars while they were in the windows, you would have to fight your way into the house with them having cover advantage. Could have to do so much damage to the front door to get access. After so many rounds police could show up and make the fight even uglier but it would create the need to push the offense instead of just playing defensive.

The game is poor right now but I feel like it has the foundation to be a great game. The AI is so amazingly bad in combat that is makes it hard to even want to play. They waste half their time running around to random spots and never firing.

- Need more ways to make money. The current way is to either go to war with another gang, take over their racket; or create a new racket from scratch by seizing an abandoned building (more or less the same thing). This gets repetitive. There should be a way to, for example, raid rackets of other gangs (without automatically starting a war), rob a store, and collect passive protection money. 
- The economy and $ values are a bit nonsensical. I could buy a crow bar or other melee weapon for approx 7,000. It costs less to open a new business, or even hire someone. Gangs will offer to pay you protection money of $70 a week. Why bother. It also feels like income from rackets is a bit low.
- Combat: Not bad, but not exactly Xcom. A few things scream out to me: melee seems far too inaccurate to be useful and guns are too accurate. Some of the physics is crazy; I am shooting people with 90% accuracy across impossible angles, but i have less than 50% accuracy when trying to punch someone in the face at point blank range? Executing people seems to have no benefit at all.
- to break up the monotony, they should have some combat missions to be timed (similar to xcom). Eg rob a bank and get out in less than 6 moves. 
- fewer gangs so defeating someone feels meaningful.
- The grappling hook is immersion breaking and should be scrapped immediately. It also allows you to drag people through walls, which is absurd.
- diplomacy: While at war, the only option is to seek a truce. If I am winning by a lot, I should be able to force a concession on my opinion (money, territory) on the loser (just copy the concept from other paradox games).
- lieutenants: you shouldn't lose a combatant for appointing one
-encountered a few bugs. Eg at war with someone but impossible to initiate combat, or it says I have lost a battle when in fact I have won.
- automate explore function for gang members. AI does this, but human cant
- right now one ends up spending too much time on combat, but combat is fairly boring. I would push the game towards more management and less combat and it'll be interesting.

89214262.review:
So much unrealised potential. There's something there to build on, but currently the game is quite shallow and bizarrely balanced. Bad economy design, bad strategic UI. Combat is "ok" but some bosses are so incredibly powerful off the bat that they trivialise 95% of the fights you encounter.

The default game settings has 10 districts with ~20-40 potential rackets in each, where there are only 4 varieties to build from. It gets tedious and overwhelming very quickly. It doesn't help that they don't have anything to interact with to help make them stand out. There's no reason to even visit them once you have them. Much like your own safehouses.

Management/Empire UI is poorly thought out. Having so many gangs, including small mobs, but only being able to scroll through them one by one, without a list or search is again tedious. Minor factions don't even have unique portraits, they are all the same and blend together. Not being able to go to diplomacy or info pages on a faction straight from the map, or even by clicking on their portraits in other menus also seems like a glaring oversight.

Game economy is really unbalanced. There's no real reason to bother upgrading your rackets apart from alcohol quality in breweries. Firstly because there are so many of them that it's just not feasible to cover the costs, but also because the costs are so high compared to the income each racket generates that the ROI is terrible. Negotiating "business proposals" with other factions for 2-4% discount buffs is almost useless considering the drama it seems to cause.

It's more profitable to just mask cheap booze as whisky and sell it to factions. Also just selling whisky outright to minor factions is a faster way to make money than relying on your rackets. Item costs and sales prices, and the way your relationship score changes from trades is easily abused and mostly nonsensical. The cache drops across the maps at the start of the game allow you to decently kit out your entire gang before you even start a war, if you want to bother running around everywhere for 30 minutes. Gear seems to hit a peak relatively early as well, so you quickly run out of upgrade opportunities.

The enemy factions also appear to struggle with the game economy, as they tend to constantly be almost broke and as such barely upgrade anything apart from their own safehouse security. Which means you can just declare war and blitz everything they have without much fuss. The only "challenge" is that there can be so much happening across so many districts that you can't keep up with any roaming gangs on the streets to cut them off before they attack your own rackets. Even that's not a big deal, as savvy players will just pause the game and rush security upgrades as needed before the building is stormed.

Lieutenants, underbosses, moles etc all seem like cool ideas that never got past the first cycle of workshopping. You can't even use lieutenants again without "demoting" them and losing morale. There just doesn't seem to be much benefit of making new safehouses and paying to keep someone locked in there for the rest of the game, when you could keep them in your party and use the extra muscle to take down all the other factions faster.

The story and side missions are all fine, nothing outstanding. It seems you generally receive the best outcomes by showing mercy or "being good" at every opportunity, which is a bit odd for a hard boiled gangster-themed game with a cast of sociopaths.

I haven't experienced any particularly big bugs, so at least recent patches appear to have stabilised the game considerably.

All in all I want to like this game a lot more than I currently do. It needs more flavour and more balance. I was holding off on getting it for a long time but finally caved. It was a mistake, as it will need many updates to really find some soul.

The game setting looks good, the concept of a open world meets XCOM style turn based game is very unique, and playing the mob boss from a more strategic level is neat.  The police and feds as a third faction that comes out of nowehere seemingly to ruin your day is a nice touch and the in game missions aren't bad either. 

That said it has some odd hang ups that prevent it from being a cult classic.

-unlike other paradox games where historical accuracy is aimed for and alternative history is played up for a joke this game really mixes things up.  Example Hymie Weiss, the man alleged to be the only man Al Capone feared is someone you can just hire off bat.  
-the gangs are very inclusive and open minded despite what history says, I wouldn't mind this if they did it like CK3 where I have options to play historical or non historical but a lot of these gangs won't even allow you to be in them unless you're of a certain ethnicity or race unless you're the bottom level guys
-There's some sort of relationship system between your henchmen which is mostly just annoying.  I get the concept was some henchmen would not attack each other but mostly it comes off as strange.  Seemingly ALL my henches are bisexual evidently and I've had such strange parings as the black and proud harlem hellfighter and the refuses to be reconstructed ex confederate solider. I mean being gay in the era is wild enough much less the age and race issues going on in that relationship.  But it seems to happen with EVERYONE.  Everybody is just itching to get into some sort of sexual relationships seemingly just as an annoying game mechanic which is all it becomes in the end.  
-Oddly enough the mechanic as progressive and ahistorical as it is, it also hinges entirely off mongamy.  Evidently all my bisexual gangsters refuse to share with anyone.  We run brothels, they're all bi, but no one wants to share or even consider a orgy.  So instead I have to keep my drama queens apart or my XCOM game becomes a slap fight between my crew except with guns.  It's beyond pathetic and really makes me feel like Al Capone should have been questioning his actions long before he had the mayor of Chicago murdered. 
-Honestly all the business management seems really secondary to the turn based fighting.  It's what earns you the money for vests, guns, etc but your best gear comes from other crime bosses which you get by killing them so really the money is just to buy better bisexual hench persons. 
-Oddly about every race is in this game minus hindus, arabs, and islander types...there are two full blooded indigenous Americans as well which can only seem so progressive about a game centered around illegal alcohol trade. Again it's an attempt to be progressive but at what end if you're also trying to be historical?  Henry Hill wasn't exaggerating about the whole not being full blooded Italian means you can't be made, ironically crime is not that open minded about race in fact they're the opposite but won't let it stop them making a buck.  
-The rival gangs are mostly made up which I can somewhat understand but all the legit organizations should be in game.
-All organizations cops, gangs, etc have females in them.  Again I get the progressive tone but it makes the game look more like Michael Jackson's "Smooth Criminal" because they all wear the men's attire regardless.  Only female henchmen, gangbosses, and prostitutes can dress like women.  The 20s must have been a strange time with bisexual criminals who are only into monogamy but have very odd dress code rules.  

Overall it needs work and I think a historical option playing up the more edgy less progressive aspects of the organizations would be interesting as well.  So far this feels more like CK3 when you make everyone bisexual and XCOM combined.

So this is the first game in a while that's actually made me angry because it clearly wasn't ready for release and is now still not fixed.

To illustrate this, basic UI issues and problems like enemies respawning when you load a previous save haven't been fixed. Either the devs are lazy, uncommitted or this game isn't ready for release. 

Now lets look at what makes the game frustrating to play:

1. The combat.  For XCOM style combat, you would think people in the 20s all have polio. The AP distance for running is appalling, and I think this choice was made to draw out combat or because the AI was too easily flanked. The effect however is it makes combat unsatisfying as you crawl towards your enemy 6 tiles at a time, having no choice but to take hits simply to advance. A proper development route would be upgrade your AI, not hobble the player. Finally, you have no time to setup or plan attacks, you can take very few strategic decisions. Flanking is difficult because of the run distance, your best option is just to (boringly) blaze away from static positions while the AI runs up to you. Yes that's right, if you stay in one place, the AI just runs at you, sometimes not even bothering with cover, until they are mowed down. 

2. I could live with the map mode but there is no solidity or robustness to the UI. None of the menus or charts are interactive or interesting. I frequently have problems trying to actually upgrade my establishments, as the menu to do so it inexplicably buried within other menus, which do nothing. Similarly, the weapons shop stupidly has a $20,000 gun in it the moment you start the game, and for the first 2-4 hours, not very much else. What is that - something to aim for? I think it was put in there because the devs were embarrassed about lack of early content, personally.

3.  The characters are good, the missions ok, but there is very little strategic feel right now.

I await the expansions. I think the first one shoud be free as an apology for the terrible combat. Then fix the AI. Then do something about the horrible disorganised UI. Then you will have a playable game ready for a decent expansion.

How to put it.

This game is a classic turn-based tactical game as I like them, with a management aspect that is really enjoyable... until the bugs arrive.
Before you read the rest I want to emphasize that if the game was finished it would be absolutely great. A fresh take on XCOM strategy (although a bit too much of an XCOM copy-pasta but that's even another subject).

Now onto the part that'll make you angry...
Here are some things from the top of my head after finishing one playthrough, eliminating 9 other gangs, in 14 hours :

- Characters regularly bug and take 10 seconds to make a single shot. As you are repeatedly firing, you find yourself just waiting around very often.
- Enemies sometimes go out of bounds and the game crashes.
- The combat AI is plain trash. Enemies will walk and stop in front of you without cover. They'll sometimes pass their turn without firing when they have you actually pinned down. They'll go back and forth, use the wrong gun, or fire shotguns from the other side of the map. Total mess.
- On a related point, the game is completely unbalanced. On normal difficulty, *I wasn't attacked once*. I just STOMPED over every single gang Chicago had to offer. At the end of the game, the breweries I captured to the AI were still producing swill, the first of five levels of alcohols you can upgrade. Evidently the fucked up combat AI doesn't help here and makes it very easy to exploit the AI and win pretty much every fight easily.
- The "hair trigger" skill is either bugged or completely unbalanced. When a gangster goes insane because of this skill, he will fire long bursts at every enemy he can see. When it's a gangster that knows how to handle a gun you will often see 4 or 5 enemies be killed just by him, with a tommy gun from the other side of the map. This simply turned the tables on some relatively challenging boss fights, that were won just by this.
- Sound bugs are popping regularly and some sounds are poorly mixed. Some gangsters have a much higher volume on their voice.
- Quests are buggy, I couldn't finish some of them, scripts would simply not trigger at some point.
- Also the mistakes with the XCOM interface were kept without improvement.
And don't get me started on little details like the UI that is often wrong (a price is shown but it's actually another, the status icons over enemies heads remain even when they are dead, or poor UI choices like these status menus that go up and down automatically when they're bigger than the screen, or the mousewheel that doesn't work on the EFFING LONG lists of rackets you have at the end of the game...).

It's late and I didn't write down everything I saw so I'm missing a lot here.
Anyway, right now it's just a mess.

BUT, a playable mess. So if you really love XCOM and want some more of it, go ahead. Just know where you're stepping.
Oh and a last thing. Don't play normal difficulty if you're an XCOM veteran, and if you do choose a high difficulty, don't choose more than 6 or 7 enemy factions if you don't want one playthrough to take you 40 hours (which you don't want because there's a lot of repetitive fighting and mechanics).

For me, I'm out and may be back in a year when the DLC's are available and if they have seriously worked on all this stuff.

As of me last playing this on 12/13/2020, this game did not stand out at all. The game was simple to grasp, and might give you enough bits here and there to keep you going. Those bits are just distractions to the giant lack of features and mechanics that helps make the core gameplay interesting and exciting.

* The core gameplay mechanics center around property management and turn based combat.

Turn-based combat: It feels pretty ok at first but as the amount of enemies and tougher gangsters appear, it feels drawn out and unnecessarily long. You're also forced to manage the defenses of your own property when an enemy gang decides to invade you, which can feel frustrating if you don't have one of your tougher underlings stationed nearby. The generic units you get and face in the property defense feels boring and more of a numbers game, which further unnecessarily extends the length of the fight.

Property Management: The concept feels pretty ok, but I don't think I've been able to generate enough money off the property and have been spending more time raiding and invading. Although I've only had a short time playing it, the upgrades don't feel impactful for the defenses and the payout isn't noticable in the long term for profits. Also there's a constant change in the areas that can affect the amount you can make, which is to deter you from monopolizing on a single product line.

They have posted that they created a community group to gather feedback and directly influence the development, but I am still waiting to see something that changes to jump out at me. I'm sure that alot of people are enjoying what it has to offer, but it doesn't really make much of a good impression for me, and feels more like an early access game.

If i had to give it a rating: 3/5
There are some interesting concepts that they want to do but it needs further fleshing out to make gameplay more interesting and less of a chore for certain core mechanics. There is definitely room for improvement.

I would not recommend this game in the state it was in, since I last played.

83963599.review: The idea behind Empire of Sin is a great one and it really has no modern games to compare it to. This is due to the fact that this game combines XCOM like combat with Civilization like diplomacy all set in 1920s Chicago. However, This game simply falls short in every way imaginable. To start, this game masquerades itself as a strategy game, but there is really no strategy involved whatsoever. Unlike the Civilization series, you really only have alcohol and money to use in trading and diplomacy, which makes the game feel shallow and makes replaying the game boring and repetitive. Even if the game included more resources and things to trade, it wouldn’t matter because the only win condition is that you kill all of the other faction leaders, which makes diplomacy completely irrelevant. The level design is mediocre at best and the combat is extremely boring and tedious, which makes warring against enemy factions redundant as the game forces you to fight every individual battle. For a 1920s Mafia game, the world lacks any realism, factions do not recruit crewmates within their nationality and ethnicity, and women make up half of the bosses and crewmates. I realize that in our current world everyone is accepted regardless of race or gender, but this makes a game set in the 1920s not really feel immersive. In its current state the game is riddled with bugs and a lot of them are game breaking ones. On top of all of this, the games released at $39.99, which is a horrendous price for a game that maybe has 10 to 20 hours of content tops. Not to mention that Paradox will likely release countless DLCs to fix and add elements to the game that should have been there in the base game. Overall, I most certainly do not recommend this game in its current form, and at its current price. 83948680.review:
Empire of Sin is a XCOM based game with some management elements thrown in, set in 1920s Chicago

The Good

Music - The music in this game is really good. The Jazz soundtrack fits the timeperiod and both the battle and background music is fitting.

The Bosses - All of the bosses are unique in a way or another. All are very strong, bordering on overpowered.

The Items - There are a lot of different weapons in this game, all with different stats.

The Neutral

Gameplay - The gameplay is hit or miss. Boss battles are fun, but 95% of all fights are with either random thugs or guards. The gameplay is fun, but it gets repetitive after fighting 2 or 3 thugs for the 200th time

Management - The Management aspect of the game is very basic. There are only 4 types of Outlets to own and all 4 feel similar to each other. Both the Speakeasy and Brothel buildings act completely the same, with Casinos being a little bit of a difference. The only one that is completely unique is the Brewery. 

The Bad

Bugs - This game is full of bugs. From animation glitches to not selecting the correct target and a really annoying glitch that happened when ambushing, which required to load an earlier save. 

Notification Spam - The game spams you with different notifications. Most of the time the notifications are meaningless like the events happening on the other side of the city.

Difficulty - XCOM games are very difficult, but this game is every easy. I played the game on Underboss difficulty and it wasn't difficult.

Exploits - Even tho they patched the exploit where you could sell huge amounts of swill for whiskey to a minor faction, the game has a lot of exploits. You can exploit the Weapon stashes for better weapons and equipment, boss abilities can win the game with ease and many more.

Replayability - The game is a semi roguelike, but the replayability for the game is terrible. There isn't some special objective for each Boss to win the game. For every boss you need to kill every single boss in the game and that's it. There isn't some special mission for each Boss that you need to do. Also the map is the same every time. If you could change your city to some other notorious cities of the time period, then maybe this could work.

Overall 

Overall this is an OK, but very flawed game. Despite the many shortcomings, the game was enjoyable, but I can't recommend getting the game unless it's on Sale. Overall a 6/10. If some of the shortcomings are dealt with, then it could be a good, maybe great game, but as of writing it's an OK game with a lot of flaws

83931582.review:
I want to like this game, I really do. I love Paradox Interactive, I think they're a fantastic studio/publisher. They've got some of my favorite games under their belt (Surviving Mars/Aftermath, Stellaris, etc), and I like the setting, music, and ambiance. 

The primary problem, in my opinion, comes from the game play. It's part of the core game play loop so I'm not sure if or how it could be fixed. The combat in this game is the turn based, grid based, isometric style any X-Com player would recognize. It is significantly simpler than X-Com2, which came out almost 5 years ago.  It gets repetitive, quickly, and there is a lot of it. Oh boy is there a lot of it. Seems like, with few exceptions when you're focusing on base building for a few minutes, there is a generated fight every 5 minutes or so. The maps get repetitive (you'll see repeats within the first 5 fights), it's basically the same 3-5 bad guy set up each time. It just is too much of the same thing. 

I would have liked to see this game focus a greater emphasis on base building / empire management. I'm sure the world opens up more as you progress. I've got 9 hours logged on the game in two playthroughs (I restarted after realizing it wasn't a great idea to pick a fight with Capone as a newbie, but the combat is easy enough where you think it might be.) 

I don't know, I want to like this game. It's got great flavor and the world building based on characters' backstories slowing coming out through interactions with other bosses is an interesting set up. It's just that you see that combat screen way too frequently for how simplistic the fighting actually is. Hopefully the fighting gets more complex, or the frequency gets turned down, but I cannot recommend this game in it's current state. Go find Omerta: City of Gangsters (Kaplyso Media game from 2013) for a few bucks on sale somewhere and you're getting a lot of the same game for 90% cost reduction.

83727579.review:
This game deserves it's mixed reviews. It's got some great concepts at its core, and cool ideas, but in its current state it completely fails to be a good gaming experience.

Empire of Sin looks like it started as an ode to mafia strategy games like Gangsters: Organized Crime, but quickly got taken over by X-Com. That actually seemed appealing at first, but the two genres never really seem to mesh. Your criminal empire is made up of various "rackets" that generate different amounts of cash depending on various upgrades. There's a deep menu explaining the desires of each ward in the city, and how well the rackets are fulfilling those needs. There are bonuses for adjacency. There are special Hotel rackets that don't generate much income, but do generate more demand. There's a system of prosperity in the wards that changes what people in those wards want at different times in the game.

None of that matters. None of it. There are just tons and tons of systems built for a Mafia strategy game that just simply don't matter at all to your success. The real game is in the turn-based combat. Using just a few men, you can easily take over most enemy rackets as they only start with 2 guards, and upgrading security is expensive, and takes a while. That means that most combat is a breeze, and by the mid-game you'll be dominating almost all battles.

When you get to a certain point you'll be able to reliably take down enemy safe houses, which are the only challenging battles in the game. Once that happens, the game is just a few battles from being over, as taking out an enemy safe house nets you their entire empire all at once. That just makes the game feel like it could have been re-tooled to be a story-driven turn-based squad combat game, and strip out the totally unnecessary strategy sim. 

I don't know how to fix this. Maybe it's just core balance issues. Maybe Rackets need to start with more defenses by default so you can't just plough your way through the game with combat, but as it stands right now the game doesn't "work".

That being said, I see a lot of complaints about bugs, and I only ran into one bug while playing, and it was fairly minor (a character always appeared to be dead, but functioned properly otherwise). Maybe some of the bugs are under control now.

I played around for 11.2 hours on the lieutenant difficulty. Beating game on the in game date of Sep 14 1920 by just clearing out the other mobsters. I beat the game without doing the quest the game gives you at the very start. Even beating the game the day I got it. 

You have a number of different bosses to chose from. With there people being from Hungary to China available for you to play as. Other bosses willing to team up with you more if you come from the same place as them or your personality match theirs. Which is what I saw in one youtube video on the game. 

Gameplay wise I love it. You have these different abilities to play with from your boss’s special ability to hinchmen’s abilities. With pistols to machine guns. Semi-autos to fully automatic weapons. The people you hire can be formed up how you like them to play

Each henchmen have different relationships with other characters. Which may cause them to leave if you shoot the people they love. Which happened to me once in the game. 

The racket system is rather simple. You produce liquor for your speakeasy. Liquor to make your Casino visitors not be able to think. And you have hotels to bring people into your neighborhood to increase the amount of customers. If the customer’s tastes in liquor change, you can change the production of your breweries. 

I love the naming feature as it's fun to name something you owned after taking it over or buying it. 

There is diplomacy from trading to allying yourself with others against other bosses. I barely used it except for declaring war on everyone.

There were only a few issues I had with the game. Fast Travel was too easy to use since there are taxis all over the place. My run as Sai Wing Mock Usually involved me fast traveling and poison bombing the guards out of nowhere. 

Another issue is that the boss' abilities are op. Sai Wing Mock’s ability can allow you to throw three bombs which poison an area for the rest of the battle. I usually clear out most of the guards in the battles thanks to me having three bombs. This would be more balanced if Mock could only throw two bombs. 

The third issue is that the unique items you get from the bosses are worth the risk of killing the bosses. Unique items pretty much turn your Zeros into Heros. I gave my mercs the unique items and they easily did their jobs well. It makes me wish the items could only be obtained through special side quests or could only be found in random locations. 

Another issue is that the other bosses very little through the game use their abilities. The only boss I saw use theirs was Genna after I ended most of the other bosses. When he threw knives at my gang during my raid on his safe house. 

Another issue I had with this was that you could beat this game with low tier mercs. The bosses only have one merc with them. With them usually being a medic. In the end I never got my hands on the best mercs and just swarmed the last bosses with low tier mercs carrying unique weapons.

There is one issue I have that is a single glitch. The first one and only one I encountered was that gangsters from other gangs stick around after their bosses are dead. I had an encounter with the Vice Kings long after their boss was dead. By this time I’m pretty sure there was already a funeral for Jackson. 

It didn’t bother me much until I raided Colt’s safe house. After I defeated the White Circus while they were at war with Colt. I got war declared on me by Colt. I went in and the White Circus had the last laugh. As the White Circus guards teamed up with Colt and his gang. Making it impossible for me to take over Colt’s Safe house. So reloaded a save and waited for Dyer to kill Colt before I killed her.  

Also during the lieutenant mode, I spent little on my rackets and never got raided by the police. I wish the game rewarded you for spending time waiting for more money even though you are strong enough to end the other bosses careers.

Despite the issues, this was a fun game to play. It's a lot easier compared to Paradox’s other games like EU4 or HOI4. Though it could use a lot of additions to make the game a bit more complex then how it is. Which can be added over time with DLC.

Take the turn-based tactical combat of XCOM, combine it with the management elements of a tycoon game, and slap a mafia skin on it, what could go wrong? Well, as it turns out, a lot of things, actually.

[h2]Gameplay:[/h2]
So let’s just start this off by saying that I’m disappointed more than anything. This is a game with a fantastic concept, a game that could have been good. However, the execution is just shallow, nowhere near enough to really sell the experience.

I have two major problems with Empire of Sin: its combat elements and its management elements. Considering that those are the two major areas to the game, we’re already off to a bad start, but I’ll talk about the combat first.

[h2]Combat:[/h2]
This is a strategy game that has combat done in a turn-based tactics manner, similar to the XCOM series. You get your group of gangsters, enter a building, and have to eliminate all of the opposition to win. It’s pretty simple, but the real experience lies in the depth of that combat. I will admit, my first couple hours with the game, I was actually satisfied. The combat was fun and I was having a good time going from building to building growing my empire.

However, I quickly found out that there is really nothing beyond that. The combat does not really evolve, it kinda remains static throughout the entire game, whether you be 2 hours in or 20. Despite going into different buildings, you’ll start to notice the exact same layouts, the same enemy types, the same weapons, and the same abilities used in every single fight. Sure, you unlock more abilities as your characters level up, but it’s only like four or five until they’ve maxed out, nowhere near enough to offer the combat depth required to avoid that feeling of monotony.

Due to how simple it is, the combat eventually devolves into this repetitive sequence that you can apply to every single fight and win without issue. In fact, once I had a group of six or so gangsters, I pretty much steamrolled any competition. Whether it be a simple building takeover or a boss fight – they all felt the same and this alone honestly kills the overall experience.

[h2]Management:[/h2]
There is another side to the game though through its management elements. And unfortunately, those management elements are equally lacking. I would go so far as to equate them to a clicker game, as all you’re really doing is applying upgrades, switching which alcohol your establishments serve, and waiting for money to apply even more upgrades. There really is not much to do here, and it was so bad that at one point I was literally sitting there fiddling with my phone while I waited for money to come in so I could buy more upgrades so that the money would come in faster so that I could buy more upgrades and you can kinda see where this is going.

However, all of that goes out the window when you realize that the entire management aspect is kinda pointless. Why spend time upgrading stuff or changing what alcohol your establishments are serving when you can simply waltz into an enemy safehouse, kill their boss, and acquire all of their buildings with just that one battle. Do this for each boss in the game and you’ve won, without ever needing to really engage with any sort of management.

Really, the most management you get is with your characters themselves. They each have their own skill tree, a bunch of different equipment slots, and even traits and relationships. For example, a character that is in love with another gangster will not attack them even if they are on the opposing side in a battle. And sometimes a character’s loyalty to you will unlock gangsters for hire that would have otherwise been unavailable. Playing around with the characters was easily the best part of the management side to the game, but unfortunately the bulk of that side is managing your establishments – the boring part.

[h2]Technical Issues:[/h2]
During my time with the game, I ran into plenty of animation issues, clipping, and freezes during combat that would hang the game for seconds at a time. That and the AI is not the greatest either, oftentimes putting itself in really bad positions during combat or just acting in a manner that actively ruins their chances of winning. I was fortunate to not run into any crashes (the game has been patched up a bit since its rocky launch), but it’s still not an entirely smooth experience.

[h2]Overall:[/h2]
I cannot recommend Empire of Sin. Patches may be able to fix the technical problems, but the core to the game is just far too shallow to be worth the time. Repetitive combat, lackluster management elements, it just loses its appeal after those initial few hours. A shame, as I really like the concept here, but the execution just doesn’t cut it.

Before getting to the pros & cons, let me just say there is a good game to be found here. The problem is, it's buried beneath layers of flawed AI design and a plethora of still-unfixed bugs, among other things. The problem is that the developers shoved this out way too early. This game needed another few weeks or months of work before releasing, because this game has faults that no simple handful of bug fix patches are going to necessarily fix.

Pros:
-The Prohibition-era aesthetic is one that's rarely explored in videogame form, and from a historical angle, this game is a pretty accurate (if obviously exaggerated) depiction of said era.
-The visual quality is impeccable, no complaints there, especially during mob boss sit-downs.
-The soundtrack likewise is a joy to listen to.
-The overall city management is pretty well handled, although not quite as elaborate as other prominent business/city simulator games.
-The companion characters are surprisingly detailed and memorable.

Cons:
-Building upgrades have almost no meaningful variety to them. While each building technically has its own unique upgrades, they all fulfill nearly identical purposes across the board, distinguishable really only by their visual icons.
-There is no automation for any task. You better love handling everything manually without exception, because that's effectively the only playstyle this game supports, even if it's for something as minor as handling a customer who might secretly be a government spy looking to bust you for breaking prohibition. I hire bartenders for a reason. What's the point in paying AI staff to work for me if they won't even handle anything? This kind of thing gets really annoying the 100th time it happens in a single game.
-The game will frequently soft crash during combat sequences. I've had a single character continue to spray bullets for upwards of 5 minutes at a time nonstop, just looping the animation nonstop.
-Hope you really love seeing the same lethal finisher animation again and again, because your character seemingly only has two: 1 for their primary weapon, and 1 for their melee. My character just cackled insanely like Mark Hamill's Joker while spraying bullets into the enemy's chest, or slitting their throat with a knife. With the cackling, it was kind of creepy over time.
-The skill trees for both the player character and the NPCs you hire are laughably simplistic. It felt like an honestly good concept that was given almost no depth, when the game could've really benefited from having more depth.

This goes to my biggest overall gripe with this game. It doesn't seem to know what it wants to be. Does it want to be a more streamlined action-driven XCOM 2 like experience? Or does it want to be this slow methodical experience that appeals to more traditional RPG and city simulator type players? The end result feels like a failure on both ends.
I do not hate this game, there are some aspects I really enjoy. It is on the verge of being what I would consider an amazing game. But its lack of focus, and overall mediocre quality even now, almost 3 weeks after its initial launch, means I sadly cannot recommend it to anyone in its present state.

My best wishes to the Romero Games staff. The fact that you guys were able to work on this game during this time is a testament to your dedication and work ethic. I just wish your team was allowed a little more time to focus on polishing what is otherwise a very solid game.

Empire of Sin probably sits at a 6 or 7/10 as it currently stands on 22/12/2020. Recommended if you enjoy the time period, X-Com games, crime/business sims. If you're not a huge fan of those things then wait for a sale or for the DLC to be released. There are two planned DLCs at this point each bringing deeper game mechanics and more stories/characters etc. If you're not a fan of Prohibition Crime or X-Com/Business Sim games then maybe wait until the Complete Edition or the base game is on sale. 

[b]The Good:[/b]
* X-Com style strategic turn based combat 

* Decent roster of main gangsters to choose from, both real (Al Capone, Dion O'Banion etc.) and original characters each with unique playstyles and empire bonuses (some are great at combat, some are better at running brothels for cheap, some can produce more booze for cheaper etc.)

* About 50 gangsters to recruit into your gang, again a good mix of real gangsters from the time period and original characters, each with their own backstories, unique story arcs, bonuses, and relationships to each other (for instance some gangsters are friends or lovers and will go into a rage if their lover is hurt or killed, some are enemies and will refuse to work together etc.) 

* The sitdown system and diplomacy are a welcome addition, and can make the minor gangs into useful allies or something more than just enemies to subjugate. 

[b]The Bad:[/b]

* Gameplay can get a bit repetitive once your empire is established. With the planned DLC claiming to add extra gameplay mechanics this will likely change in the future, but for now it can be quite repetitive, especially with how slow money making can be at the start. 

* Bugs can often affect gameplay (sometimes animations don't load and your character just floats from pace to place, sometimes the combat screen doesn't load when you enter hostile buildings and you have to reload the save, etc.) 

* Some characters are far more powerful than others due to their special abilities. Goldie Garneau for instance can just about clear an entire building by herself, while Salazar Reyna's special ability often misses or fails to kill enemies even when they are in the open. This can lead to having to adopt similar or boring playstyles for weaker characters to make them viable. 

[b]The Ugly:[/b]

* The voice acting is often pretty bad. Some characters sound like they're doing a bad imitation of how they think people sounded back then, see? 

* AI is terrible. They often make bad pathing and combat decisions and the trade system is skewed, you can often convince the AI to trade away their OP special weapon for a few common rarity pistols and $3000. 

* No fast-time option, so you're forced often to sit and do nothing for 5-10 minutes while you're waiting for money to roll in so you can upgrade your businesses.

The biggest sin in empire of sin, is that of publishing this game as a finished product rather than an Early Access. I don't know whether the onus is on the developer or the publisher or both, but it's a blatant lack of ethics  and of respect for prospective custommers. Sadly, it is increasingly common in the gaming industry.

The game is a bit further than one might expect from the initial release of an Early Access in that the storyline for each boss is already in, but as far as bugs and game mechanics polish go, I've played Early Access games that were further along the development line on day 1 of their Early Access (props to Fell Seal: Arbiter's Mark team) than Empire of Sin is on an official release.

So if you chose to buy this game in the state as of this review, beware that you are buying into an Early Access for a game that will hopefully meet it's expectations only several months from now.

I can't endorse this product because of the unethical marketing strategy. I would've paid full price to participate in an Early Access if it had been properly advertised as such because the genre is right up my alley and the game looked (and still looks) like it could have a lot of potential down the line.

That's the end of the short version. Details below.

As for appreciation of the game in it's current state:
-The atmosphere and music is great albeit a little repetitive.
-The voice acting embodying the personality of the bosses is enjoyable, although limited in scope.
-The graphics are fine although still bug-ridden e.g.
--Attack animations causing characters to go through walls or shoot through objects
--Certain characters end "frozen" during some or all of their animations and when this happens, it appears to slow down the execution of actions.

-Given the prevalence of tactical combat in the current state of the game, the fact that buildings where combat take place only have a handful few layouts for each building size quickly becomes very repetitive.

-There remains a lot of gameplay bugs, even after 2 big bugfix patches. I have only experienced one that was gamebreaking and forced me to restart a new game, and it was in the intro tutorial with Goldie. However I've had to reload to last save for a couple of bugs, or save and reload right away for a handful few very annoying ones, and there are others you just accept to playthrough however annoying.

-Gameplay is very shallow. And this is well above bugs as to why I feel this should've been released as an early access game. There are 2 main game systems, the tactical combat system and the empire simulation system. They intertwine by allowing you to hire better mercenaries or purchase gear or by hostile acquisition of revenue-generating buildings.

--The game can be won while ignoring the empire simulation altogether. You can kill every other boss and win the game, no matter how well guarded they are, with your own boss alone on max difficulty. Part of this is game balance. Another part is heal/sustain mechanics and most likely a bug with a healing item. And an even bigger chunk is terrible combat AI.

--The combat advantages gained from a good empire sim are very marginal, unless you purposefully stretch the game to wait for later game mercenaries to catch up and be fully upgraded as the cheaper/early game ones are. Gear from merchants is generally worse than the random loot you get from thug hunting/box farming.

--Even with self-imposed rules or boundaries to try and explore empire simulation, the max difficulty AI is quickly outscaled. I won my second playthrough with self-imposed rules by 1923 because I had nothing else left to do than finish the bosses off. By contrast, prohibition lasted until 1933. Eventually you just realise that you would need to self-impose a lot of idle time to try and reel the player's growth potential in line with the poor AI and the simulation mechanics are neither sufficiently complex nor varied to where even very casual gamers won't figure enough out within a few hours.

Despite all of that, I still have mild enjoyment playing this game because of the laid back jazz atmosphere and some of the more corny dialogue and the sheer laugh of breaking the game so hard.

First of all, I got this for free through my wife who works at Paradox. However, I've got nothing at stake here personally.

I am still undecided what to say about this game, or if I want to recommend this game or not. After 17 hours, I just finished my first playthrough... first 15 or so hours I took it slow, then I got a bit bored (and overwhelmed with the management), so I just went around and killed everyone in a row, winning the game. But let's take a deeper look in things below.

---

The game's premise is pretty interesting. I like a bit of management, as well as good old turn based combat. The theme is also close to my heart, so I was very tempted to buy this game. Luckily I ended up getting it for free, so I launched the game and dug in.

Within the first 20 minutes I realized that I am not actually playing a game made by an AAA studio headed by John Romero - I was playing a sort of an indie dev game that somehow had big names attached to it. The game feels like a small studio game, where the publisher has pressured the team to make a game too complex and too fast, without enough playtesting.

The game is simply clunky. From controls to camera to combat to management, everything feels like there's a good IDEA behind it, but not enough testing and not enough planning actually went in to the features. You'll very quickly realize that the AI in combat is wacky to say the least and very easy to exploit. At the same time, the management of different rackets is a bit confusing and extremely cumbersome. The story is explained through quests, but they are not very well presented, they get a bit confusing and in the end I completely ignored them. They need to be paced a lot better.

Once you snow ball in this game even a little, it's super easy to just go and take over everything, while ignoring the story, police raids etc. You just go from a generic battle to another. There's also plenty of weird little bugs that occur pretty much all the time. However I did not run into massive game breaking bugs, unlike some other people have.

There's a few longer, better reviews that outline my feelings towards the game very well:
https://steamcommunity.com/id/BadgerBrownCoat/recommended/604540/
https://steamcommunity.com/id/TheDeluxeTux/recommended/604540/

---

With all that being said... I wish I could go into more details about everything. With less than 20 hours though, I don't feel I can do that properly. The game has many glaring, major issues and it doesn't feel like a proper, released game. However, with all its faults it is a playable game and has a certain charm to it. Of the 17 hours I have played so far, 15 were somehow still enjoyable and kept me engaged. I had fun and I didn't hate the game, even with all its faults. In a way it felt like a game that was just deep enough to interest me and shallow enough at the same time to allow me to enjoy an hour or two after work.

Even though the devs have announced that there'll be DLC's coming, I don't think anyone should bother with them. Get the game in a sale, hope the devs abandon this after a few patches. I hope - and so should you - that they'll get enough money and goodwill out of this demo of a game to get funding for Empire of Sin 2, which would be properly planned and tested before release.

At the moment this game is only worth about 10 USD. I can recommend it at around that price range, and if you have tolerance for small issues. And if you like the theme. But it's not an AAA game. It's a game that feels like it's done by industry beginners.

This should have been the launch state of the game, I am growing tired of video games launching it a crap state and then patching it out months later. You want your money? Give me a quality game from the start.

[h1]Bugs[/h1]
1. Battle will start, but the first character's turn will never begin. Game and save breaking.
2. Animation bugs where a character will be stuck in the shooting and downed pose. When animation bugs occur the time to take an action increases dramatically.
3. Occasionally, you won't be able to attack a building. You confirm when prompted and it just sits there.
4. Hotel Synergies go all crazy sometimes. I've had to SELL a racket to get all of the synergies before.
5. Battles don't end when you kill the last enemy if 2 friendly factions are at war with each other.
6. Death animations do weird things when using melee attacks.
7. Sometimes the UI shows an action unavailable (no color) like you don't have action points, when you're full action points and can execute the action anyways.

[h1]Balance Issues[/h1]
EDIT: I just want to say, this game was the first game I received all of the achievements. It is incredibly unbalanced, resulting in a strategy game that requires no strategy.
1. AI will accept absurd trades. There are a lot of exploits that stem from this issue.
2. You can trade for the AI faction's unique weapons and they'll never equip another one, leaving them weaponless in battle.
3. Quick travel takes no time. This allows you to explore the whole map, meet all of the factions, and collect all hidden stashes in one in-game week.
4. Stashes are on the map from the start of the game. This makes the game trivial. Collect a few good stashes, equip your team, kill every enemy. Why interact with rackets, synergies, trade-deals, or quests?
5. Healing can be done instantly by quick travel to safehouse, which costs nothing. It can also be done using skills by starting an ambush, using healing skill, cancelling ambush, and repeating. This makes the doctor passive heal pointless.

82600914.review:
I've played about forty hours so far of Empire of Sin and have finished the game six times.  It's not a perfect game, but I have a lot of fun when I am playing it and it does keep me coming back.

The setting is great, and I love the different feels to each of the neighborhoods in Chicago.  I really like the dynamic zoom mechanic that the developers made for this game, where you can smooth-scroll from inside a building to outside the building, to a view of the street, to a tactical view of the neighborhood, to a tactical view of all neighborhoods, all in real-time.  This feature is great and is not getting nearly enough credit in the reviews.

The game has quite a bit going on with it.  You've got a light economic management thing going on, which mostly consists of producing and setting the correct types of booze, and buying or taking over buildings.   You can also upgrade establishments, but with the current build of the game (Dec 2020), upgrades are usually not worth it, as they are expensive and take a long time to build after you pay for them.  The game rewards going as wide as possible as quickly as possible, so my go-to strategy is basically to start to clear out and take over the neutral casinos and speakeasies as soon as a new game starts.

Meanwhile, you've got a bunch of other mob bosses running around setting up their own empires.  When you meet one, you can either tell them to go pound sand or you can sit down with them to cut a deal.  The deals that you cut with the mob bosses are so incremental that they are barely noticeable, but I think the sit-downs themselves are quite fun, if a tad repetitive.  After your initial meeting, there are a range of diplomacy options available.  These are generally pretty useless, except for the trading, which is currently rigged in the player's favor.  It does not take much to convince bosses to sell your their unique weapons in exchange for some garbage ones and have them walk away thinking they got the better of you.

While it is currently very easy to complete the game without diplomacy at all, diplomacy can be used to win, in a manner of speaking.  I did play a game where I quietly took over unoccupied neighborhoods and made nice with all mob bosses and stepped on no toes.  Then, I sold them all weapons for peanuts, and they all trusted me.  Then, I kept calling in favors and repeatedly called in a hit on every boss with every other boss, and watched them wipe each other out.  Then, when there was one left, I just went in with a small team and took that person out.

You've also got an RPG-like quest system in this game.  There's a few generic quests available to every mob boss; these were fun in my first playthrough but the rewards were pretty crappy so I have more or less ignored most of them since.  Each boss also has a main questline, this can be a nice diversion.

Finally, you've got the gangster system and the tactical battles.

The gangster system is a neat idea and does a lot of things right, but needs a bit of work.  There is a roster of henchmen that both you and the CPU opponents can hire.  While theoretically you can assign your henchmen as neighborhood managers or as protectors of one of your buildings, in reality you and your henchmen will all fight together as a roving squad of death, as that is by far the most effective use for them.  Gangsters have different classes, but the doctor and demolitionist classes are far superior to any of the other three, as doctors get free healing and can also use rifles, the best weapon in the game, and demolitionists get a free grenade that does massive AOE damage and causes bleeding. As you increase in notoriety, you can hire more expensive and more skilled henchmen.  Currently, there is not much difference between the cheapest goons and the most elite killers; I would love to see the lower tiers of henchmen nerfed quite a bit, and the higher tiers buffed.

The tactical battles are the best part of the game and are the reason I keep coming back.  The difficulty is generally pretty easy, except when you are up against a group of enemies who all decide to lob grenades on the same turn.  The safehouse raids are so much fun!  (they need to be harder, though, and a greater variety of safehouses would be sweet).

Empire of Sin also has a great score by Crimson Diamond composer Dan Policar and team; I would pay extra for a soundtrack if Paradox decides to sell one (please, Paradox!).

All in all, this game is a lot of fun right now, but also has a lot of room for improvement.  I am optimistic about the future of Empire of Sin.

Empire of Sin:
~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Next time you look at yourself in the mirror (without saying that you are the most awesome man or woman in the world), ask yourself, who would you choose to be if you were born in Chicago during the 1920’s prohibition? Perhaps you would be a Smart Operator, and always keep your enemies next close to you.  Or an Enforcer, who bullies everyone on sight. A Con Artist who would sell gallons of water pretending that it’s the finest whiskey ever made (well, that would be a bit far-fetched but after 5 or 7 drinks it’s usually hard to tell!).  Well, here is your chance to become one of the most fearful individuals of that time! So, forget about it (your sins) and built a mighty empire in the charming downtown Chicago.  So boss, what’s next in the Empire of Sin?

Empire of Sin is an RTS/turn-based strategy/management game developed by Romero Games and published by Paradox Interactive on the Steam platform on the 2nd of December 2020. 

The first thing you have to do before writing your history in downtown 1920’s Chicago is to set up a game. You’ll have to choose one of the 14 available characters, each with 4 specific abilities.  Some of these characters were actual gangsters, such as Al Capone, Angelo Genna and Daniel McKee Jackson, while others are fictional. Then you’ll have to choose how many neighbourhoods (3 to 10) Chicago will be divided into, how many factions will be participating in the struggle, and finally, in which level of difficulty you’ll be playing the game.  They are 5 in total from Associate to Boss. I strongly recommend the Normal (or in this case the Lieutenant) difficulty on your first playthrough.

As you appear for the first time in one of Chicago’s neighbourhoods (will depend on who you have chosen as a boss), a fellow will appear on the bottom left of your screen. He will show you the ropes, including the options you have within the game (tutorial). He will appear every time you have to learn a new game feature, but you can disable it at any given time. 
The game is pretty much a real-time strategy game with three distinct phases which you can swap between at any time. An important point to mention is that you can also pause the game when you want to check the status of your rackets, or upgrade them, hire new gangsters and equip them, try to form an alliance with other family bosses or even bribe the police department. 

The main phase is the Chicago map which you can zoom out to see all the suburbs and zoom in straight onto the street, where you can move and command your group of gangsters about what to do next. You’ll have a few rackets in your neighbourhood at the start of each game. By zooming out onto the suburb view, you’ll be able to see which buildings you own, other families or factions who own rackets and another two types of buildings you can acquire. The vacant buildings have a green dollar sign icon on them, and the buildings that have an orange target icon on them are occupied by thugs!  You’ll need enough money in your coffin to purchase the property first and then convert it to one racket of your choice, which is speakeasies, brothels, casinos, breweries, hotels and safe houses. You can avoid forking out any money by attacking another family racket and taking it over, but you’ll be at war with them straight away. You best bet is to attack the building where the thugs are. At least you wont have to buy the property, but it will still cost you to convert the building into a racket. If you decide to explore other neighbourhoods, you can do so by clicking on the taxi icons located somewhere in each suburb. 

You’ll trigger the combat phases by attacking a building and on most occasions, you’ll need to battle the guards outside and inside the buildings. Beware not to attack a building if you see the cops walking on the same street as they will jump into the gunfight to try to arrest all the people involved. Sure, you can kill them if you want, but the relationship with the police department will take a big hit each time you gun down an officer. And let me tell you, you’ll blow serious money with corrupt cops to try to rectify the issue. Your best bet is to escape by positioning your characters onto the white square on the edges of the battle map (street). 

Each gangster at your disposal will have two action points which you can use for movements and actions such as shooting at an enemy, using the overwatch and more. More combat options will be available to each of your gangsters as they learn new abilities. In the Lieutenant level of difficulty, you’ll probably win most of your battles against the thugs, and other families’ guarded rackets. Eliminating a family boss in their safehouse might be slightly more complicated, but you should be able to beat them if you have 6 to 8 gangsters in your group with a good arsenal. However, it will be challenging if you decide to play on the underboss or boss difficulty levels.

The third phase is the management side where you can hire gangsters, use the diplomacy tab and see your rackets and how much there are making per week. There is also a mission tab where missions will appear as you go along. I strongly recommend completing a few missions and you’ll be rewarded with money and notoriety points which you’ll need in order to unlock new and better gangsters for hiring. You’ll also need notoriety points to set up your organisation with an advisor and an underboss. 

As your empire starts to grow, you’ll undoubtedly be at war with other families. I’d try to be at war with one at a time and concentrate on taking over all their rackets as fast as possible. What you need to beware of is retaliation; they will attack you either by themselves or with one or more other families. So make sure to upgrade your buildings’ security, but you’ll need money for that. More guards and you’ll have more chances to retain your rackets. You’ll also need money to upgrade each of these rackets’ ambience, advertise them by word of mouth as well as upgrading the deflect (appearance of being something other than what it is) to avoid raids. With the breweries and safehouses, you can upgrade the booze quality, storage and production.

Anyone who has worn out their copies of every XCOM game, as I have, knows there is not a wealth of new games in the genre. I appreciate what the Romeros are trying to bring to the table with Empire of Sin, but for now the game falls short in core aspects of execution. Hopefully, this will someday be a game that I feel gives me my money's worth. 2/5 stars.

Last month I bought and completed Hard West, a game I greatly enjoyed for its combat mechanics and level design. A few days after my interest in HW ran its course, I saw Empire of Sin in the store. It seemed to promise a lot of the things I loved about games like XCOM and HW, but with an innovative scalable strategy layer and an emergent narrative based on 1920's Prohibition Chicago. Being a Paradox game I somewhat expected it to come out half-baked with a ton of issues, but this is a rare effort at an XCOM competitor and Paradox are generally good about supporting games for a long time.

I hope that continued support is the case here, because the tactical gameplay in this game gets old very quickly. At the outset the game shows a ton of promise, in 3 attempts at starting a campaign so far my favorite part each time was the solo missions at the beginning. The "boss" character of your gang really lives up to this name, and taking down 5 or 8 enemy thugs in just a few turns is a great introduction to the combat system. After taking over a few rackets, earning a few made henchmen, then assaulting a rival gang's safehouse to overpower their leader and seize their territory, you can really immerse in the game's promise of being a criminal overlord with an empire.

What follows is where the game becomes bogged down in itself. Running multiple gang wars when you own a sprawling empire is an exercise in tedium. Your racket guards are hopelessly inept at lower levels, and when a racket is raided by the enemy you're ripped away from your boss character and are stuck controlling "60 hp woman with lead pipe" or "55 hp man with short-barreled shotgun", typically against an equally inept force of random enemy thugs. Then, when your guards lose you immediately get to repeat the experience inside your racket.

The tedious gang wars also highlight the repetitiveness of the different buildings. Each building can be "small", "medium" or "large" and the interiors of each racket type do not vary much. So, in a short span the game goes from being a very enjoyable stint as the baddest guy in town, to fighting through a hopeless slog with no-name characters in the same environments over, and over, and over. This is not an enjoyable experience for a turn-based shooter.

The strategy layer provides more scale than depth, which would certainly be forgivable if the combat sequence was more engaging. Owning 30+ rackets in a neighborhood, each with 20+ upgrade levels, with 10 neighborhoods as default, quickly becomes a chore when the ultimate outcome is that each time you make slightly more profit or the guard battles become slightly less tedious due to upgrades. 

Immediate improvements to the tactical layer that I would suggest are:
-Make the player character and their made men essential to the core game mechanic: turn-based tactics. It is not as enjoyable to fight battles where they are not involved, and these should be automated 100% of the time. It might be workable to give the player a way for responding to such events, such as posting made men at the neighborhood safehouse and having them immediately respond to help the guards against any raids in that neighborhood.
-Make combat involvement mostly line-of-sight based rather than area based. Having a random group of thugs in an alley around the block or a faraway policeman become mandatory elements of combat because they were within X tiles of the ambush is never an enjoyable surprise.
-The controls sequence for fighting battles with a controller is not intuitive to work through, and sometimes limits player options compared to KB+M. In my opinion, XCOM: Chimera Squad is the gold standard of intuitive controller support in the tactical layer and I think it would be a good thing if this game had a similar controls sequence.
-Speaking of XCOM:CS, their breach system was a fantastic innovation in the genre. I think that a similar mechanic for raids in Empire of Sin would provide a sorely-needed breath of fresh air to the short roster of interior combat environments. Breaching from outside in would also help solve the disconnect between the outdoor and indoor environments in this game, which at present feel like different worlds (see: no-name guard battle progression).

Empire of Sin has established itself as the leader of the pack when it comes to organized crime-based strategic gaming at the moment, but there’s still plenty of room left for improvement. For the Paradox fans out there who see their name attached to this, it’s nowhere near a grand strategy, so you can go ahead and let go of those expectations before you enter the gate. It is, however, a fairly well done criminal business sim with a solid tactical combat side packed full of plenty of RPG elements and an atmosphere of the era that few games can top. This review is based on the state of the game as it was during the launch:

Empire of Sin tries to do a lot of things, and while it manages to do some of the aspects of it relatively successfully, it sadly stumbles when it comes to majority of them.

The fantasy of being a gangster is pretty successful one, where you get to choose from wide cast of characters as the head of your family. These boss units tend to be stupidly powerful, for better or worse, being able to take down most enemy units with ease or even alone if given enough time.

The soundtrack of the game is pretty good and fits the themes the game is going for very well.

Graphically, the game is mediocre. Some models look fine, but things like cutscenes can look a bit cheap. I didn't personally mind these that much, but they can stand out quite a bit.

As many people have reported, the game is sadly riddled with bugs, from minor ones such as animation glitches or characters taking 5 seconds to initiate an attack or end turn, to major ones such as constant crashes (I've experienced so far 4 during my 6  hours of playing the game) and other irregularities. The list is sadly too big to count, with seemingly every player encountering their own unique ones based on reviews that I've seen. The game does feel like early access a lot more than game that should be launched with deluxe editions and whatnot (also don't buy the golden weapons pack, it makes the game way too easy, and it's already very easy even on the higher difficulties).

The game is also pretty badly balanced overall and some gameplay mechanics feel either poorly executed/planned or just overall unfinished. Combat encounters start with units seeking cover, but you can't decide it, so they can just stand out in the open. Attacks on enemy bosses can be over in few turns or you can get killed without a proper chance to fight back at all. You can be right next to enemy, but as they are next to a wall, your chance to hit them is lowered by 40%. The list again is sadly too long to be written here, but just count on me, it's quite extensive.

The shallowness of the gameplay and the quest system are the final nails in this game's coffin. I do, however, hope/think that the game will be salvaged, but it's going to need a lot more than bug fixes to earn favorable reviews I imagine. Right now, I can barely imagine myself finishing a single playthrough and I have zero motivation to play the game again. For a game that is clearly made with multiple playthroughs in mind... well, that's saying something. 

So don't buy this game yet, but wait for fixes and updates. The game has so many good ideas going for it, but I can't help but to feel like it's maybe one of those soups with too many cooks. More narrowed focus on singular aspects rather than trying to tackle so many things at once would have probably worked better for a game like this. I still hope to see this be a success story later on, but right now I'd avoid it like shoes made out of cement.

- The different parts of the city are pretty far, and travelling between those is not very straightforward. Running rampant since Bosses are OP and the other bosses aren't around to fight.

The conversational system of Civilization but without having any meaningful decision.

These are the following reasons why I am glad that CD key websites exist:

1. The economy is an absolute shambles. 

You only have 3 options of making money:

- Own a business (brothel, casino or speakeasy) and then supply those businesses from your breweries, and increase customers using hotels. There is no mediation. What happened to protection racketeering for local businesses? Money laundering through legal fronts? What happened to gambling dens? Prize fighting? Numbers games? Counterfeiting Press? The difference between Breweries and Liquor for the time period? Doing independent trade from external groups? Empowering minor groups to become major groups to get some vassals or even integrate them into your own gang?
