81854399.review:
I wanted to like this game — I really do — because I actually enjoy these turn-based tactical combat games such as XCOM, Fire Emblem, Wastelands, Gears Tactics, Age of Wonders:Planetfall, Phantom Doctrine, Phoenix Point, Mutant Year Zero: Road to Eden, Battletech, Shadowrun series, and of course Final Fantasy Tactics. 

When I saw this game had that combat style AND it let you run a criminal empire that expanded into a living world in a deeper strategy game sense I was excited for that experience. Then I played the game. 

TLDR: Overall my initial reactions are the game is a really shallow experience.
 
That empire management stuff and the economic systems in play are very shallow in particular. After combat you get to take over the buildings. There is little to no difference between the rackets though. When it asks you what you want it to be there is really only three choices. They each make you money, some more than others, they each have an upkeep mechanic you gotta pay, and that's about it. No difference between the three (Speakeasy / Brothel / Casino) though and you can literally spam only one type and be just fine. 

The Breweries are needed or you won't make any money in your Speakeasies. They need you to supply them with alcohol. You can trade excess booze for cash too which is a broken exploit right now because you can disguise it as Whiskey. 

From there you just spend the cash you make on more speakeasies (or upgrades) to make more money until you need more booze. And do the cycle again and again. It always seems to be the same repeat. Not a lot of depth here. 

It think the game's economy would be way more interesting if there was some kind of supply and demand system that is more robust than the preferred booze type that changes each month. Where if say your neighborhood of Chicago was oversaturated with speakeasies then it would become harder to attract customers and booze would have to be sold cheaper. Which means lower profits if you invest in only speakeasies. It would incentivize players to then try to monopolize a particular business in that neighborhood and cut out the competition maybe choosing brothels, casinos, or something else instead of a speakeasy. 

Hotels bring in more customers and double your synergies. If you have say three of a kind of the same racket type they give you like a 10% bonus. I think you can only have one Hotel per neighborhood though. 

The other thing you spend your cash on is hiring henchmen. Though the combat is so dull you really don't need a full 10/10.

The game revolves around the combat and that isn't even all that special. The maps are tiny first of all. The combat is over in a matter of turns even when you're trying to take down a bosses safehouse. This is because the OP boss abilities. The other major flaw to the combat is the lack of environmental interactions. They are virtually non-existent. You would think people would be climbing over benches or vehicles to scramble to get out of the way of a gun fight that just broke out. And the player could be using the vehicles or other things in the environment as explosions or using explosives to destroy cover. It's very basic half cover, full cover, and flanking the enemy. Half the time there is no penalty to just running up next to them to get 100% and the kill but leaving yourself outside of cover. The AI is not very good. 

And when you kill a boss the game doesn't even replace the dead with procedural generated one, or even lesser factions. One would expect some lesser criminal would at least try to take up and assume the mantle and seize control in that power vacuum. 

I honestly think the combat is a step back from previous games in this genre. Instead of improving upon games like XCOM or Gears Tactics even Empire of Sin just does the bare minimum. The characters ( think xcom soldiers) do have classes and each class has different abilities you can choose in the skill trees but there is a lot of overlapping abilities even amongst the classes. 
   
They badly need an auto resolve function for the combat because you'll get sucked into repetitive fights back to back to back when you're trying to manage your empire and forced to fight as your guards. I don't mind this every now and then I would even choose to fight the fight but you have no choice. It's every time you gotta go in and fight the fight.

Also they really need a better way to compare weapons. Since your constantly upgrading and changing it's not a fun experience.  The UI functions and information is actually really shoddy. For being a strategy game and a Paradox published game you would expect more. Half the time I was scrolling over symbols and couldn't find a way to tell what it did or explain it and where i was getting it from. Not even a name to let me know what it was. Did I mention there is no manual even?

I haven't even encountered any of the game breaking bugs reportedly out there either. 

The game is just a hot mess but there's hope that they'll fix it in that it just released and by and large it's been negatively received by the community. They got to do something. 

What do I like about the game? I love the setting and the theme. The time period of prohibition-era mobster ran Chicago has always been a fun time to play around in. The violence and intrigue of backstabbing and killing former partners in crime. The musical score is pretty good too.  It has a lot of style going for it and you can tell it was a labor of love for at least some of the devs. The game has it's potential but that's where my praise for this game ends. The theme alone doesn't even come close to outweighing the issues I have with it's design or mechanics. Which leads me to leave this game with a negative review rather than a positive one.

This is a game I followed with much anticipation for months on end. I love this time period, I love this kind of game. I have waited for a game like this for a very long time, but it is a niche game for a niche audience. I know there was a lot of expectations for this to be better than it is, to be strategically deep and have deep management options. I will say that what is there may not be incredibly deep, but it's not overwhelming either. I really feel like this is something that will improve with time, the foundation is good and it's something that the developers and community can really build on like our own empire together. 

I would like to see some things in the future though that aren't currently there such as the ability to send goons out to attack rackets. The AI can do this, why can't I? It's a little less gang feeling and more of a "Kill Squad" with how it is right now. I should be able to send out a group of goons maybe led by a gangster sort of like how The Godfather 2 was. I would also like to see what's known as "Fronts", there's only the specific rackets and they aren't really hidden the way I thought they would be like a backroom sort of thing. The last thing I can really think of is proper extortion rackets. I mean yes, the AI minor factions and even the other bosses will pay you protection money but there's just something about having a business that is legit paying money to you as a boss and it feels more like a territory thing. A little more business expansion than just the few rackets that we have would really help fill this game out.

At the end of the day though, this game is solid and I feel like it will expand with good feedback. We as a community have to show the developers why we love this time period, why we love this kind of game. I know that I love it already despite being a little less than even I expected. I know that I can sink a lot of time into this and will continue to watch it over time with great interest. When mod support comes out, I think the community will help out as well. I can't recommend this game for everyone, but I can to those who love this era, love strategy and management, or any combination of these few things. Empire of Sin is something that I think a lot of people like me have wanted for a long time and with a little guidance it will become more of the game that we've dreamed of. Till then, I'll be happy running the streets of Chicago, yet stay hungry for more.

81796561.review:
To be blunt, the game is boring. Like a lot of other people have said it has potential, but as it is, it's at best a bit boring and at worst a slog to get through.

Some of the problems are a question of UI, which could be easily fixed. For example, the city is divided into neighbourhoods, and you have multiple businesses in each neighbourhood. There is a screen where you can see all of your businesses in that neighbour, but if you want to make changes to them you have to go into a different screen for the individual business and lose sight of the state of the neighbourhood over all.

The combat is kind of fun, sometimes, but a lot of battles are so one-sided it's just annoying that you have to do them at all.

There aren't enough gangsters to hire. I don't care about their depth or complexity. There just need to be more, and you need to be able to hire more, and the AI needs to hire more. Even in the late game you'll have a squad of 10, and the AI *might* have as many as 2. You'll only see them if you attack their HQ though. Also you can have one of them as a lieutenant to govern your businesses in a neighbourhood, but they only apply a small bonus, and there are 6 neighbourhoods and you can only hire 10. So using them as anything other than a hit squad is a waste of time.

The battles when the enemy attacks you are just boring. You either win in an absolute grind, because your basic guards are rubbish, but so are the units they attack with, or you just accept losing and then retake it two seconds later with your squad.

Some effort has gone into the streetscape, but it's wasted because you never really look at it. You move your units around mostly from the zoomed out view.

The controls in the city view are awful. There's no button to zoom on a character, so if you've stopped controlling one you need to go look for him across the whole city to get control again. Similarly, when it comes to looking for your enemies' stronghold, you need to check each individual neighbourhood, because there's no button to just show where they are.

There's only one way to win the game. You take over all the other factions' territory, but you can do that just by attacking their HQ and then you get all of their businesses. I played around for a bit, then decided to go do that to everyone one at a time and I took the whole city in about 2 hours.

I was hoping for a game like Gangsters: Organized Crime, but this is not it. This isn't even as well put together as Company of Crime, and costs twice as much. Give it a miss.

81796416.review:
[h2]Booze, money, and guns[/h2]

[h2][b]Introduction[/b][/h2]
🔹[b]Empire of Sin[/b] (EoS) is a character-driven strategy management game, developed by Romero Games and published by Paradox Interactive. The sea of negative reviews could easily repel anyone trying to get into the game. Is it genuinely terrible or is it just lacking enough polish that turns into a vapid experience?

🔹Welcome to 1920 Chicago. You assume control of one of several crime bosses inspired by real-life mobsters in the US prohibition era. Your one and only goal as the head of the family is to expand your empire by taking out the competition and be the last boss to reign over the city.

[h3]Rating: Decent[/h3]
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2282929825]Click here for the complete Rating Chart[/url]
[table]
[tr]
	[th][h3]Hit[/h3][/th]
	[th][h3]Miss[/h3][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]✔️Text-based dilemmas that have small consequences over time
✔️Enticing atmosphere and setting about the US prohibition era
✔️Wide array of bosses to choose from, each having unique abilities and traits
✔️Combat proves to be incredibly fun when AI is working as intended
✔️Overview of the city map is distinctively colored, making it easy to find what you're looking for
✔️Visuals and soundtrack truly embrace the roaring '20s[/td]
	[td]❌Tutorial barely scratches the surface, leaving many of the more advanced mechanics under explained
❌Diplomacy is almost useless, given how often AI turns against you 
❌Difficulty is lackluster and unchallenging unless playing on the highest settings
❌Sometimes, combat can be a drag due to wooden AI
❌AI characters are mostly clones of each other
❌Recycled assets throughout the city but not enough to ruin the immersion
❌voice acting fails to capture the gravity of the sit-downs accompanied by dull and repeated animations[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

🔹I have included my [b]full elaboration of the cons[/b] in an external document due to the character limit. You can find it [url=https://docs.google.com/document/d/16GlSb5FzGsuGzeuN_9qZ5vX9um_1V8Be8VRvoHdi9MM/edit?usp=sharing]here.[/url]

[h2][b]Gangster melodrama[/b][/h2]
Upon arriving in the city, you're nothing but a low-life thug in Chicago despite having fame attached to your name. You must gain a solid foothold by taking over rackets and retain it by going all out on illicit businesses and shady deals, all while Feds are breathing down your neck and mob families waiting for a misstep.

You'll encounter numerous scripted missions as well as randomly triggered ones while trying to acquire new rackets by either paying a hefty amount of cash up-front or swiping them from someone else. The missions consist of straightforward errands for your family or text-based dilemmas. The choices typically fall into the villainous or benevolent categories, so they're not that nuanced but sometimes the roleplaying options do offer a bit more flexibility.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2312207225
[h2][b]Live large and carry a big gun[/b][/h2]
The gameplay is divided into three parts: RPG, combat, and empire management. To begin your crime life, you must choose one of the fourteen bosses, each having their own particular set of traits and skills with a touch of small backstories to diversify them further. The same goes for the huge pool of brazen gangsters available to hire on-demand. Gangsters work in one of the five professions: Con artists, doctors, enforcers, hired guns, and demolitionists each with a somewhat unique talent tree to take advantage of during combat.

How you handle the rivals and your own crew very much shapes how you rise as a boss. Meanwhile, you gain notoriety by taking over rackets, completing missions, and taking out enemies. Higher notoriety allows you to hire bigger-shot gangsters. As nifty as it sounds, AI fails to behave accordingly and ends up breaking out wars on you for no reason.

But to be fair, the turn-based combat proves to be incredibly fun when AI is working as intended. Planning out your moves and making the most of your mobsters' abilities are crucial to turn the tides of the war in your favor, even though it feels lackluster, unchallenging, and sometimes can be a drag no matter what difficulty settings are chosen.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2312215047
During Chicago's prohibition era, alcohol is liquid gold. Continuous injection of booze into your businesses must be maintained so breweries are the key to keep them in a functional state. While your workers are busy supplying your empire with the hooch, you have several options to amp your earnings higher. Establishing speakeasies, casinos, and brothels will make sure you would have a steady income, while hotels increase the number of customers in each neighborhood.

Moreover, to assure having a long-lasting criminal empire, different aspects of your rackets must be improved. Upgrading defense and deflect allows you to repel gang attacks and police raids. Ambiance spruces up the place that directly impacts the racket's draw. Lastly, word of mouth attracts more customers to your place. The upgrades as well as your empire's statistics are presented through text-laden menus that mostly feel like a burden to read through.

[h2][b]The roaring twenties[/b][/h2]
[u][b]Visual[/b][/u]
I went in for EoS completely blindly and I was surprised by how pleasing the aesthetics are, given it runs on Unity engine. Different corners of the city are sometimes recycled assets, yet they are amazingly detailed. Characters are of high quality and have sharp textures that help to make these gangsters (but not all of them) more believable. UI is given nuance with an eye-catchy black and gold theme if you don't mind all the texts that clutter it.

[u][b]Sounds[/b][/u]
The jazz-mixed soundtrack is the exact tune and tempo one would expect from such a crime setting. It's coupled with a rather modernistic piano and trumpet pieces that truly embraces the roaring '20s style.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2312224928
[h3]Technical[/h3]
🔹[b][u]Specs[/u][/b]🔹
[u]GTX1050 2GB - Athlon II X4 645 - 8GB DDR3 RAM[/u]
The game runs with all settings maxed out, using about 70% of VRAM at 1680x1050 60 FPS.

🔹[b][u]Bugs & Issues[/u][/b]🔹
Two updates have already rolled out fixing some of the minor and major bugs. I've been informed the balance issues are addressed and under view. 
[list]
    [*]During combat inside buildings, allies spawn in random places despite entering from the door
    [*]On occasions, conquering rackets early on might void the later missions tied to those specific rackets
    [*]Under certain conditions, the AI can be quite aggressive and engage the player repeatedly in a war.
    [*]Characters occasionally get bugged and skate across the floor, stalling the combat and animations for a short time

[/list]

[h2][b]The bottom line[/b][/h2]
🔹I have honestly enjoyed EoS on its core gameplay level as I don't look for a challenging experience in my first playthroughs. Bringing [b]XCOM[/b]'s turn-based gameplay to the underbelly of a criminal empire is a unique and somewhat underappreciated setting that we should see more of it. However, its technical ricketiness gets in the way of many things it attempts to do well.

🔹There's no campaign, only a sandbox mode where the "kill or be killed" rule applies. Although, the number of present bosses and neighborhoods can dramatically affect each session length up to a dozen hours. I can see myself getting 100+ hours out of EoS in the near future but regrettably, given all the game design imperfections, it's not everyone's cup of tea.
I can only recommend buying it at half the price or wait until it's polished out.

Hi,

Played 49 hours and finished 2 times in Easy with Goldie & Donovan, 3rd ongoing with Jackson on Medium difficulty.
Seems like some bugs are linked to which boss you choosse, as I canceled my 3rd play with Ragen cause way too buggy. So if you have problems, try another boss to see how it goes.
No problems on Donovan, Goldie or Jackson.

Some quick tips :
-Dont forget to set a new talent to learn on your boss first round of starting !
-Go recon all the maps and find the Bandits standing in street, not in building. They are guarding a treasure chest most of the time. You can have extremely good rewards in chests. You have 3 one-time bonus : +50.000 dollars, hire anybody without notoriety requirements, become instantly friendly with cops.
And then you can find weapons or items going to Purple quality (nearly the best).
Some boss can solo straight the treasure chests, most are guarded by less than 3 bandits, otherwise 2 henchmen is enough.
-Dont forget to switch your breweries level of alcohol produced, dont stay in the low level.
-Dont forget to switch the alcohol liked by the neighborhood in one of the panel (dont remember the name) to get a green cross instead of a red one.
-You can level your boss/team on the bandits stronghold.
-I feel it is more rewarding and mostly free of consequences to attack the minor clans buildings to get more income than to go straight against other boss buildings.
-Because when you feel confident, you can go Hideout hunting vs the other clans and hopefully defeat the enemy boss and grab all their buildings in one swoop.
-When you are in War with another boss, zoom out to the different maps to find their goon squads walking around and intercept them and kill them before they attack one of your building.
Choosing how you engage the fight is a real boon, ambush from different angle is fun.

For now I didnt really get into the diplomacy option, except to trade some alcohol with the minor clans.

I recommand the game, you can play nicely with some boss and do like 80% of the gameplay with them, no bugs.
And it should be more stable with the other boss someday after hotfixing.

I paid £41.99 for the Deluxe Edition of the game and so far I have 31hrs on the clock, so the question is, do I recommend the game? I have to say YES.

That said the game for me currently sits at a sold 6/10, which does not seem to be high after spending £41.99, but there is enough to take away from this game that is good. Having read some of the negative reviews, I can't say that I totally agree with their points of view, although there are one or two things that do ring true.

The good bits.
1: The game feels authentic to the period, the environment feels authentic to the period, so yea well done to the devs in bringing the 1920s to life. Graphics are good and sound too.

2: The story starts at the beginning of the notorious lives of the characters such as Al Capone. Some have argued that its boring all the running around and does not feel authentic. well what people fail to realise is that in the 1920s (just watch Boardwalk Empire) people like Al Capone were nobodies, it took years for them to build up their reputations and power. People like Capone did a lot of the grunt work until such time he could get people to do the work for him.

3: The game at the moment provide an average challenge and there is some reasonable character development.


The bad bits:
1: The game is fun, but very repetitive. There does not seem to be a right or wrong way to play the game and as such if you bypass some of the set missions, all you seem to do is go from A to B, raid a building, and then develop the establishment. And that's it. That's £41.99 right there.

2: There are annoying quirks in the game that really serve no purpose, like when gangsters in your team fall out over who they fall in love with. Its a distraction that's not required, but I can probably get into it more if the Devs developed it a bit better such as being able to create multiple teams and you have to choose carefully who to put in that group.

3: I have yet to come across any game killing bugs but I have found some annoying mechanics that need to be fixed, such as anomolies of enemy henchmen stuck in walls, or were their movement matrix fails so they can't exit a room. With the first issue I left the area and re-entered, the problem seemed to fix itself. The second issue fixed itself but I had to wait a few mins, I went to make myself a brew, when I came back it was fixed.

Although I have ticked yes to recommending the game, in its current state, its not good value for money. I would suggest waiting till it goes on sale and getting it, hopefully by that point we might see a DLC and some mechanics improvements.

management and diplomacy doesnt really add anything or play a big part, you can just speedrun combat with safehouses and win.

Ending statement:

This is hard cause i actually enjoy this game, I could easily boot it up for 1-2 hours and speedrun a few districts and challenge myself and see how early i can win, but that isnt what the game was designed to be, the game is sold with the image of giving you deep management and having to stay ontop of police and also dealing with other mafia bosses and empires trying to stay alive in chicagos underworld, and if thats the goal then its failed, this is a turn based (x-com) skinned with mafia characters set in a 1920 prohibition chicago scenario game, thats how ive played it, just gone from combat over and over again, cause nothing else really matters to win or progress.

Empire of Sin is a mess.  The common refrain seems to be it's just buggy and while it's certainly incredibly buggy that's not the extend of the game's issues.

On the topic of bugs, in the fourteen or so hours I've played I've had multiple Quest triggers fail, animations routinely fail to load (with a handful of game ending freezes) and a dead man requesting we end our War.  I'm running the game on all of the preset settings.  This is literally the first run any playtester should have ran.  Take a glance at the official bug forums ( httpsforum.paradoxplaza.comforumforumsempire-of-sin-bug-reports.1086 ) and just read the thread titles as it's is a comedy goldmine.

Now to the meat of the game; There are two major modes of gameplay.  The first and the one you'll be spending most of your time in is the combat.  There's UI issues abound and for the sake of brevity here's a quick list;

Firing a Primary weapon ends your turn, firing a Secondary does not.  To swap to a Secondary requires you to, well, click the swap command and confirm.  Simple enough, yeah  There are literally two options for your secondary Fire and Reload (a Secondary Shotgun will have a Cone AoE option as well).  An average turn when you don't have to move is  SWAP Weapon  FIRE Weapon  SWAP Weapon  FIRE Weapon.  Just add the two options to the basic bar!  Fire (Primary) and Fire (Secondary) along with Reload (Primary) and (Secondary).

The UI will list multiple instances of the same options - My Maria has three end turns.  They all do the same thing.  This is likely a bug, but it's pretty easy to figure out why it happens.  One of her Perks is to take a move after an attack.  This added it's own End Turn option.  As did another ability.

Now we're actually playin', baby!  Well great, here's the thing about Weapon Balance.  There isn't any.  In a comical flaw, Burst Weapons roll to hit for each bullet.  This means that anyone that can wield a [Sub]Machine Gun should target the hardest to hit enemies.  45% to Hit  I'll take those odds on my five rounds every turn.  Oh, while we're here attacks are only modeled against the characters selected.  So if you hit and kill an enemy with your first bullet in a Burst fire the guy directly behind will not take any damage at all.  If you miss a guy in the middle of a crowd you will *never* hit anything.  Jagged Alliance and X Com had this in the early/Mid Nineties.

Enemy AI is dreadful.  They charge.  Everyone.  Every time. Seriously.  This was supposed to be brief.  Jesus.

The Available Gang members page is static game to game.  Getting the higher tier Gangsters means playing with the lower ones.  Every single game.  But don't fret!  The bonuses you get for using Characters means that you'll likely want extra bullets in your Burst fire conga line over a slight boost in higher stats anyways.

The Second part of the tactical portion of the game is moving and controlling or defending the streets.  This is made laughable by a couple of systems.  Chiefly that your crew can instantly teleport to any location you have revealed on the map by right clicking on a building and selecting Travel Here.  The game gives you a notice of where the enemy is planning to attack so you can teleport to a location, massacre the assailant and repeat, with virtually zero time taken off the in game clock.

Now you're given a map and on that map are various buildings, and most of them allow for you or rival gangs to control them as Rackets which feeds into the Economic side of the game (oh we'll get there).  You may attack and take over enemy turf.  Of which there is one map of each type per size of location.  The first, second and twentieth assault on a Mid Size Speakeasy will be the same location.  Any every time in between.

Thankfully, there's a helpful catch pre programmed into the game for you. Successfully attacking an enemy Safehouse knocks that Rival out of the game... and grants you their entire empire.  There is no reason to ever attack an enemy Racket.  If you need quick cash, take out an identical derelict building or three.  It's way easier and it's way more beneficial for you to just declare War and take everything all at once against a Rival by teleporting directly to their front door and waging the shortest War ever.

The game tries to discourage your time and space bending gang by having you not heal between battles.  But there's no different damage states.  So if you heal in mid battle you'll come out flawlessly.

...Which leads to pushing the Control key to instigate a sneak attack in your area, and in this case on nothing and then pressing Tab until you get your doctor and using their skill to heal.  And ending combat, clearing their cooldown, and doing it again.  Near instantaneously. 

On to the Economics!

Want infinity money  Sell garbage alcohol to the smaller, Minor Gangs disguised as Whiskey.  For some reason, they have infinite money and will always accept your deal.

Which is better than engaging with the actual systems present.  Your income randomly rises and falls, based on Customers Winning Big at your Casinos.  But you never get a notification that your House just took a loss.  It seems like it tallies up all of this at the start of a week instead of being organic and shifting through the day.

Become a gun runner.  Sell everything you don't need. It's simply less miserable than trying to figure out how all your Rackets collide in it's huge mess.  It's almost indecipherable at the start of the game when you've got three buildings.  It's the spreadsheet from Hell by the time you're out of your starting Neighbourhood.

Diplomacy!

Hahahahahahahaha oh dear God I'm done.

81687162.review:
An ambitious game that doesn't excel at anything it tries.

For what it’s worth, Empire of Sin really embraces the Roaring ‘20s style, showing off Chicago streets that are initially fun to navigate and a roaring soundtrack of jazz mixed with some more modern pieces. The writing and weird cast of characters, both fictional and fictionalized alike, have a lot of charm. There's even really delightfully over-the-top voice acting for nearly every character, littered with standout performances like gangster boss Frankie Donovan, aged Western sharpshooter Grover Monks, or the hammy duo performance of a gambling bookie and a button man. (They're in love.) The charm wore off a lot quicker than I’d have liked, though.
Fights quickly become rote due to mindlessly repetitive maps and poor, buggy combat AI.
The challenge here is to run a complex illegal empire while also balancing the chaotic personalities of criminals both in your gang and outside it. Like many of Empire of Sin’s ideas, it's a brilliant concept: You have to keep a lot of violent people with poor impulse control both happy and alive in turn-based tactical RPG combat in the vein of XCOM. You direct your chosen gang boss around the city, doing missions with bits of flavorful dialogue to enjoy and controlling a crew of hired guns in battles against other gangsters. Those might be fights with rival gangs, groups of independent thugs, and very occasionally even the police or the Bureau of Prohibition's agents. Interacting with the characters of the '20s is where Empire of Sin shines, but the fights you're doing to earn those stories quickly become rote due to mindlessly repetitive maps and poor, buggy combat AI.

The tactical battles are built on good bones: Gangsters have a to-hit stat, hit points, and you find weapons with varied stats. Basic combat numbers are pretty granular, with health in the 50-150 range, so a thug might take two to four pistol shots to go down. It's just enough randomness to make the weapon stats and upgraded rarities really matter. There's also a half-or-full-cover system you'll recognize from every tactics game since 2012, well implemented here, with angle of attack and distance mattering depending on what weapon you're using: a shotgun does best from within two tiles, a rifle from seven or more, and a submachine gun is happiest somewhere in the middle. There are balance issues, like one-hit kills from sniper rifles and surprise damage from unavoidable dynamite attacks, but there's fun at the tactical core.

It's the maps that really kill the combat. They're pretty, at least, thanks to locations like dim speakeasy interiors and luxurious gambling houses, but they’re chokepointed, poorly laid out, and offer very little tactical variety. Most fights end up revolving around a single corner or doorway as you set up a kill zone and watch enemies swarm into it – and many of the maps only have one or two of those chokepoints to fight over. The terrain is static as well: there’s no destruction, and no interesting ways for characters to get around. It's an honest crime that you can't vault over the bar counters into cover like in every gangster movie ever.
The dominance of some strategies over others undermines what should otherwise be a wide-open sandbox game.
All of that goes on as you build up your network of illegal breweries, casinos, speakeasies, and brothels to get rich on the management side. To do that you have to  stay out of the police force's sight and try to one-up rival bosses in both business and territory control. The way it’s all executed, though, makes it little more than surface-level fun with no balance or depth: Alcohol out, money in, but you never make enough money to really feel like Scarface because upgrades and gang members are absurdly expensive. Of course, that rarely matters because the dominance of some strategies over others undermines what should otherwise be a wide-open sandbox game.

You can, in theory, play many ways, such as diplomatically catering to allies and placating opponents as you build up your empire, but those are never the best idea. Why would you wait for your cash reserves to build – and I mean literally wait, since the management layer is real-time and has a single speed – in order to wage a full-scale gang war when you can just directly attack enemies and take everything they have in one fight?

Part of the issue with the strategy layer is that while the city is nice to look at, getting your characters to where you need them to be becomes a major chore. Your characters control in real time on the streets, and you order them around like units in an RTS until combat starts. They're slow to react, slow to move, and frustratingly bad at pathfinding, requiring constant hand-holding. This makes attacking enemies building-by-building frustrating and boring: You move from place to place and attack, fight the same three or four guards on the same three or four maps, then take over the building.
While the city is nice to look at, getting your characters where they need to be becomes a major chore.
While you’re doing this, enemy crews are attacking your rackets, subjecting you to an endless stream of boring defensive matchups between your hopelessly outgunned guards and big swarms of enemies. You, meanwhile, can really only afford to field one effective combat team. I have no idea where the other side gets their large bands of roving, well-armed, disposable muscle, but you're limited to a few precious and expensive gangsters.

Fights might be more fun if you could afford more gangsters and more security upgrades for your rackets, but you really can't. The economics are so poorly balanced that amassing any large amount of cash is really only possible once you’ve already built a huge empire of rackets, and even then you burn through it buying just a handful of incremental upgrades. Think spending $3,000 dollars for… +7% on a building's income of $500. Woohoo, only 85 in-game weeks before I break even! That's just a mere... hour and a half of my life. (One game speed, remember?)

The interface, by the way, is truly terrible for managing a huge empire. You can own dozens of businesses but there's no single screen to manage them all at once. Instead, you get to sort through them neighborhood-by-neighborhood on screens that also have all your competitors' businesses. To upgrade them, you must open a new screen for each business, one at a time. I eventually resorted to simply building new businesses, ignoring all upgrades, and hoping that quantity had a quality all its own. Thankfully, that worked.
Just drive over to the other boss' house and shoot them in the face.
So how do you win a gang war, then? How do you get rich? Simple: You just drive over to the other boss' house and shoot them in the face. See, your units can teleport around the city by "driving" instantly to any discovered place. So you just declare war, teleport to the front door of the enemy's safehouse, and assault it, bypassing any defense their armies of soldiers would have provided. Defeating the enemy boss in their HQ means you instantly take over all their buildings: Congratulations, your empire has now doubled in size and you got a really overpowered bit of unique gear to boot.

It's a shame, because the glimmers of a great game are here. Take your crew: The network of thugs-for-hire in your black book all have morale and loyalty scores, their own specific background traits, personalities, and relationships to the other gangsters. They get mad or worried when their lover is injured, and they won't shoot a friend on the other side of a fight. They can gain new relationships in play, become alcoholics, or get syphilis. Gangsters can die permanently, too, which is fun to avoid once someone becomes integral to your crew. Push them far enough and they'll leave your gang. But even with all of that promise, Empire of Sin’s many faults have pushed me too far.

TL;DR > This game feels vastly unfinished, you don't feel like a gangster, not engaging, little strategy, little challenge, there's nothing that makes me want to play it again. if you want a true mafia themed game, get the old ones or wait for another one.

Because Paradox was involved I was expecting the game to have its DNA, the developers not only failed miserably at incorporating PDX philosophy in game development but also in delivering a game, at its current state feels unfinished.

- The Relism Factor & Immersion
Forget about realism, bullets can ricochet from foe to foe, poison gas can turn enemies into allies, half of the crew you can recruit seem to be taken out of fantasy books, you have Indiana Jones with a moustache, big fat baby man, the bearded hobo, a girl who came from Westworld, the Butcher, that gypsy fortune teller from the machine, and so on.. The game look tacky and EXTREMELY OUT OF THE GANGSTER VIBE. 
There is no campaign, only a sandbox mode filled with missions that do no more than guide you through the plot of your main character, that could be interesting if not for the limited amount of options and outcomes you have, so there is no narrative. 
Half of your guards are women, because gender equality apparently was a thing back then. Costumers in your rackets all look the same, if they are wearing coats they look like lab scientists, so you can picture your speakeasy full of lab coats and a couple of she-hulk guards. By the way, making a character's style badass and punkish doesn't make it look like a gangster.

- Graphics & Sound 
Some characters were well made, the models are fine, there is a certain level of attention to detail but nothing special, the animations in the other hand are a lackluster specially in dialogues where it contributes to the taky vibe. The battles are very uninteresting visually speaking, the blood looks gooey, the scenarios are limited and the animation makes the characters lifeless, its just a bunch of human bodies moving around.
The voice acting I'd consider fair, nothing special here either. 
The soundtrack is decent if not relaxing. 
I'm not a demanding person when it comes to graphic or sound quality so this doesn't bother me.

- The UI & Gameplay
Really bad. If you want to change an equipment you better remember the stats of the current equipment so you can compare to the new equipment.
The information panels does a poor job at demonstrating information, you need to dig in to find what you are looking for, you could see a lot more with much less.
It's unfortunate that for every attack you have to directly control the battle, a simulation (total war style) would be a nice quality of life. 
Many bugs.
There is a limited amount of options in dialogue, more so in outcomes, rendering a narrow window of opportunities, so there is not much to engage in here. 
The good thing is the keybindings, you can pretty much play this game almost entirely without using a mouse. if in battle hovering the mouse to a space will show the % of accuracy for hitting targets, that's neat. 

Final Words
This game is a bit childish in some senses, from the design of the characters to the playability. A try-hard attempt, there is nothing to make you feel like in the 1920's. I don't know how to express it better, THERE IS NO GANGSTER VIBE, that's it. If you want to play a real game with a mafia theme, try old games or wait for the next one.

I think the main take away from the game is that depending how you feel it is either not sure what it wants to be or it was a gamble that did not entirely pay off.

The main systems that I view in this are X-Com (Remake) combat, Gangsters (late 90's game) concept, along with some very light business management, and quest and RPG elements.  On it's surface, those are all very good ideas and if they're put together, I would absolutely adore this game because it's what I want.  However, it suffers from 'just missed the mark' on every one of the things it sought to bring to the table and it leaves one wanting.

X-Com style combat?  Unpolished and inconsistent with damage, character ability, mechanic function, item availability and trait development.  I'm not sure how the X-Com turn based firefight which has turned into the new standard could be so glitchy and difficult to implement for the studio.

Light business management?  It's not as deep as the number of screens likes to make it seem.  It lacks any refinement and the depth of interaction that the Gangsters Game had with it's industries and businesses.  All money is the same, any structure is the same, the five illicit businesses are the same no matter where they are.  You can stick five casinos next to each other and they function the same with the same income, ditto with brothels, or speakeasies.  Fifteen illegal bars on the same block have zero impact on how much they earn.  Changes are incremental at best, and have no real effect.  There's no real techniques to hide anything other than investing in 'deflections' nothing as refined as Gangsters of hiding brothels in legit hotels, or speakeasies inside of resturants...just click the box and you're good.

Quest and RPG Elements.  The game wants you to think that you're an RPG, that you have dialogue choices with other gangsters, make deals, have an effect on them.  Wants you to think that they might actually act differently depending on how much they like you and your behavior towards them affects the relationship you have.  Nope, someone can be polite and professional in a meeting, or act really friendly, and have MASSIVE debuffs towards you that makes war inevitable.  Your character can only click on tribute and hope that will help.

The game wants to be far more than it is, far, far more than it is.  And while it's not a horrible game, it just does not really nail anything so well that you overlook the exceptionally mediocre other aspects of the game that miss their mark.  

It might be worth getting if you haven't played the other games that this one is borrowing from, but if you're here, you already have.  It will get better when there's a modding community, and probably after the standard Paradox DLC business plan kicks in, until then, give it a pass.

I feel badly because I really want to enjoy this game and I think the devs actually put a lot of time and effort into trying to achieve something amazing. Sadly, it falls short, but not so short that I think it cannot be addressed by patches.

First, I want to say I'm thrilled that this game exists. The subject matter, the setting, and the game systems are all aspects I tend to gravitate towards. There aren't many games that scratch this itch for me. This is why I hope the devs continue to look at the feedback, digest it, and work towards a more polished, bug-free experience. I don't want to see DLC released until the core gameplay is solid. Do that and you're dead to me.

What I like most:
 -> The turn-based XCOM combat system combined with a large assortment of gangsters to hire who all exhibit varying traits (and can gain new traits). It has issues and I get into that later, but this system was a good choice for this game.

 ->  There are decisions that impact your experience, sometimes right down to you losing hired gangsters because of conflicts/failed missions. Decisions, or lack of, being impactful is good (imho).

 -> The UI is pretty good. The character sheets look good, and all of the panels are setup nicely so one can find the info they need. I don't think there is any info that is nested deep down in any panel. Everything feels fast and snappy on my end, right down to the load times.

 -> The equipment seems to matter, and the loot system appears just right for this kind of game. Gangster traits are very nice and give you some nice decisions to make.

 -> The overhead map system is pretty slick and makes navigation fairly easy. It could use some refinement when using the mouse wheel to zoom out, but the M key works best to immediately get to the overhead mode.

 -> I like that rackets aren't just carbon copies of each other. They have pros/cons, different costs, etc. I just wish there were more types of rackets that I could pick from.

Things that need help and distract from the experience:
 -> Combat animations are not polished (blips, poor transitions between states).

 -> In a few instances I've lost rackets without any notice. They're just gone. I wasn't given an opportunity to protect or reclaim the racket. This feels like a major bug to me and it needs to be addressed. Sinking a lot of cash into a racket for it to vanish without an opportunity to save it is poor design if this isn't a bug.

 -> When combat is initiated, your gangsters can be situated next to thugs. This isn't very practical or good for giving the player more agency. When this happens, it means cover is meaningless and your gang could start with a large disadvantage. In XCOM, and other games, the maps are large enough so the player can set the table as necessary - to better prep for the combat to come. Even though the maps are small, this can be fixed if thugs and gangsters don't commingle at the start - specifically for non-story combat missions. Another way to solve this is to have a setup phase happen before combat, allowing the player to position their gangsters within a defined area of the map.

 -> Income/Upkeep doesn't feel balanced. I'm always short on cash. When one of my rackets mysteriously vanishes, yeah, that really sucks for my wallet. I can't purchase items, hire new gangsters, without the worry of how I will pay for something if another racket goes belly-up.

 -> I've had missions fail for no reason. If there are missions that are timed, or have conditions, these have to be more transparent to the player.

 -> Many of the combat maps are too small and uninteresting. I'd like to see something other than a derelict building populated with thugs. Maybe it gets more interesting later on? Either way, I want to see maps that are cosmetically different, perhaps even with destructible items/cover.

 -> Some of the gangster skills seem overpowered.

 -> The AI is downright horrible. They make horrible decisions and cheapen the combat experience. Sometimes the AI is fixated on one gangster. Sometimes the AI circles around the map. Sometimes they move next to a gangster but shoot at someone else further away. It's total chaos sometimes. You could place your gangsters behind cover and use overwatch to dispatch most of the AI (albeit making a boring combat session).

 -> Melee seems hugely under-powered unless I'm missing something. If a thug rolls towards me with hopes of using his fists, he's never going to make it unless I roll poorly in my shots or there are multiple thugs trying to melee me. Perhaps gangsters should have massive penalties to long guns if a thug is in melee range? Or perhaps make some melee thugs that are heavily armored?  I think all of this needs to be changed, right down to how many choke points are on map and/or reducing the arc of overwatch.

If you read this far I give you crazy mad gold stars.

Overall, 7 / 10. Most annoying bugs were resolved in the first few days and the game runs just fine now. Its XCOM-style turn-based combat, fighting for control of illegal businesses, getting into wars with other factions, and ultimately trying to come out on top. 

You run a crew of 'real' gangsters, up to ten, and from 5 'classes', which can be further customized with a tree of talents to choose from, and further with their gear, weapons, etc. You manage various seedy businesses, but there's not much depth there. Missions drive some storylines, but aside from the first few that give you alot of cash to initially get started in the gameworld, they don't do much. The real fun is in taking over existing businesses from other factions, and growing your own empire. Hired Gangsters are powerful, and expensive, so your main goal is to have enough businesses to support both hiring, keeping, and outfitting your gangsters, so that you can stand up to the other major factions.

Atmosphere is high quality, theres fun diversity in gangsters including their dress and special abilities, and the combat is challenging at higher difficulties. I'd play on the standard starting difficulty if you're not familiar with XCOM style games, and a higher difficulty if you are. The navigation of the world and in combat is a bit tricky to learn, but once you do you'll appreciate why they did it that way - becomes very easy.

Big Pros:
* Combat is fun
* Leveling up and diversifying your crew's abilities and equipment has depth and value
* Visuals and navigation are clear, clean, and useful, once you get used to them
* Obvious room for growth in mechanics through future content/DLCs from great initial framework

Big Cons:
* AI on lower settings atleast, is weak, both in combat and their management of their businesses
* Police don't seem to do anything but slightly annoy you, no matter how many of them you shoot
* Current Balance around Safehouses is broken and allows too much progress too quickly
* Too much of the game is not skippable, which is especially annoying at the start of a game talking to all of the factions and getting raided - an autoresolve would be nice

If development is continued on this game, the Con's can disappear quickly, and the Pro's will expand, so I recommend this game in its current state.

81621167.review:
TLDR: Empire of Sin, while technically playable, is riddled with so many mistakes, design/production shortcuts, and bugs that it badly undermines the experience of the game. Bugs that affect vital missions, characters, and faction interactions sometimes block gameplay altogether.

[b] The Good: [/b]
Supporting a relatively independent, creative developer. Romero certainly has not lacked for screwups, but at least he does it in pursuit of a particular vision.
The scope of the game is interesting, though realized with wildly mixed results.
The art design is solid and generally fits the theme well. The effects are satisfying (sound + visual of the tommy guns for example). The only major negative here is that the generic NPCs need more variety in their appearances (even small variations in faces would go a long way).


[b] The Bad: [/b]
As others have noted, the game may have a grand vision but it falls well short in execution. For example: the heavily advertised system for organic interactions between the gangsters is severely underwhelming. It might be on par with Shadow of Mordor’s nemesis system (released in 2014).
The quality of the writing and the voice acting is all over the place. Some of it is quite good, but most of it falls somewhere between passable and sloppy. The writer(s) clearly struggled to decide between classic noir and cartoons. There is no gradual change (in both the writing and the voice acting) between somber reflection on cutthroat violence and slapstick shenanigans. It sometimes feels like someone spliced The Untouchables with Who Framed Roger Rabbit but made no effort to integrate the two. 

[b] The Ugly: [/b]
What a horribly buggy mess. Random bugs of varying severity are littered throughout the entire game. Some are minor, like voiceover and subtitles not matching. Some are major, like generic NPCs changing their entire appearance after they are killed; voice actor and character model getting completely mismatched; occasionally parts of the interface refuse to close. The lethal bugs are scattered mainly across various quests when, for example, certain essential characters disappear, or are impossible to interact with. Usually I am not overly concerned with mentions of bugs or performance issues in reviews. Oftentimes these get fixed, assuming the game is not abandonware. The user experience can vary widely depending on hardware, and so on. However, sometimes a game’s programming is so shoddy it makes it nearly or entirely unplayable no matter the user. Unfortunately, that is exactly what happened here.

Bugs are not the only fatal flaw either. The diplomacy system between factions is such a mess it is hard to know where to begin. The worst of it revolves around the transactions. The system for valuing items (weapons, equipment, consumables) is imbalanced and easy to exploit. Specifically, the “black market” (an interface panel for buying items from a non-faction store) will only buy items from you at a tiny fraction of the value. However, the other main factions will buy/trade for any item based purely on the dollar value. You can effectively run your entire empire by selling junk to the other factions, draining them of all their funds, and investing the money into your properties. You can even throw enough junk items together to trade for the faction-unique, extremely valuable weapons (the ones you otherwise can only get by killing the boss of each respective faction).

I earnestly hope Romero Games and Paradox work out the bugs and revise various mechanics. I would love to be able to honestly recommend this game. They have quite a lot of work ahead of them however, and I cannot imagine Empire of Sin being worth buying for some time.

Honest Opinion. 

I purchased this game hoping it would be somewhat similar to the 1998 classic 'Gangsters Organized Crime', which I still play. I am a big fan of Paradox also, so I always pay attention to games released by Paradox and have done so for over ten years. My first pre-game play impression was that of a somewhat in depth game with interesting mechanics however the biggest turn off was the turn based combat, which I was never a fan of. If anything, at one point i decided I wasn't going to buy this game due to the turn based mechanics but my love of gangsters organised crime, the whole genre in general and my faith that paradox always releases games with great play ability and depth, made me purchase this game. To help give an honest and structured opinion I will address each of the main points below. 

1) Turn based combat

To me surprise, I enjoyed the turn based combat and felt it went fluently. Some of those up close attacks that would keep missing at points is a little annoying. If the target is right in front of you, but behind a table, you should at least be hitting them with some damage each time. My only complaint is that it gets very repetitive , especially when your constantly having turn based battles. Also, your basic goons seem to have the worse aim ever, so when you go through the motions of using your 2-3 guards against an attack of 4-5, you will miss A LOT and it feels like the outcome is a forgone conclusion. The enemy can be right in front of you, and in a lot of cases you won't even nip them with the spray of a sawn off... surly it can be tweeked to work better, but it makes grunt battles very tedious. 

This has opened my mind to other turn based combat games so that's also a plus!

2) Strategy & management 

I hate to admit it, but the strategy and management aspect is lacking greatly. Sure, you find yourself planning on building more breweries if needed, choosing which one to upgrade so you can produce swill / whiskey or the needed beverage. Maybe your drawing too much heat, or your expecting a war and beef up security at interfaces so you can fight off attacks. But you will find yourself running through the motions making very basic decisions when it comes to management. 

Other than trading goods, diplomacy is shallow, feels pointless, and the game ends up turning into a free for all of repeating  turn based battles. After taking 2-3 rackets the enemy wants to give up and there's no personality behind the AI, all other factions simply send squads to your rackets. It would have been much better if each gang had their own methods or preferences when going to war. It seems the other real difference is the enemies colour and location. 

The types of rackets you can have are extremely limited also. A speakeasy, a brewery, a casino and a brothel....... why not take a leaf from Omerta (the only leaf anyone should take from that god awful game) and add other options such as protection rackets, food joints, have celebrity areas, politicians and so on, it would have added so much more to the game in terms of strategy, rpg elements, missions and so on.

Another thing, it is also very easy to attack an enemy safe house, kill the leader and take all of their rackets. I was a half hour into one game and asked the North side mob to wack the head of the Genna family. It was promptly done and the genna empire suddenly become the northside mob. This is a bad idea... There should be a mechanic whereby the rackets in that part of the city get taken over, but the gang remains in a weakened state in the hands of the underboss. 

I have also played on easy and normal, it seems each gang expands very slowly and their income is always quite low. The AI needs to be a bit more aggressive and active. I am going to try it on hard next, but there was not change between easy and normal so I'm doubtful it will make much of a difference. I found I was easily able to accumalate thousands, build up my gang and just attack a bunch of rackets if the other gangs became annoying. That's all the other gangs are in this game, irritating....

As your mob gets larger, the game feels like its about turning the map into whatever color your faction is. There is very little you can do to feel like a rich, powerful mob boss. NO flashy cars, flashy homes you can customize, no clothing for characters, no personality or image you can give to your gang to make them stand out... it just feels pointless...it doesn't even feel like there is any challenge... you just rinse and repeat 1) Ransack vacant properties 2) trade the weapons for cash 3) build up rackets 4) Do it again and again. 5) If a gang attacks, then attack some of their rackets forcing them to surrender. Again and again and again..... 

Yes, there are missions, but they fall far far short of what is needed. If your looking for a minimum of CK3 immersion then forget about it. 

Why would I still recommend this game you may wonder?

1) I love the genre
2) There's a complete lack of any game like this (other than gangsters organised crime).
3) It looks good and is somewhat enjoyable. 
4) While its hugely lacking in areas, its still okay... 
5) I had a good time playing this. 

But more than anything, the more i played this game and the more i enjoyed it, the greater i felt it could have been so much better. I believe tweeks can fix some of the above (and a few bugs i came across), and I hope some DLC's come out which add more possibilities , abilities, depth, options and mission branches. As well as the chance to reflect your progress within the game in a cool manner which will motivate you. 

That's my honest opinion....

81608435.review:
As much as I find this game fun it is limited by some broken mechanics. I really like the graphics, I like that there are so many characters with a fairly distinctive feel to them, and I like the whole gangster theme. But the things that I like don't alter the fact that, whilst it can be enjoyable Empire of Sin is ultimately severely limited.

Take the strategic/business layer as a prime example; on the one hand it is well thought out with several ways to improve your economy and your individual business security. But it all means nothing in a game where you don't really need much money meaning that you can almost ignore the whole layer for most of the game. Likewise the Diplomacy and Faction elements - why bother with them at all when you can simply storm everyone's main safehouse, kill the Boss, and take over all their businesses?

I played for 10 hours on the next to hardest (underboss) difficulty just steamrollering over everyone and plucking their juicy equipment from their cold dead hands. It didn't matter which boss I started with despite the fact that they have well designed traits and special abilities due to the fact that it is entirely possible to kill everyone with only basic attacks and tactics. The enemy AI rarely makes use of cover or flanking tactics and I just felt that it didnt represent any kind of serious challenge.

Even though the framework for an excellent game is there the game as it stands is broken on so many different levels. Police presence is fairly low even when things start to heat up and when the police get caught up in a crossfire between other factions it is easy to see how utterly broken the AI is as they do nothing but retreat without contributing anything significant - so all the elements of keeping a low profile and bribing the cops are a complete waste of time.

Changing to the hardest difficulty only means that no matter how many guards you add to improve the security of your buildings enemy guards will have more hp and be better equipped. So the phases where you have to defend solely with guards may as well be skipped (and it is frustrating that battles within your properties CANNOT be skipped when you have very little chance of winning despite that the outside battles CAN). But, hey, none of it matters anyway because you get everything you lose back just by attacking and winning the boss fight. This essentially means that you only really need to play a single fight to defeat each faction in the game. This being the case I just can't recommend this game to the majority of players for long term play.

All the quest chains and character interrelationships are fun and sometimes interesting and it''s great that seemingly minor companion quests can gain you a massive edge by linking you to a far superior character. But, again, all this is a hollow enjoyment when the core gameplay is fundamentally flawed. There's no doubt that it's still fun - to a point. It's just a real shame that all the groundwork for something with real depth is rendered shallow by a few core issues. Will I play and enjoy it more? Sure but that doesn't mean I can honestly recommend a game that presents only an illusion of strategic depth, an illusion that is quickly dispelled by just a couple of serious problems resulting in only a "casual" game.

Of course there's still plenty of time for the developers to address these problems...

Short version: It’s a great game concept and some good elements but poorly executed and feels like it should be Early Access at best due to the decisions the game developers have taken. It has a poor ill planned UI, bugs and lacks a lot of content you would expect of a game of this price.

I would buy this game but only when on sale (50%+ or around £20-£15) and maybe not then tbh.

Long version:
The game is set in 1920’s prohibition Chicago and as you probably seen this but, you play a gangster trying to take over the city against AI rivals. The visual style is appealing and there is some good voice acting and music. The combat system is the turn-based X-COM style that’s became popular on the Unreal engine. Generally speaking, these aspects of the game that are very appealing to me and something I could spending a lot of time playing and enjoying. However, there are several aspects of the game limited my enjoyment-

Firstly bugs and crashes, they are there and in abundance unfortunately. As of yet there has been no patch (that I know of) to address these nor communication from the developer or the publisher to manage everyone’s expectations on when these will be addressed which is a shame. 

Secondly the game content. I’ve played this game for just over 13 hours and whilst I’m planning on playing more of the game (just so I can say I've ‘completed’ it), I don’t expect my experiences to change substantially. The side missions are pointless, lack flavour and are very, very repetitive of the game’s main mechanics i.e. go there, talk to this guy, fight this guy (and maybe his friends), go there, talk to this guy, fight this guy etc etc. 

The empire building exists of attacking ‘thugs’ (squatters in unused buildings) or attack other ganged own properties and that’s it. Which gets very repetitive very quickly. There is no need to identify potential buildings for illegal use or understand the illegal market needs for a brewery, brothel or casino in the neighbourhood. Your empire actions are limited to setting up these establishments in the neighbourhoods also. There is no need option to create ‘protection’ rackets take over legal business to launder money, no dealing in anything else but drink. Basically, it's setting up buildings and that’s it. 

Empire Management is also virtually none existent. You can upgrade most of the buildings in certain generic areas (like security, type of or amount of drink etc). There’s nothing else. For example, moving your guards from establishment A to B to meet potential threats, creating scouting parties or protection parties looking for enemies or police in a neighbourhood doesn’t exist.

You can create a gang for you to run around the map with. Whilst each of these characters have their own back story, of which some are interesting and linked to some quests they can seriously break immersion. You and the AI’s have a set amount of characters to pick from but it’s a small pool and when they die, they are gone. Also, they have restrictions to hire which limits the pool even further. So, whilst you want to create a group of 3 or 4 Italians or Irish (or whatever culture you want to play as), you can’t. With my Italian ‘themed’ play I was forced to run around with an elderly Irish lady, a fat half clothed (southern American I think), an Indian Hindu, an Irish drunk and a Chinese lady. How can you pretend to be Ali Capone and the Italian mob taking over Chicago when your pool of side kicks has been chosen by the Race Equality Commission? Why couldn’t they just implement a procedurally generated pool of side kicks based on your background (if you’re the Irish mob, your enforcers will mostly likely be Irish!) with a couple ‘oddballs’ thrown in?

The RPG element is very, very limited. Yes, you can equip your guys with weapons and items, and choose from skills to give the illusion of customisation. But in reality, this is very bare bones also. When you get an epic item it stays, you can’t customise weapons, nor your crews apperances, nor specialise down a certain path. RPG elements impact heavily on immersion and mechanics somewhat too. For example, you can get a Rosary that increases your initiative by 10, your health by 15% and increases defence skills by 5. Whereas weapons mods like increasing drum size for your submachine gun or sights, gun cleaning equipment, outfits (i.e police, smart, worker outfits) are missing. 

The games economy is also very skewed. For example, to run 2 hotels cost circa $10 per week but to buy a baseball bat (?!) for one of your crew to use in melee costs $6,725. I don’t understand what decisions developers took to come up with this economic scale but it’s ridiculous and feels like they were developed in silos.

This game had lots of potential. I was hoping for ‘X-COM’ combat focused meets ‘Gangsters: Organized Crime’ Empire Management game but I’m sorely disappointed by both aspects.

[b] TLDR: [/b] Buggy mess at times, but very fun and worth the buy. I'm sure the bugs will be patched out at some point as the majority of the ones I have encountered are just graphical bugs that don't effect gameplay. The other two are annoyances. Being that sometimes enemies will spawn outside of the combat map and be unaccessable and untargetable. Requiring you to leave the combat zone and reenter to fight again. The second is that sometimes you will not be able to move without looking at your characters on the world map outside of combat.

Empire of Sin is a strategy game in which you take control of a mob boss and build your empire while competing with other bosses and some minor factions. The turn based combat is much like any XCOM game as well as Paradox's Age of Wonders: Planetfall. The goal of the game is simple. Be the last boss standing. You can achieve this through guile or sheer brute force. Gang up on a faction with your allies and divvy up the loot. Or just rush their safehouse with your top gangsters. Each boss has their own unique storyline to do on the side while taking over Chicago. Along with various side missions thrown in along the way. There are five gangster classes not including your respective boss. They are Enforcer, Hired Gun, Demolitionist, Doctor, and Conman. Each serves their own purpose and has their own skill tree. All of them are pretty self explanatory. Enforcers are your front-line pretty much. They can suppress, take reduced damage, counter melee strikes, and usually have a higher health pool. Hired guns are one of the two damage dealers. They pretty much just sling [b] A LOT [/b] of lead. Demolitionists bring the [b] BOOM!!! [/b] They have access to skills that allow them to throw explosives that can put out some massive hurt if the enemy dares to clump up. Every mob needs a Doctor on the take of course. They heal your team passively out of combat, in combat they provide heals as well as reviving downed gang members. This is quite important as your gang members have a chance to be injured if they take too much damage in combat which will require them to heal for a set amount of days making them unavailable for use. Last but not least our sneaky friends the Conmen. They can pickpocket enemies to take their things and once they receive their final talent they turn into the chain killing sniper one might see in XCOM if specced right and given the right gear.

However, while the game might be fun it is not without its downsides. I have encountered several bugs during my time playing this game since release. The two major bugs causing the game to just not work the way it is intended to. The first one that causes me the most irritation personally is movement bugging out when using the overhead map or just when walking around Chicago. First off I love this game, the premise is incredibly fun to play in this 1920's sandbox of crime and violence. I also think my review is more positive because I did not follow the development of this game as I have begun to do in general.

As much as I am enjoying this game it is not without its flaws.

The combat is at times disappointing and cumbersome. There is very little squad-based strategy. When you are grinding money against the thugs that occupy abandoned buildings often times you just set your troops behind a cover and shoot the enemies as they come towards you. As you get the late game this becomes more and more of the case. In my first game when I was eliminating other gangs I would just sit at the entrance of their rackets and just wait for everyone to come to me. A nice fix would be to add mini objectives or something like a toggleable timer before the police show up.

I have played two games one on the middle difficulty and once on the hardest difficulty. The hardest is quite hard, but unless you want a cutthroat start you would play the easier difficulties. When you hit the end game there seems to be very little that the enemies do to adapt to your strong parties. The AI still sends out little parties to attack the weakest points without sending large groups to try and attack your powerful bars or breweries. My first game felt like cat and mouse chasing away other factions as they could attack a dozen of my rackets at once while I could maybe split up my experienced crew to attack 2 rackets at a time. 

There are a number of minor bugs that never got in the way of my gameplay once, but the exploits are quite overpowering. One thing you can do is buy all the other gangs cheap beer and then sell it to other factions that have infinite money as higher tier alcohol. There is no penalty for lying about the type of drink, but you get massive profits in return. This needs to be nerfed because you can get insane amounts of money for a few clicks. Another exploit has to do with arming your gangsters with other faction's unique and powerful weapons. I think it is intended for you to pick up super powerful guns when you kill other gang bosses, but you can buy their OP rifle for 2 baseball bats and some gangster pocket change. In my first game, I went and bought all the special guns and then just blasted through everything in my way. As I said before, if you like to roleplay, the time period, and strategy games this will be a great pick. If you are worried about the issues that I have brought up I would recommend playing a smaller map with more bosses on a higher difficulty and not doing any of the exploits. This is my second review for this game. The first was fueled by disappointment and too much Mountain Dew (if that's even possible), and I don't think I was being entirely fair. I still say you should wait for major tweaking and bug fixes, but there are good game bones here. The stories are well written and even in my frustration with the game I want to see how the different storylines play out. The bosses feel unique from each other when you interact with them, and there are some sweet historical items to pick up. With that being said, here are the suggestions I'm taking to the forums:

The most important thing: they need to open up the workshop. Mods will go a long way to smoothing the rough edges and calming the community while Romero Games gets updates ready. 

Faster combat and attack alerts: any fight with more than a handful of AIs is... well, it's boring. You spend a lot of time watching your enemies, their enemies, their enemies' allies, random thugs, and someone's grandma move around the environment (usually into the line of fire, which is helpful). It's okay in smaller groups but becomes messy in a crowded area. Looking out for hit squads and marks on your buildings is helpful, but a way to speed combat up altogether would be better. 

Balance the economy: the Spiffing Brit *sips tea in salute* put up an exploit video about how to tank the economy, and if you do that the game becomes much easier. If you play it straight, it's still unbalanced but in a different way. Sometimes it feels like you're getting $1 a week and saving up for a console while the neighbor got their kid two consoles and all the latest games; other times your character apparently has a money tree in the backyard. I can say that finishing my boss' storyline gave me a huge chunk of money and more rackets, so I should have finished it much earlier than I did. I imagine other bosses would be the same. 

Space out the content more: the game tries to get you going in so many directions at once that it becomes frustrating. It's hard to get immersed in one storyline when you have three others and a sudden gang war pulling at your attention too. The UI could also be more intuitive... there's lots of information there, but usually not what you need where you want it. 

I gave up on this game briefly (hence the first review) but now I'm actually looking forward to updates in the hope that the gameplay will match the writing and environments. I'm not sold on DLC by any stretch and as I said above I recommend waiting, but keep this on your watch list, it may deliver yet.
