81557246.review:
Ok so as a quick break down. I love XCOM and I happen to Mafia theme stuff, lastly I see this game is made with Paradox who made Stellaris and that game is awesome, So I just HAD to get this game. I've not played much as of writing this review, I might edit it further down the line as I learn more and more details both good and bad but already this game is proving to be very fun and addictive, albeit it with several flaws.

Quick Warning for those who may be looking for a Mafia/XCOM mix. Don't go into this thinking its EXACTLY like XCOM in combat execution at face value. Yes it has cover system, aim system and etc, but its more akin to XCOM Chimera Squad.  You don't have a turn, then an enemy turn, its character initiative based. So do not be fooled into thinking otherwise! I don't think its a bad thing, I like Chimera Squad also, but I do understand not everyone is into it.

With that out of the way let's break this down as best as I am able.

This game is a Mafia empire building, pseudo open world with a top down view, running in real time sporting a combat system heavily based off of XCOM. In my experience I'd say its slightly more akin to the original syndicate games or Satelitte Reign where you manage a small group that grows in power, getting more loot and tools to help you go up against growing enemies.

The world is pretty vast, broken up into neighbourhoods where characters, NPCs and mobsters will all do their own thing. Its entirely possible to run into a complete badass in the middle of the street just walking along. or in a bar and such. Its actually kinda cool the game keeps tabs on people roaming about freely while you run about running your businesses. Its like a much weaker variant of the recent Watch Dogs Legion where you find anyone of interest and keep tabs on them, sure you won't be able to play as them but still its an impressive little attention to detail that you can kinda do that to some degree in this game.

You'll be mostly spending your time running from spot to spot, doing either A. Raiding a racket to take it over/or plunder it. Or B. Trying to get to a point on the map to do a mission before something or someone gets in your way. At first its pretty easy going but as the game gets on its gonna happen a lot more frequently to the point you might be running yourself ragged trying to deal with every little message/attack that comes on screen. Honestly, between combat and generally upgrading your businesses this is what you'll be doing the majority of your time. If your not keen on the idea of being constantly bothered you may end up disliking this gameplay loop, so you'll need to learn to love the combat and theme if your to endure for the long haul, so its understandable if your not into it.

Honestly, The theme and setting of this game is the best part about it. The music, the environment, the voice acting and brief moments of cutscenes via the sitdowns are really well done, if not limited. It really does get the feel down lovingly. There is also batches of humour scattered about which also fit in oddly enough, but I'm not gonna mention them so you can learn it for yourself.

Combat as mentioned earlier is almost a complete carbon copy of XCOM Chimera Squad. However unlike Chimera Squad, it lacks the polish. Not that it doesn't look good when it works, it even has some sweet animations when you execute someone with various characters, the guns sound good you use the tile system as normal......but then bugs will set in. They don't ruin the game completely, but they do get annoying. I've already had a soft lock occur twice because I tried to melee someone after switching a weapon forcing reloads. Animation can bug out, sometimes characters glitch out their actions and remain in a perfectly sitting position as they suddenly float to where you say and then proceed to fire a shotgun from their knees. As said they mostly doing ruin the game, even make it funny but they do however get irritating that they usually last until you close and reopen the game.

Diplomacy is....well its as you can probably imagine in most games involving it. Either the AI is dumb, or you can exploit it to high hell and not nesscesarily in that order. This game has both types. but it genuinely offers an interesting system, entering business partnerships or managing to worm your way slowly into the police's good books.

Running the empire itself is basic enough to understand though you might be overwhelmed at a glance, but once you've ran with it for a bit you'll know what's what. I won't go into details because I'm dure you'll agree you'll end up running into what I said earlier, you'll be running to a point to upgrade or expand, then something of interest or not, will pop up, or you'll be attacked, or approached, or something. Anything that prevents a clean cut approach usually to getting needed business details over with. At first its not an issue, but as the game goes on it will get hectic.

Loot is random for the most part, which you get by raiding businesses to customize your mobsters, you won't be able to change their clothes and such though sadly. The mobsters themselves do have near little missions which can genuinely be a lot of fun to go through which also helps you get connected to them both in gameplay terms and as a person. my funniest encounter is a mobster of mine falling in love with a woman, wanting help with a date and asking me to ensure they don't drink, getting progressively more funny as they keep trying to get one before it turns out its actually a hit on them more or less. Its little things like that which do flesh out the NPCs which as said before they do their own thing helping the game's life so to speak.

I only wanted to write a little bit, but there really is a lot to bring up the more I think about it so you know what to expect.  The game is fun, addictive, set well but suffers from bugs, lack of polish and mostly easy AI, with spikes on occasion.

It might sound like I'm bashing on the game, but these are nothing a bit of fixing can't sort. I'm being honest so any curious purchasers from the time of this aren't surprised if they decide to step into this game. The game has issues, but I'm still enjoying it which is why I can recommend it but ONLY if your willing to look past the issues, if not, you might wanna wait for a sale or something.

This game is a real flop on release, which looks like it might be becoming a trend for Paradox games. I don't have the faith that this game will be fixed like they're currently doing with Imperator though.

There are two resources to manage in Empire of Sin. Money and alcohol. You start out with barely any income in either of these and are expected to expand. In the tutorial you are immediately pushed into the red by hiring 2 underlings, each of which has a minimum wage of $300. You don't need them this early. Paying to upgrade your rackets doesn't pay off nearly as quickly as going around fighting thugs and establishing new ones and you don't need hirelings to do this.

Diplomacy is handled quite poorly. Every time you meet a new gang they will threaten you, and you have the option to threaten, negotiate with, or attack them. I don't write reviews often but i felt it was needed here. The feedback in store although correct i feel is very angry. I wanted to get in some gameplay before posting a review and i think its best summarised by saying its A Swing and a Miss. For now at least.

Don't get me wrong, I really want to enjoy this game (And I Do) But there are a lot of issues that need addressing which judging by the feedback on the store a lot of people have noticed and are angry about. If this was a £20 game then fair enough but paying a lot of money and getting hyped for this has been a bit disappointing seeing the state it is in at launch.  

That being said, I fully support the developers and wish them the best of luck in resolving these issues, but there is alot for a £70 game on release.

So to begin:

The combat is X-com style i guess you could say but lacking the Umph. Ai isnt the brightest and charges straight at you, even if they have good cover. The animations feel clunky at times and if the animation freezes the game pauses for a significant amount of time whilst it catches up with itself (Sometimes resulting in a crash) Also seen issues where the character models stop walking or running, even taking cover correctly. They just start hovering and sliding their way across the screen, when this happens there is a significant wait time for actions to finish before the game carries on. (Like 20 seconds, its really bad xD)

Executions are cool, however most the time I kill someone who's downed they stand back up before falling back down to their death.  

If you get into combat and two other factions are fighting, you have to wait for them to resolve their conflict before you can carry on your game. (Very annoying when its 3 thugs and a few police whilst you're just sat there skipping turns waiting to raid the last boss's safehouse.)

The gangsters you can hire are the same every playthrough, what i mean by this is that because there is a notierety structure for unlocking and recruitment, you get stuck with the same 5 gangster each time you start. Not neccassarily a bad thing, but maybe give an option to randomise it as it becomes very repetitive. Speaking of; the maps are heavily recycled usually featuring the bloodstains of past battles outside of the fighting area but still there even though its your first time there. 

Missions are chained and presented to you so fast that you never have time to finish them. Strips away any player autonomy in completing missions. (Reminds me of the Settlement mission questline in fallout 4)

Diplomacy feels like a lost cause as its always better to just kill off the competition and take their rackets. As soon as you conquer their safehouse, all their empire becomes yours. Basically streamlines players to attack safehouse before rackets. If there is a way to finish a game with an alliance i haven't found it yet. 

Upgrading of rackets is incredibly costly and time consuming. Usually more cost effective to conquer others or buy new ones.  Also the hotel synergy could do with a bit of elaboration. 

There no customisation either with regard to your gangsters. You can edit their loadout but thats about it. Theres like 5 archetypes Enforcer, Con Artist, Doctor, Hired gun, Demolitionist. No real stand out qualities in any of them besides the obvious (Doctor can heal, Bomb guy has bombs.) But no visual customisation at all.

Even though the city management is good and intuitive, it feels shallow and easily mastered.

A few pros:

Visually stunning,
Unique storyline for each boss,
There is alot to do. (Like any paradox game really)
The music is great (There is one song with a very noticable loop though, please fix this, it breaks me everytime. xD)

I want to reiterate however that this game has a lot of potential and its not awful its just buggy as s**t and needs some TLC. 

I feel alot of us may have boarded the hype train and its sadly crashed.
We wanted an Xcom Omerta but we got a BTEC jagged alliance in a fedora. 

So, maybe wait for a sale to buy the game or buy it and enjoy but expect it to be unpolished and buggy. I don't think its worth £50 to £70 price tag in current state. 

Its not the end however, if they fix the issues (and I've seen that their working on patches already) then i'm all for the amount I paid. But please fix the issues. 

We got faith in you Romero. 
Don't let us down.

I pre-ordered this game, hoping it'd be the breath of fresh air this genre needs. That it is not.
Empire of Sin is a shallow, buggy, and unchallenging experience that could've been great.

Build a hotel in each neighbourhood for extra cash, though it's hardly necessary.

It's domino effect, the angrier the other factions get, the quicker you expand, which will anger more factions, which will make you expand quicker and so on.

Then there's the bugs. As I experimented with the game, I saw many of them, from people getting randomly hurt to their animations breaking to parts of the UI disappearing, but I also encountered two game breaking bugs: the classic infinite loading screen and one where one of the enemies was slingshotted of the map before combat began, making it impossible for me to kill him and for combat to end. 81531410.review:
This is currently a very easy and casual game without a lot of depth. The main game layer is set up more like a RTS game with a bunch of AI empires on the map all expanding and fighting each other at the same time in real time, with some basic diplomacy options. You capture a limited set of basic building types that all boil down to extra money per week, and each building has a few tiered upgrades that make them better at making you money or better at defending themselves. To take over another empire on the map all you have to do is attack their safehouse and fight their boss, which is an easy battle, then all of their buildings are transferred to you. That is pretty much the extent of that gameplay layer. There is no research or special empire upgrades, it's just buildings that make money so you can get more buildings to make money, money that doesn't really matter because you can just take your starting 3 characters and wipe out everyone on the map right off the bat.

There are other layers to the game though. The combat layer is pretty simplistic and needs a lot of balancing, but has room to maybe be more interesting in the future as there's a random gear system and some RPG-like progression. It's turn based xcom style with cover and overwatch, with a number of special abilities than can be quite powerful for your units to learn. You can just go around picking fights all you want for loot and money rewards, with a shop to buy a random selection of equipment.

Another layer is the quest system, each leader and each NPC you hire has a number of personal quests that pop up, in addition to a large number of generic quests that take place around the map, many of these have multiple ways to finish them based on your character's stats or your own preference. For example you can pay a guy off to leave you alone or just kill him, if you kill him you might in the future have to deal with his buddies trying to get revenge, things like that. This is probably the most interesting game layer currently, but other than interesting stories and some pieces of loot, you don't get much out of it other than more money.

Graphics are passable, but not amazing. Animations are very janky at times with arms bending in ways they should never bend as a unit moves around, or bullets firing sideways out of a gun as the person firing it stops the animation too early. The UI could use some work, for example the overworld command menu is a pie menu but doesn't trigger based on what is highlighted only what is clicked, so you see an option highlighted and you click thinking you selected that option, but you didn't because you click just outside the menu and closed it instead.

If you treat this game as a serious strategy or management game, you will probably be a bit disappointed. If you play it as more of a sandboxy RPG there's a decent offering. Like don't try to win right away, just run around doing quests, killing enemies, and hiring new crew, it's an alright time waster. If you are trying to win, you could probably finish a "match" in like an hour or two, you basically just have 20 or so easy fights to win, which would be pretty boring obviously.

I don't usually give scores, but this game is kind of borderline so I want to explain my thumbs up. I would personally rate this game at like a 60-65%, given the $40 price and current state of things. There are better uses for your money, but it's not an awful game. If you really enjoy the mobster theme (I think it's cool but I'm not a true "fan") this might be more like a 70-80% for you. And like I said, if you want a serious strategy or management game, probably avoid it.

I'm giving this a thumbs up because I am enjoying the game (though I doubt I'll have the patience to play a campaign as each boss), however the game does need some work.  I enjoy the setting, and I like the XCOM like aspect of combat (albeit not very difficult in most cases).  If you want to play a game where you play the role of a feared mob boss with little that can stand in your way, you’ll get some enjoyment out of this.  If you’re looking for a challenge, keep walking.

Many of the other reviews have covered some of the flaws, and I won’t restate them.

But a major flaw I’ve found is how battle in the street works.  When battle begins in a building, it’s clear, attackers vs. defenders.  However, some battles will take place in the streets. For example, if you are going to attack a racket, you have to first take out the guards posted outside, so there is no avoiding it.  

When an outdoor battle initiates, it carves out a section of the neighborhood map as the battle area. Any non civilian character that happens to be in that area is part of the fight.  This can include your gangsters, gang guards guarding close by buildings (these can be friendly, enemy or neutral), police that happen to be patrolling the area, down to some random thug in the alley with no gang affiliation that feels it’s necessary to jump in the fight rather than mind his own business. On paper this sounds kinda cool, but here are some issues I ran into:

In the game sometimes you have a nonaggression pact with specific gangs.  This can happen after you’ve been at war with them, and decide to form a truce.  This means that your standing with the gang is still “enemy”, but you just have agreed not to fight each other for some time.  If you break this pact you take a hit to your honor.  So if you’re attacking a different gang in the street, and there happens to be some guards from the gang you have the pact with, guess what, they join the fight and start shooting at you (since they are your enemy). If you defend yourself this BREAKS THE PACT!!!

Another bad situation I got into, I was attacking one gang, and two other gangs that were neutral to me but at war with each other were also on the map.  This triggered a fight among just them, and I had to sit and watch the dumb AI guards battle it out, skipping the turns for each of my gangsters over and over until finally one side won.

Another great situation, I was being attacked and controlling a single guard outside a racket being attacked by 3 enemy guards.  All I did was get shot and run to cover near a police officer that happened to be nearby (I was hoping he would help protect me, since I was outnumbered).  The police officer got shot by the enemy attackers, and when it became his turn, HE ARRESTED ME!

Tl;dr: Fun game if you like the idea of XCOM in a 1920’s setting, and aren’t looking for a challenge.  But be aware there are some issues.

I don't mind janky games, and Empire of Sin is both an interesting concept and unique execution, the low-budget animations and voice-acting are therefore part of the charm.  But, for people who see those things are vital to the presentation, it's going to be obvious.

The bugs ... are bugs.  I am not a, "Games are bugged, what are you going to do?" person, but it is true that even the most classic and recognizable games have had them.  So, it is a case of, "Well, they say they are going to patch them and I hope they do."  I do not believe this game will be completely overhauled, so if what it is now doesn't appeal to you, I don't expect any amount of patches to change your mind.  But if you find the game compelling but difficult to get into because of some of its technical flaws, I would say come back in a month and see if a patch has improved things.

As many others have echoed, there is a lot of promise in this game. Numerous ideas and systems in place that definitely show me the developers had amazing ideas they wanted to capitalize on. There are hints of depth everywhere, such as upgrading the word of mouth for your bars, brothels, and casinos causing more foot traffic. Upgrading the decor and ambience of your establishments to enhance the allure of certain places, potentially increasing the amount people want to spend there - though with the caveat that you also increase upkeep(it makes sense, as hiring a band for a bar obviously means you have to pay them). There's so much more to it as well.

Certain neighborhoods have certain alcohol types they prefer, which can change, so you have to be mindful of what you're producing and where you're producing it. Keeping your gangsters in certain establishments run the risk of various different negative traits as well. Don't stay in a brothel too long or else you might snatch up an STD! Stuff like this really makes you give things a second look, and with how extensive the Empire Management screen is, you can see they definitely wanted to double down on the strategy aspect of things.

But unfortunately, nothing meaningful ever really comes of it in any impactful way(s). At most it's usually an extra couple $$$ if you play your cards right, and honestly I never had someone pick up any negative trait by staying too long in any one place.

There's a certain level of interest in the RPG-lite type mechanics in place, where you roll persuade checks, and despite appearances there's some decision making in dialogue to be made, so I definitely give credit to the game here. One intriguing part of the game is that each mobster you potentially hire seems to have their own backstory and side quests. One gentlemen I hired named Grover had a backstory in the circus of all things. His side quest involved me going to one of my owned establishments and either talking to the person who potentially betrayed him or just letting him kill him outright. I talked to him personally with my boss and found out it was a misunderstanding and Grover was mistaken. It isn't huge, but it serves to give the game some life and personality.

Despite this though, the biggest shortcoming is definitely the combat. While if you've played Firaxis' XCOM games, you will be completely familiar with the formula, though it's such an unbalanced mess here. Sniper rifles are so grossly overpowered that it's such a no brainer to just equip anyone you can with them. Shotguns underperform, SMGs and LMGs confer aim(marksmanship) penalties, and pistols don't do nearly enough damage to warrant using them in any meaningful manner. I actually don't think I bothered to use my pistols once outside of being forced when I don't have access to a main weapon. 

The Heal skill is only on a 1 turn cooldown, heals a good chunk, and it feels like all level 1 security for your establishments get it. It also only takes 1 action point to use so you can often cheese out fights with it, because another failing of the game is the atrocious AI. They will often just stand in the open or take bad angles to take pot shots at you. It isn't like it's much better for you, because your security have such awful aim, that even with a proper flank and ideal range you're getting like 55% to hit at most. Most defense missions are just boring dice rolls where the AI doesn't do itself any favors. 

As an aside really quickly, what I find odd is that the game even tells you your percentage chance to win or lose a defense mission but offers no way to autoresolve. Lol? I feel like that is either a mechanic that didn't make it in, got scrapped, or is coming.

Your generic goons are whatever. Bosses? They can solo entire rooms full of people, and some of their abilities are just GROSS with how powerful they are. Daniel Mckee Jackson gets an ability called Last Rites which is essentially Face Off from XCOM where he keeps shooting his pistol. Balance in this game is nutty and trivializes so much of the combat encounters. Given that this is a Paradox published game with an "expansion" or season pass, I would hope and think that patches are going to happen. So I fully expect them to fine tune some of this stuff. I was actually excited to see this game be released.   I really [i]wanted[/i] to enjoy this game.   I really [i]wanted[/i] to love this game.   I really [i]wanted[/i] to recommend this game.   Sadly, I can't really suggest this game for the vast majority of people.

The game plays very much like Omerta: City of Gangsters.    You're a 1920s era gangster trying to make a name for yourself during prohibition by setting up distilleries, speakeasies, brothels, and casinos.   Along the way you build up your gang which you use to take over neighborhoods of Chicago.

The combat is a tactical style combat, similar to XCOM or Mutant Year Zero : Road to Eden.   

You can't create your own gangster, but you can choose from a variety of historical gangsters of the era, as well as some unique ones included to add more variety and diversity to the roster.   Each of these is voice acted and they all have their own unique stories.  The voice acting isn't horrible, but it's not academy award material either, to be honest.   

The biggest problem is that the game gets very repetitive, very quickly.   Wandering around town, you will get called to sitdowns by the other bosses, one by one.    Should you agree, the conversations are all essentially identical, a fact which is obvious very early on.

The combat, which can occur on the streets of Chicago or within building maps is as repetitive as the conversations.   This greatly reduces the amount of time the game is enjoyable.   

There is only one way to win the game--to take over the entire city of Chicago, one neighborhood at a time.  There is only one path to doing this--eliminating other gangs, one gang at a time.   Yes, there are diplomacy options in the game, and you can make deals, including non-aggression pacts or teaming up to take down another gang.   Ultimately though, this can't be used as a strategy to win the game.  Sooner or later, you wll have to take down all of the gangs or you can never win the game.    In the words of Connor MacCleod, "There can be only one!"

In the end, I am disappointed to say that I can not recommend this game for purchase unless you are huge fan of Omerta-City of Gangsters and wish some of the issues in that game like the overpowered enemies were fixed.     Even then, I can't see it being worth the cost giving the extremely limited scope of the game and limited replayability.    I would highly recommend waiting for a deep cut sale price if you purchase it at all.

81508357.review:
Feels very rushed, but I've enjoyed some of it and feel like I've gotten my money's worth. The aesthetic, music is nice, and the gameplay is xcom tactics/ basic management. The characters are colorful and unique, and its not a bad game if you are in the mood for some casual tactical strategy with a cool 1920s gangster aesthetic and a rudimentary strategic layer. 

Don't expect a deep experience or much replayability at this point - each starting character has a set of unique missions, but the gameplay loop is fundamentally the same. The basic idea is that you complete x-com-lite tactical battles to take over bars, brothels, and casinos and expand your empire while defending from AI attacks and doing basic diplomacy, and completing various battle and fetch missions. You control a squad of gangsters that each have unique traits and backstories and fall into one of a few classes with skill trees - doctors, gunmen, brawlers, etc. The tactical battles can be pretty difficult on higher levels, and you face off against both nameless AI goons and the AIs own unique squads of gangsters. You can upgrade your businesses in a few ways but it feels pretty meaningless currently. 

Some of the design choices (or choice of what mechanics to forego at release) are pretty frustrating. For example, you can recruit unique characters, but the bulk of your & the AI's forces are nameless goons. When the AI attacks your businesses, you may have one unique character defending, but it is usually a nameless goon vs. nameless goon slugfest where the goons all have a 50% chance at best of hitting each other and it takes two or three shots at least to kill a goon. Its simply boring - and there is no autoresolve, no way to speed up the fights, nor even an option to forfeit the battle, which I would gladly do since when you ultimately win a gang war by killing the opposing gang boss, you get all your businesses back anyways. A way to skip or decline minor, repetitive fights is something I would expect from any modern strategy release, and its absence here suggests that the game was shipped before it was ready.

More evidence of premature release is that it is currently obviously unbalanced and full of game-breaking bugs. I've had saves corrupted and multiple freezes requiring restart. Some quests are just broken. There are the seeds of an excellent character-driven gangster sandbox strategy game here - maybe they will bloom in time, but its uncertain.

So I love this game so far, but I have some major issues with it to. While I do highly recommend this game to anyone who likes tactical or resource management games, if I could actually give this a numbered score it'd be a 6 or 7. Here's why.

What the game does right:
- The world feels like it's alive and breathing around you. Random events happen, but they always feel like they've been led up to with foreshadowing. Sure, you might randomly get attacked by a rival gang but you definitely saw it coming, the attack doesn't surprise you, and if you were in their shoes you'd do the same thing.
- In the same vein, the fact that every henchman is a specifically designed person with their own relationships with other potential henchmen is amazing! Every little bit of this game oozes personality and identity.
- The depth of management of your empire is huge. If you REALLY like games where you have to think and plan out the use of your resources and keep an eye on every little bit of minutea, this is your game. There are pages upon pages upon pages of reports and charts and financial analysis and stat sheets. I'm a data analyst, and the report tabs are a data analysts wet dream. I could make like 20 more points like this around faction relations and trade deals and alcohol management and this that and the other thing but I'll just say the "Civilization VI" style management part of this game is phenominal.
- The initial game balance. You really do feel like a new mob boss at the start with what you have access to and the resources you have. You don't feel like a random dude that has no business being here, but you also know you're a small fish in a big pond.


What the game could improve:
- Combat, while fully functional, has some issues. The AI of your opponents all has the "chrysalid" AI from XCOM. In a game where the AI use guns, that takes a lot of the tactical challenge out of it. I'm playing on the highest difficulty and pasting everyone. Yes, I have 800+ hours in XCOM, but this feels line the same level of challenge I'd get on normal in XCOM.
- Machine guns are unbalanced. When you fire a machine gun, you do burst fire. That involves firing three separate shots. The shots do around the same damage as a shotgun slug, work between close and medium range just fine, and have good overall accuracy. In what world wouldn't you use this weapon against literally anything?
- It could do a better job explaining overworld controls. It took me 2 hours to learn I could center on my crew by hitting tab in the overworld. Same goes for keyboard shortcuts, I still haven't found the shortcut for pause.

What the game is horrible at:
- "Boss" powers are PAINFULLY overpowered. One of the bosses straight up unloads an entire pistol clip, and if he kills an enemy while firing he just continues shooting at the next one. Another one runs up and does 3 melee hits that do 50+ damage each, and if you kill someone you get all your AP back and the ability comes off cooldown meaning you can do it again. These powers feel like an instant win button.
- Challenge Scaling. So, I'm playing on the highest difficulty. I got into a gang war with a massive gang when I had one henchman. I took out one building, defended another, and then I said fuck it and went after the mob boss for fun after saving. When I actually managed to take down their safehouse I just straight up got 11k and every single one off their rackets immediately, and somehow this didn't piss off anyone enough to come after me for it. I went from having 4 buisnesses to having close to 20 overnight, and I know for a fact if I keep going I'll keep growing exponentially. The entire challenge of the game is gone.
- Between these two things I'm literally having to limit myself to give myself a challenge. "You can't use the DLC Weapons. You're not allowed to attack a safehouse until the rival gang is down to X number of rackets left." Etc, etc. When I'm on the highest difficulty and I'm inventing my own challenges and restrictions to follow, something has gone horribly wrong in balance.

Summary: This game is definitely fun, and both the theme and the resource / empire management save it and make it something special. The combat almost needs a complete overhaul though. DEFINITELY buy it if the genre and setting are your thing, skip it otherwise for now. The game has huge potential, it hasn't realized it yet though.

81504119.review:
I went into this game sort of expecting something reminiscent of Omerta: City of Gangsters, but that's not really what this game is at all. Empire of Sin seems to have this weird dichotomy between many of it's mechanics and the actual gameplay. 

At the start it gives the suggestion of a deep narrative, and as you go along you're presented with various story-based objectives and side objectives which appear to differ depending on which boss you start the game with. It's this narrative and familiar Xcom style of gameplay that sparks your interest and keeps you going while you're almost expecting the gameplay to become more varied as you keep playing. But that just never happens. You very quickly realize the monotony of building the same 4 kinds of buildings over and over again and that this is indeed the whole game. It's not at all like Omerta where you had many different kinds of businesses to open that played into a variety of mechanics. No, this is the same 4 buildings that all serve the purpose of making money that you just build over and over again. For hours all you do is take over a place, bit of combat here, build your 10th or 20th speakeasy/brothel/casino/brewery, & repeat. Someone else said this game was like a board game, and yeah that's pretty much spot on.

It's both disappointing and weird to me that they went in this direction and it kind of makes me think they had to have had a different idea of where to take this game at some point because there's some really cool stuff in this game that suggests that. There are a lot of bosses to play as, each have their own storyline, unique personalities and perks. There are a ton of gangsters you can hire, and they even have relationships with each other where they're friends, lovers or enemies. You can promote them to important positions in your gang. You can get gear for yourself and your gangsters, even unique gear from killing other bosses. All of this to me hints at a much deeper game than it is. So when I was playing it I kept thinking "Well there HAS to be more to it than this, right?" But no, disappointingly, there just isn't. 

It's a real shame too because I genuinely love so much about this game like the characters, the combat and especially the music (although hearing that "upgrade complete" music every time was really annoying after a while). But the game is deceptively shallow so unfortunately I can't recommend this if you were expecting a much deeper experience than what is essentially a digital board game.

At this time I have over 8 hours played. This game has different gangs with different bosses to pick from. The bosses have empire bonuses, like discount to racket upgrades and an extra guard in certain rackets and so forth. They have a special fighting move, like one ricochets a bullet to 3 targets and one charms someone with smoke which causes them to switch to your side but take damage until they die. And they have a special bonus, like trade deals being 10% more likely to be accepted or truces lasting 50% shorter or so forth. The bosses are all based off either historical characters or from fiction. Al Capon is of course a selectable boss.

In game each boss has their own main mission chain and there are small missions or mission chains that appear around the map. Like right now I'm in a middle of a mission chain where I'm up against a gang from canada that makes poisoned maple syrup. I had a branching choice to poison a rival's booze with their syrup which would have made me profit but hurt the citizenry, or rat them out to a member of the rival gang. I'm eager to see how it goes.

Rackets can be bought if unowned, they can be liberated from hostile thugs, and they can be captured from rivals. If a enemy gang wants to target your racket, a mark will appear on the racket. You can rush over there if necessary, or if you've upgraded your security you might have enough guards there to beat them without your gangsters. You'll be controlling the guards there when it's attacked.

The map is divided into neighborhoods on a map. Gangs can control a neighborhood. There can be as many as 10 or as few as 3 neighborhoods. There can be as many as 13 or as few as 6 rival gangs. You can hire gangsters, which come from history or fiction like the bosses, and possibly put one as an underboss in a neighborhood. Different gangsters have different bonuses to the neighborhood when placed as an underboss. It's possible to synergize a gangsters bonuses by specializing a neighborhood. In the neighborhood I started in, I placed enough casinos that it gained the nickname "Gambling Strip". I don't know what other neighborhood titles there are.

I like how this game is so far. Since it's published by paradox, there's likely going to be a lot more development in the form of big free updates that come alongside DLC that add even more. That's sort of a reputation Paradox has, a lot of future development of a game, with a combination of free updates and dlc. Of course this might dare to deviate from established tradition, we'll have to see.

What I wanted: mobster XCOM
What I got: mobster XCOM Chimera Squad

The tactical combat is unchallenging since your character is going to be incredibly OP, aside from fighting other mobster bosses. There is an ability that trivializes those too. 

The base "management" aspect is basically non-existent. You take buildings and put a category on them, then they make you money (or produce booze to fuel the money making). Then you can upgrade them, mostly to either make them less likely to be attacked, better guarded, or better at...making money. Which you generally don't need. If you are aggressive about expanding, you'll rapidly find yourself swimming in cash. The gameplay loop is simple: attack thing to make money to attack more things. 

The icing on this mobster cake is that there's a ton of stuff that's simply under-explained. What actual benefits does an advisor or underboss give? What does the "draw" on the buildings actually translate into? What are the actual effects of hotels? What are the synergy bonuses? And most of all, why on earth is the diplomacy system COMPLETELY ripped from EVERY OTHER PARADOX GAME? John Romero, you could have been a LITTLE more creative here. It's literally the same thing in Stellaris or CK2/3 with the green+ and red- and the (+/-X) weekly or monthly or daily or whatever. 

This game is shallower than the average Crusader Kings gene pool. I recommend passing on this until there's some DLC (to make it actually interesting) and it's all on sale.

This is based on early impressions so I may come around on it, but so far it's hard to find a reason to want to keep playing.

The main thing I dislike about this game is how mindless and devoid of tactical thinking the combat is. Both your units and the enemy units have so much health that getting hit doesn't feel like a significant consequence, and it feels like the way hit percentage is calculated often doesn't make sense with your positioning (why do I have 70% hit chance to shoot this man 1 tile over with a shotgun, while I have 90% hit chance on this guy who is literally obscured by an entire truck?). All added up, positioning feels like an afterthought. I won the first story mission I did after the tutorial by pressing 1 (the button to shoot) over and over until all the enemies died, without moving.

There's also other cases of dubious design: In said mission (this is in Stephanie St. Claire's campaign) the game made me run several blocks across town to meet a butcher, who told me to go back to my HQ to talk to a guy, who then made me follow him back to the butcher - and walking takes a long time! This also somehow took *twenty-eight days* in the game. That's more amusing than a real problem, but it doesn't exactly make for great immersion.

Other than that, the UI is frustrating. Most UI elements either have no tooltips, or the tooltips only show stuff like how certain numbers are made up of other numbers. Coupled with some really cluttered screens, this feels like a big no-no for a strategy game in general, and in particular as a person with ADHD this makes this part of the game borderline unfathomable.

It also has other problems like poor voice acting and animations, and some very stilted writing and dialogue, but I'm willing to overlook all that because I can tell they were earnestly really trying for something. But... it just feels like they didn't know how to execute on that ambition at all. It's a shame. I'll try to play more of it but I'm not hopeful.

81489746.review:
I want to start this by saying I truly wanted to like this game more than any other I've played. I love the setting of 1920's Chicago, mobsters and love the genre of grand strategy. However, even though for these reasons I'll probably still occasionally play it, I would advise all others not to buy Empire of Sin in its current state. The issue with the game is not the ideas and concepts, rather, the execution. While combining business management, Paradox diplomacy, turn based strategy, and an RPG looks good on paper, they all have their own issues that break the game. Business management aspects are rather dull, requiring massive amounts of capital to upgrade businesses anywhere from 2-6 thousand an upgrade, while the income may only be a few hundred. The same applies for purchasing weapons, a normal pistol may cost as much as an entire brewery of yours. Diplomacy is fairly meaningless, as deals that are stuck are comically meaningless. The combat is alright, not new or innovative or bad and buggy, just average. RPG aspects are dull and lacluster, as character developments don't have much of an inmpact and negative effects can be easily circumnavigated. While these are all poor in their own right, what ruins the game is the AI. The AI won't attack, expand, or do much of anything. They just kind of sit there. As the player all you have to do, is kill an enemy boss at their safehouse and you win all of that gangs possesions, After killing two or three boses, you basically win the game. This coupled with completly dumb AI strategy ruins the game. This game is much closer to being in Alpha compared to a finally release state. I"m not one for complaining without offering solutions, so here are a few suggestions that I would make to improve the game. 

Overhaul the economic systems 
Completly fix the AI 
Make gang wars feel real
Have enemy bosses switch locations, so you have to gain on intellegence first for a suprise hit 
Perhaps require a certain ammount of captured businesses before confronting a boss? 
Give other ways to win the game besides killing boses 

Overall, there a tons more suggestions I could make but I'm sure many more players will make them as well. This game is in need of a No Man's Sky type overhaul. The foundations are there, yet this game needs to work out all the kinks, bind the systems together, and vastly improve the AI's strategy for this game to become the ultimate gangster game it was marketed as and I hope it can become.

Don't usually post reviews but this game has a "Mixed" rating at the time of writing and that certainly doesn't reflect the quality of the game.

This is a blend of turn-based combat and real time strategy, similar to something like XCOM in gameplay but not in theme. You pick a boss with unique abilities and set out carving out an empire in prohibition-era Chicago. Build rackets, gun down rivals, etc etc. You can do pretty much everything you'd expect out of a gangster game, and there is a pretty cool logistical planning and optimization element to the mid-game.

It benefits (in my mind) from there not being any comparable modern game to compare it to that also adheres to the organized crime genre. If we're being honest, it also is a better game at launch than most other games have been that are under the Paradox banner (looking at you, Imperator: Rome, which continues to be a worse game now than this is at launch). Could they tweak some elements of the combat to make it harder to accidentally, say, run across the map for no reason to punch someone in the face? Sure. Could there be some work done to add an automation layer to make the mid-game less stressful? Yes. 

But is it currently worth the money? Right now yes, and especially so considering every other Paradox game (minus Imperator) has gotten exponentially better as time went on, and the things that are wrong with this game right now don't have anything to do with core gameplay, it is all quality of life and the things most likely to be fixed by a patch.

81487343.review:
Empire of Sin is super challenging, there are a lot of complex systems at play and the tutorials are quite bad at explaining.
It can be fun to discover these systems and their interactions on your own, but it can also lead to a lot of heartache when it feels like you're being robbed by some random bull.
After playing for 13 hours i was able to beat the game on the hardest difficulty. It was very challenging and I lost about 6 total units out of the 10 I hired.
In some ways, the game feels like civ, combined with mafia, combined with XCOM, combined with darkest dungeon.

Pros:
-Very unique experience based on what character you chose to play as and what crew you hire.
-Combat has a lot of customization and cool combos to pull off
-Every character has their own storyline, and randomly generated buffs/nerfs that connect to their background
-Characters all have people they like and dislike based on their traits, and can betray each other, fall in love, or try to take you down from the inside based on factors including loyalty and morale
-Fast travel system is super unrestricted, meaning you can be anywhere and everywhere at once if you optimize your play
-Exploration through normal walking around is rewarded

Cons:
-Super buggy still, they say they patched a ton before launch and I'm glad cuz otherwise it would've been unplayable
-Combat has no good system to skip your turn or speed up time progression of the combat, making the game feel super slow and tedious at time
-The game doesn't seem to have enough content to be worth its $40 launch price, maybe dlc will help
-The game feels like it would be one of the most fun multiplayer rts games ever, yet it is singleplayer only (this is the biggest problem imo, no idea why they didn't make multiplayer)
-One of the key systems (managing your empire) is really annoying to manage, as you basically just get alerts every 5 minutes and then u open a menu and adjust based on the info given. You don't have to do anything to get that info, and whether or not you keep up with this micromanaging can be the difference of having no income and being the richest player in the game
-The police AI seems broken, they rarely conduct raids on your businesses, and if they get suspicious about one of your businesses u can close up shop for very little in game time and they will forget they had any suspicion at all.
-In combat, the police AI are bloodthirsty terminators, who will put you in handcuffs and then shoot your defenseless goon until he full on dies rather than arresting them. They have way better aim than any of the early or mid game characters and do crazy damage for seemingly unknown reasons.
-Goons are not necessary, but make the game astronomically easier, the only problem is they take flat percentages of your total income, so when u hire a guy you pay him like 10 grand just to join up, then he takes 3-10% of your TOTAL income every week depending on how OP he is

TL;DR: Like lots of games, ton of potential but just way too many problems to recommend it at this point. If you like the prohibition mob setting, its worth keeping tabs on this game to see where the development goes.

Jeez, this is bad.

I was so into this game. I had it preordered and it was a tossup whether I'd be more into this or Cyberpunk. After all, it's a management sim with a mafia theme and tactical combat. It's basically made for me.

Except it's not. It's not for anyone. Its initial strong charm wears off quickly when you get into the flow of the game, which it's clear nobody put much time into. Your character's unique traits, promising a customized experience, aren't particularly useful, coming in randomly once in a while, but never telling you exactly what happened. The sit-downs, supposed to be a clash of personalities, are invariably an exchange of zingers followed by an offer of sharing bonuses. The management part is fine for what it is, but traveling around the world map is an infuriating exercise in zooming out, zooming out some more, sometimes zooming out a third time to go to a place and then you can interact with a building and do your talking or fighting. There are a zillion missions that come in from nowhere, far too many to track, and all of them basically have the same flow. It quickly becomes clear that the game has shown its whole hand in the first minutes and you're just going to see the same things over and over again.

Speaking of repetition, there's the combat. The thing you spend most of your time doing. You can essentially win any fight by just shooting over and over and over again. Terrain doesn't matter, placement doesn't matter beyond line of site, AI is terrible, and everyone is outclassed. And combat is the endgame of every interaction, as far as I can tell. There's no autoresolve; it's just endless fight after endless fight.

If there's violence in a mob game, it needs to be visceral. And it's not. It's a sanitized gunfighting game where there are dozens of people standing in the line of fire, who you can't hurt. There are no civilian casualties. You can only hurt other criminals. Even accidentally. I don't WANT to kill civilians, but the fact that I never accidentally hit one in dozens of firefights kept taking me out of the game. 

The game might be fun enough without the combat, but the combat kills fun as efficiently as your gangsters kill nameless thugs. 

I want to wait and see if this gets patched into something good. But there's a fundamental sloppiness, from the animations to the systems that don't really interact with one another to the deluge of repetitive quests to the wasted subject matter and bland writing, that makes me think this is the game we get. Which is ultimately the sin this game traffics in.

81476611.review:
This game is a pretty solid foundation for a turn based tactics game. However it is not very polished and has a lot of minor issues and a few major ones. For instance my best campaign so far was ended because I destroyed a faction, and that dead faction would try to talk to me later which would immediately freeze the game, forcing me to Alt+F4 it and restart. Loading back into that campaign would lead to that same thing happening soon after the save, so a multiple hour long campaign is just ended due to a bug. The minor issues include things like unskippable conversations (which are about the same between every boss, so get old fast), character pathing getting stuck while exploring on the map, and the game hanging mid-combat while it seems to be calculating something. The game is basically still in a beta state with many bugs, some of which are game breaking so I cannot recommend it in its current state.

However, the game has a lot of upgrades over Xcom 2 which is the closest game I have played to this style. There is a percentage chance to hit predictor that updates as you mouse over tiles a character can move to. The percentage chance to hit does not lie from what I can tell, whereas in Xcom 2 the player will miss more shots the better they do in missions, so the RNG is wildly inaccurate once you get into a campaign. You recruit the same basic soldiers early, but with their relationships you can recruit some late game people earlier in the campaign so you can recruit a wide variety of people. You can also influence how their traits are gained to an extent, making each soldier slightly different in every playthrough. If the developers work on this game it has a chance to be great, it is just not currently in a fun state as players will just get frustrated with the glaring bugs and other issues.

EDIT: As an update to this review, the bug that initially prevented me from progressing was fixed, and I was able to finish my first campaign. However upon starting a new one on the next higher difficulty I was unable to attack any territories as whenever I clicked to attack the game just ignored my input. The devs have been releasing fairly quick patches to fix bugs, however there are still some that break the game so my overall review still stands.

81475415.review:
It's a mess, but at heart it's a fun tactical X-Comish game with a management layer thrown on top.

Let's start with the "mess" part, just in case you're looking for a reason to skip it:
* The UI lacks a lot of standard quality-of-life features, like being able to select people by clicking on their names, being able to jump to a location by clicking on its direction icon, being able to center the map on your character
* The combat UI is *finicky* about selecting enemies to hit, and you'll often set up a long combo attack hitting multiple people and then accidentally click on scenery while trying to click on a target and have it reset so you have to set it all up again
* The gangsters you can build into a team are the exact same ones, game to game, so there's not as much replayability here as you'd like
* The voice acting is mixed (some voice actors are so focused on the accent that they bring no emotion to the line itself, for example) and the character animations are poor
* Some of the game is written in a dark, serious, gritty, Godfather-esque tone, and some of it is written in a zany "it's just a game, why so serious" tone and obviously they don't work together well
* There's a huge selection of randomized-effect weapons ala Borderlands included to power up your people, but there's not an easy way to compare their stats against each other - you have to mouse over, scroll to the specific stat, and then go to the other weapon, mouse over, and scroll to the specific stat

But if you can get past that, there's some good tactical and management fun to be had here. Not sure that without fixing some of these things that it's really worth the full $40, though.

The game's tutorial has you recruit two additional gangsters and that ends up costing you $600 in wages when my rackets (2 speakeasies and a brewery) earned somewhere like $400.

This is a really greatly themed game. The setting, the story, the voice acting, all well done. 

So basically the game evolves around recruiting gangsters, getting better gear, expanding your empire either buy taking over derelict buildings, rival buildings or just buying a building that is for sale. All of your buildings (rackets) can be upgraded in a multitude of ways.

The gangsters you can recruit all have various skills they can learn and have a lot of unique quirks and perks.

Under the hood, this is a number crunching game. Supply and demand, percentages, bonuses all combine to give you your income. There are some neat "poker" mechanics when it comes to collecting various rackets in a district. 2 of a kind, full house, all give you added bonuses, so try to build in sets.

The combat is distinctly tile/turn-based combat. Move, get into cover, try and flank, shoot or melee. Each gangster can learn a few combat skill to flesh out the combat, but it's exactly what you think it'd be. If you like combat like this, you'll enjoy it here. Nothing new, just simple, solid mechanics.

Now, there are a few issues with the game so far. A few movement bugs, sometimes characters t-pose when fast traveling, if you are doing the tutorial do not enter a sitdown when you get the popup for instance, adding armor to your characters, you won't be able to click dialogue buttons and will forever be stuck on that screen.

Some audio sounds loop on top of each other, especially when there are multiple characters talking and the guns... they don't all sound great.

But, the aesthetic, the business aspect of the game as well as the story and sidequests really make this an interesting game and even if you have a passing interest, I would definitely pick this up. The positives far exceed the negatives and I feel like it will only get better with time.

I don't regret getting this game, but if you're a little reluctant, just wait a month or so and it'll be on sale.

With a neat idea of genre combination and a fresh setting the game was set up to be a success. Yet, it is held back by extremely shallow game design. Both aspects, the tactical combat and the economy sim, fall desperately short. 

The combat lacks variety and any noteworthy innovations. Which could be fine on its own, but the combat A.I. is simply the shoddiest I've seen, significantly worse then the original XCOMs 25 years ago. Most enemies simply walk close, do nothing, and get killed. That's it, without special enemies or inventive weapons, every combat feels the same, and it doesn't change with difficulty. 

The economy part is inconsequential to the game. Sure, it provides money, but that can be earned by quests and raiding. Other than titles like Civ or Stellaris, economy and politics cannot be used to influence the game other than providing money (or so it seems 5 hours in). The complexity of the economic system stops at one building making booze, the other 4 converting booze to money. All five types have the same incremental upgrades that have to be clicked once when there's money. Shame, because with the good UI and ample statistics the game promises to be fairly complex. But it just isn't.

The only strong side of the game is the squad selection, with a huge roster and intricate relationships between the characters. Don't expect DragonAge level of story here, but there are neat side quests for the crew that are worth following, simple branching decisions and unique rewards included.

And no impression would be complete without mentioning the bugs. Game braking hangups, broken quest lines, audio occasionally lagging 3 seconds behind, bugged animations, permanently stuck overlays, stuck characters, long pauses, and questionable hit-percentages over long distances. How could all that pass QA? The bugs are easily found and fixable. Another obviously rushed release.

The game has potential, with good design over all it is definitely likable. Maybe it gets a second life with a bunch of DLCs, but this first throw seems like a below average deal to me. I regret the purchase.

Ambitious game developed to late-2000s standards that did not live up to the marketing or pre-release reviews.  First Steam refund.  Hoping the dev team or modders make it live up to its potential, but not worth full price for a game that is at best early release.

The game has basic elements for an interesting concept, but execution misses the mark across the board.  The business management component is simplistic with little variation across rackets.  The turn-based combat is poorly developed, with AI behavior, combat mechanics, and one-line comments from characters that make it a frustrating process to click through.  The neighborhood/empire component of the game is also simplistic, with nothing required other than brute force expansion across the city, ignoring the largely unnecessary boss meetings that simply result in a classic boss fight with no opportunity for diplomacy or other outcomes long-term.  Character development, moral decision-making, and skill progression are also limited compared to modern standards.

There are also numerous bugs still in place, particularly in the combat interface, including characters not moving to squares, AI characters abruptly shifting clothing when animations are stitched together, and a clunky interface that borders on defective.

Some of the graphics are very well designed and developed, including building interiors and the city street view (although, again, several bugs observed for building interiors).  The dialogue and animations are also stylized to match what you might have seen in the late 2000s, which was off-putting given modern design standards.

This is a real toss-up for me. I'm basically 50/50 on it, and I wish Steam would allow me to post the review as neutral with information in here instead of a 'recommend' or not... because the game has the bones of something really cool. The structure is there. The visuals are wonderful. The systems in place have potential. The idea is great, and 'almost' executed well enough for a recommendation - but alas, the details were ignored, the pacing isn't right, the entire concept of the AI having even a 2nd grade reading level was overlooked, and the trade/barter/negotiation system is all one-sided. You have no say over the core of what makes this game great, and therefore, it becomes mediocre at best. 

It's an economy driven game, without the need to build much of an economy. It's a business simulator with no control over your prices. It's a multi-agency strategy game with no say over trades or negotiation terms (it's take what they offer you, or piss them off). It's a turn-based tactical combat game, without the need for proper tactics, even at Boss difficulty (the highest). It has many screens of in-depth information, but doesn't give you what you want to know when you want to know it. It'll interrupt your gameplay entirely with repetitive noises and loud crashing sounds for things you don't care about, and then fail to notify you on things you do care about. Even things like quest markers take an unusually long time to find on the map. It's as if they never thought allowing interaction with a quest would make the player want to know 'where' it takes place. A simple button to zoom in on the location would be best. Information such as what you're currently producing has no mouse-over at all (is that barrel swill or rack? I really don't know unless I go to another screen to find words next to the symbol. Also... the strongest weapon in the entire game is the taxi. Don't bother investing in security. It's not needed. Just pause, taxi there instantly during pause with your hero, and blow the enemy up. 

It needs improvements, and perhaps due to it's extensive modding capabilities, we'll get even more than the devs have planned... assuming they have it planned. I wish them well on their journey to make this game the great game it was meant to be. I hope they see the criticism in the reviews as an opportunity to improve it to something awesome, like No Mans Sky has done, and not something to abandon, like say... Phantom Doctrine. 

Overall right now, I give it a 6/10 -- and at $40, that's just not good enough. Wait for a deep sale now, or evaluate when it's had some patches, has improved it's AI greatly, has expanded it's availability of information, and hopefully has fixed Salazar's voice... because... well.. that voice has got to go. [h1]DO NOT BUY THIS GAME EXPECTING XCOM WITH CITY MANAGEMENT. IT IS A CITY MANAGEMENT SANDBOX GAME FIRST AND FOREMOST. WITH XCOM COMBAT SPRINKLED IN.[h1]

Now that THAT'S out of the way.

This is a great game. I only have 6 or so hours on record, but fully expect to have at least 24 by the end of the week. I think that the marketing for this game was handled poorly as so many here are complaining about the repetitive nature of missions and the combat over-poweredness of the boss.

This game is a SANDBOX styled CITY MANAGEMENT game. Meaning that you will be left to your own devices, and the ultimate goal of the game is to control the city through various means, there is a long progression track that's entirely intrinsically motivated as far as taking over the city and growing your gang is. 

Added to this is the chaos of random missions (they have decent enough stories and quirks overall) that give you buffs, money, equipment, de-buffs, and positive or negative talents (permanent modifiers to your characters) based on how you go about the missions and how you finish them. But these are not supposed to be the main focus of the game, and are just minor extrinsic motivators compared to what the game is designed for.

Most of this "review" is expressing how the other reviews are wrong. And I understand that's in strange taste. But they are only wrong insofar as their expectations of the game do not match what the game is.

If you enjoy sandbox style games with a understandable and enclosed economic systems. Along with faction diplomacy, buy this game.

If you enjoy xcom and desire more of a xcom management strategy where everything is clear and focused on one goal and the missions that happen habe a clear goal and reason? Dont buy this game. 

I believe it is a wonderful game, and could use some polishing as far as diplomacy works and the AI. But for what I have now, I was engaged, even with the rather bland combat, until well past my normal go to bed time. 

Solid game. And I can't wait to see what they do with it.

Well, my disappointment is immeasurable and my day is ruined.

For the people who preffer looking at red and green thumbs, heres the jist of it: Wait a year, get it on sale for like 20 bucks.

Let me start with a bit of an oxymoronic statement, I love this game, Im addicted to it and I haven't stopped playing it because I just fucking love it to pieces, but you shouldn't be buying it for the full price tag in its current state. The game is obviously unfinished, this is Early Acess without the label, no doubts about it. There is an obvious vision that was torn to shreds by money hungry publishers and it breaks my heart to see it.

Firstly, the gameplay, which can be split into two parts: Combat and Managment

Combat is based on X-COM style strategy if a third grader designed it. Instead of your team going simultaniously, each character has a stat (Initiative) which determines when they act. The biggest number acts first. This sounds like a good idea on paper, but what ends up happening is you being massively overpowered and clearing 5 of the 6 goons before they even get a chance to shit themselves at the sight of you OR your entire squad gets beaten within an inch of its life and you're forced into spending your turn healing and repositioning. The early game is the best part because things are kinda balanced, since you don't have the equivelent of 5 highly trained navy seals on your team, instead you've got a half-blind man with a shotgun and your Boss, who more than likely is taking potshots with his pistol behind solid cover, yet still can't seem to hit the broad side of a barn. Nevermind the fact that there are numerous bugs which slow down gameplay, break how certain perks and skills work, alongside the AI, which at times is average and at others takes the idea of hiding behind cover as a cowardly suggestion rather than a good idea.

The managment side consists of managing your rackets (buildings you take over, most of them generating money or booze), making deals and maintaing or degrading your relationships with other mob families and kitting/leveling your crew. There are 6 types of rackets, which I won't go into detail about. There are plenty of youtube videos explaining them, but the jist of it is they are your primary source of income. The diplomacy is lackluster to say the least, each time you start a war the best course of strategy is getting a taxi to the enemy Safehouse, clearing them out and taking over everything they own. This takes about 10 minutes and 4-5 guys. RPGing your crew is so basic that it makes me fucking mad, you can equip a trinket, armor, 2 consumables, primary and secondary weapons along with different ammo types. Perks are fucking pathetic, due to the randomisation aspect of them. You end up hiring a guy to be a tank/close combat troop and he ends up with 4 perks about fucking sniper rifles and overwatch, making him glorified cannon fodder.

The story is... dull. It's not bad, but it's not good either. Can't really say much about it, if you can get into a simple mob story, you'll love it.

Graphically unimpressive, it's got that roaring 20s vibe, but just kinda looks wierd at times. The game can't decide wether it should be taken seriously or not, so it ends up messing with the general immersion of it. The best example I can give is a crime family, whos leader is literally dressed up as a circus clown.

And now the pudding, bugs. Bugs, bugs, bugs. So many fucking bugs. Graphical glitches, crashes, gamebreaking bugs, quests glitching, combat glitching, diplomacy glitching. Absolutely fucking pathetic. Releasing a game with these BASIC technical issues should be a crime.

In conclusion, the game is akin to a beautiful souffle filled with melted cow shit. Looks good at first, but then ya bite into it and you'd rather have just died. Wait a year for all the massive patches and DLCs to come out, wait for a sale on the season pass and don't pay a dime over 20 dollars/euros.

81457717.review:
Empire Of Sin borrows from a lot of titles. If you've played X-Com before you can jump right into to a tactical fight here and you'll see all the terms and actions you're already familiar with.  Sure the theme lends itself to a  few unique twists here and there, but this isnt the deepest most brain burning turn based tactics game. 

But the nod it took from Civilization 6 is particularly fascinating to me.  What Civ 6 does so well is make each individual game feel like its own little world and story.  No two games are exactly the same and each one finds you making new friendships/enemies and taking new approaches to victory.

While the depth of Civ 6 far surpasses anything you'll see here, what Empire of Sin borrowed from that game it did REALLY well.   For me. Where each game feels like its own little gangster story in its own little universe.  The criticism that it all boils down to you having to take out each gang one by one is mind boggling to me.  In my games I've seen different gangs attack each other and ally each other at different times for different reasons.  And my gangs took different approaches to diplomacy. I've tried being very isolationist and I've been very trade happy.  I've made lots of friends and killed lots of enemies and had a lot of fun. Is it "Samey"... maybe... but no more or less than most of my favorite strategy titles.

It's REALLY light for a Paradox game.   This is NOT the EU/Hearts of Iron answer to the mafia.  This isn't even a really light crusader kings.  But this is a good thing to me.  I like those games but after awhile picking which friggin tire tread to go with on each tank becomes unfun... for me.   I like that this game pulls the lens back a bit and takes a bigger focus on the overall development of your gang and it's leader and members.  I get that some people are disappointed it doesnt have a Crusader Kings level of depth in this regard... but I'm not. I played CK and it's great... I dont need to play it again.   This game borrows from a lot of titles but it's for sure it's own thing and I like that.   And it's ok that it's a lot lighter than we are used to from that publisher.

It's not perfect. It can be a lot better and I have faith it will be. Theres soem bugs here and there but I'm not the kind of person that freaks out over this.  None of the bugs broke MY game, but reading the forums for just a few minutes and you'll find these things ARE happening to gamers in decent numbers.  I save a lot and if a mission bugged out for me ina  game I just ignored it and went forth trying to take over the city and was able to do so.   You may not be so lenient so I thought I'd share my experience.  

But as it stands I really like this game.  I can't tell you exactly what it is about that I like.  No one system is groundbreakingly original.   But the way it blends everything together is fun especially considering the prohibition era gangster theme.  I think the definitive organized crime strategy game has yet to be made, but this holds it's own in a genre that isnt overly saturated.   

I cant tell you if it's worth it or not.  I dont see games that way.   Buying and playing games are two different mindsets for me.  Sure I wait for deals and discounts on certain titles while I decide if it's something I'll play at that time, but basically if I want something enough and decide to spend, I'm not worried about how much money was spent. Thats already gone. I'm worried about how much fun I'm having now and how much fun am I going to have in the future.   So to me, it's worth it. I'm having fun playing the game and I think it's going to get better.  If you're on a budget though maybe wait awhile. Games like this go on sale frequently and given some time I think many of the quirks will be ironed out.  But I do NOT feel like a beta tester as others have said.  I very much feel like I'm playing a damn fun game that's only going to get better.

81451542.review:
Right now I'm sad to say that I really can't recommend this game. It has potential, but all the systems don't really gel together nicely at all. Combat is very slow and very low stakes most of the time (on the middle lieutenant difficulty) where you're mostly fighting worthless thugs that are no real threat. Your crew regenerate as you walk around the city, so I never had to use a healing item or send anyone back to my safehouse. They should really have limited combat to anything involving at least one named gangster on both sides and replaced the rest with timers - I spent most of my game murdering thugs and ransacking empty buildings for money, which wasn't too bad because my boss had an ability that basically insta-killed three people - but it would be very dull to fight them all out normally.

Combat was so easy on this average difficulty that everything else kinda becomes pointless. I played for 2.5 hours and I could walk in and murder an enemy boss with nothing more than one guy injured, and I hadn't been trying all that hard in the fight. Then you get their whole empire, which is 1000% faster than fighting thugs and taking rackets one at a time. It would make more sense for it to splinter into minor factions or you get some of it based on your stats / reputation etc. It's a shame because combat again has potential, it's just a little slow and clunky right now, and almost all your battles are boring busy-work with no danger.

There are quests, for some reason. You teleport to a place (or walk there the first time) and talk to someone, maybe have a fight. It's fine, but on top of everything else happening it feels chaotic. Right now I have two management quests (get x rackets/x weekly income), my boss personal story quest, a gangster personal story quest, and a bunch of random quests about random things/people. It's a bit much and none of it seems to have a huge impact on the game.

Speaking of which, boss sitdowns are a disappointment. You can't seem to be proactive at all (maybe I missed some buttons or something), and the bonuses from doing a deal are pathetic - 2% cheaper security upgrades? Come on, give me at least 10-20%. You can establish defensive pacts and stuff as I saw when I negotiated about joining someone else's war, but right now any war can be ended instantly by marching into the enemy safehouse, so eh.

Upgrading your breweries to make better booze and choosing what booze they make is the most interesting management aspect. Sadly the other racket upgrades are all mostly just positive - word of mouth makes you a bit more likely to be raided as well as making things more popular, but other stuff is just better. Again, it takes so much time to get these upgrades and so much money, when you can just go murder an enemy boss or raid 10 thug buildings and ransack them for far more cash.

Your gangsters are named and have personality traits and relationships, which is potentially very cool but doesn't matter with current combat at standard difficulty. There are tonnes of guns and weapons and grenades and armour and powerups to equip, even different ammo types! But it doesn't really matter when the mooks you're fighting tend to be the same set types of pistol guy, shotgun guy, machine gun guy, melee guy, without any really exciting abilities to be concerned about.

Everything is just so close to being awesome, but there are too many annoyances. Too many boring pointless battles. Too many quests that don't really matter. Sitdowns with insignificant bonuses. Too much going on to make it worth trying to manage and upgrade your rackets. More rackets means probably more raids and slow slow battles between your guards and the raiders, so why would I want more rackets? I can make more money by raids anyway. I haven't even tried selling the loot items I get from battles, but if I can sell the huge pile of fancy guns I've accrued there'll be even less reason to bother with rackets.

I hope they do some serious tweaks and adjustments (or allow modding) to make this game as good as it could be! I will try one more game on a higher difficulty, but I fear that'll just make the battles annoying and frustrating as well as slow.
