Got about eight hours out of it before getting a little bored. There's a lot ooooo to the game, but a lot of ehhhh, too. 


Pros:

- Atmosphere ranges from meh to woah at times. The city looks gorgeous and lively. Old timey cars rumble through the streets and pedestrians fill the sidewalks. Though I wish there were more soundtracks, the few that are there are pretty kickass. Jazz with a little bit of metal/industrial mixed in at times to give it an edge. I have to point out that one seems suspiciously similar to the Mos Eisley Cantina theme from Star Wars, but I'm hesitant to call it a ripoff. Could just have been a common jazz riff of the time. Either way, I liked it. 

- Gameplay loop is fun for a few hours. Even though the tactical combat is kind of ehhh compared to games like X-Com or Phoenix Point, there's still a little excitement knowing every move you make is growing your empire.

- It's been a long time since I've played dedicated tycoon games, but the business side of things seems fine. Lot of min-maxing you can do to make sure potential customers are heading to your establishments over the competition. And of course, failing that, you can always go and get rid of any competition with pew pew. I wish all tycoon games were like this. It could stand to have some more production chains and racket types, though.

- A lot more quests than I expected in this. Every one of your gangsters has their own personal one, from your main boss to the hired help, at least from what I've seen. There's also quite a few side quests as well. Some are so basic they're not worth doing, others are more interesting and can have severe consequences/benefits for you. The storytelling in them is basic, but there is some intrigue here or there.

- Speaking of quests, there's quite a bit of voice acting and dialogue options. Some can get repetitive, and the dialogue ranges from passable to cheesy, but I think it's overall a benefit.

Cons: 

- Animations need polish. People look fine in the 'overworld' where people are just standing or walking around. But once they start doing combat maneuvers they just look unnatural. Lot of sliding around and awkward turning. Melee attacks look like they're being performed by manequins moved by giant puppet strings. I don't usually give a crap about this kind of thing but for the first few battles it was very distracting. 

- Tactical combat gets repetitive fast. It's saved by the fact it's only a part of the game, but if it was all the game had to offer? No way would I recommend it. I haven't fought the cops yet, so I can't say I've seen all the enemies in the game, but god is there a lack of variety in most of them. Same dudes with the same models with the same three types of weapons, with no variety in special abilities that I could see. I get that the time period doesn't really allow *that* much variety, but I can think of a few things: 

How about enemies manning mounted heavy machine-gun turrets that you gotta go behind to kill? How about attack dogs? How about dedicated medics who can go around buffing/healing soldiers? How about molotov-cocktail throwers and flame troopers? How about cars rolling into flank you during street/garage fights, filled with dudes ready to light your ass up from the windows? What about that same thing but with MG-mounted jeeps? Or hell, you could even throw in a World War 1 tank if you want to stretch reality a bit. And if you want to stretch it even further via some Steampunk/Fantasy elements, that could add even more options. I wouldn't mind. Fuck historical accuracy if historical accuracy means boring gameplay. Gimmie some Nikolai Tesla steam robots and electricity guns. Give me voodoo zombies (the game already kind of has them) and Deep Ones summoning Cthulhu cultists. Fuck it.

Lack of enemy varieties is further hurt by the lack of a destructible environment. Unlike X-Com, Phoenix Point, or any other TBC games I know of, nothing seems to be destructible. Even flimsy wooden crates can take a shotgun blast without so much as a dent. The battlefield remains a static, boring place thanks to this. 

Your own boiz do have a degree of diversity, especially when you take into account their traits. However, without a worthy opponent, all that is pretty much wasted. 

- Need an element of public relations to the game. PR was fucking huge to real life mobsters. Without the community at least turning a blind eye, you had jack shit. It's why, as the game actually mentions, many of them set up shit like soup kitchens during the Great Depression. There is absolutely none of this in the game that I can see, which is a fucking shame, as it would add a whole new dimension to the game. It would be awesome to have to balance publicly destructive criminal actions (such as things that would negatively affect the local economy) with doing shit for the community like opening up orphanages or the aforementioned soup kitchens. If you play your cards right, you should be the people's hero; have people cheering your name in the streets as you walk by. 

- I can't tip the pianist in my speak easies and have them play Rhapsody in Blue like the real life Al Capone would do. What the fuck, game?

TL; DR: Bugs (quests, mechanics, and dialogue), repetitive visuals and combat, and feels like it's missing key features. Graphics are fine, has not crashed yet, stable frames, foundations for the game seem like they're there. I recommend EoS but only when on sale. Otherwise, just hold on to your money and hope it gets active support.

First of all, some background, I only heard of this game through CallMeKevin and pre-purchased it after seeing Blitz and CMK's sponsored videos on EoS. I liked what I see from the videos. Two other factors that affected my decision to purchase the game were that a.) it was developed my Romero Games (I'm more familiar with John Romero's work) and b.) that it will be published by Paradox Interactive. Knowing Paradox Interactive their games (developed or published by them) tend to have long lasting support and DLC with two already slated to be released in the future. 

In its present state, the game has bugs, mostly found in quests, diplomacy, and combat. The quest bugs are really annoying and game breaking. It's either you can't find the NPC (High Roller Heaven quest) or the mechanics of the quest are broken (breweries remain closed after finishing the quest for Jacques). It needs quite a few quality of life improvements (like a better way to filter properties in your empire and a way to see the day progression maybe a clock or meter). The tutorial is solid enough though I had to figure certain things out myself. The economy and management aspects are pretty easy to understand but makes it feel lackluster. As for combat, it's pretty repetitive and loses its flare after a couple of fights. Diplomacy and interactions with the other factions are bland, making it feel unnecessary. Properties and the map could really do with some changes. It gets repetitive. One thing to note is it hasn't crashed yet, at least.

It's not all bad. Even if combat is repetitive, it is currently not buggy (the same can't be said for the rest of the game), the existing aspects are decent. Map is big, even if it's repetitive like the combat, a single playthrough could potentially last hours. A decent number of mob bosses to start with (still hoping for custom character creation). Frames are stable for me. 

A few things that, in my opinion, could help make the game better, adding more roles and actions you can take as the boss, adding more kinds of businesses, and interactions with local politics (this happens through a quest and ends there). Just my opinion, won't really affect my review.

I enjoy the game but it feels like it's missing a lot of features which I hope get added in free and not tied to DLC. Unfortunately, it feels like a game that could pass up as an early access game. I heard modding tools will be added which will, most likely, make it better off.  I recommend it for the potential and the foundations are there I can see that there are building blocks to make it a good game. However, in the state that it is in, I only recommend purchasing when it is on sale. I will probably update this review when I feel like enough changes are made or if I find anything else to add during my playthrough.

Edit: Added quests can get extremely buggy and some are game breaking.

So, I've seen both comments saying this game isn't worth the cash in its current state, and those that say it's a fun game but does have it's flaws. I fall into that second camp and would recommend this game, and there are a few reasons for this.

1. It's fun to run around the streets of 1920's Chicago! The developers did a great job creating a fun atmosphere for this game. If you run right past a car crossing the street to your next objective, the cars will honk at you and generally make a fuss. And I have also noticed that each district has it's own personality, go tot he docks and you'll see Thugs hanging by the docks, and you can almost smell the salt air. But head to the Near South District, where I started, and it's a rabbit warren of tight streets and alleyways, where you can get jumped by a gang if you aren't paying attention.

2. The combat, while maybe not quite as smooth as X-COM's or one of its copies, is still enjoyable, if not very challenging (and something I hope the devs will work on). You can charge in, and with my first boss's ability, blow three guys away on first site, have an almost perfectly clean fight, but still manage to lose someone because you didn't quite pay close enough attention to what that one enemy thug is carrying. (Sorry to my first two gang members, you will be missed).

3. The business side of things, while not very complex, does have some intricacies. If you want to make the most profit for your buck, you need to make sure the distilleries you have are producing the right amount of each kind of alcohol, to meet the demands of the various districts you're working in. Plus, you can manage your buildings to make sure they aren't competing with each other and instead work in harmony. I also love that you can take over a rivals business and decide to either keep it as is, completely wreck the business, or even better, burn it to the ground in true Chicago style. Though I do wish the buildings would actually be shown as ruined husks when wandering the city in street mode (hint hint devs).

4. I've seen some say that the characters are dry, and I would have to disagree. They have life in them! I was wandering in the dockyard district with my crew when all of a sudden there was a spat between three people involving love, relationships, and broken hearts. And one of them even became an alcoholic because of it! The bosses themselves are also fun to interact with, it was great sitting across from Al-Capone and talking smack for a few minutes for getting down to brass tacks and making an uneasy alliance to both grow our empires. Which in the end led to me, a fake Canadian Frenchwoman who moved to Detroit to make a name for herself, contracting out security to Al-Capone to stave off his rivals.

All in all, I would recommend this game if any of the above intrigues you, I've played around 6 hours today, and know that I'll be coming back for more. I still have to take over Chicago after all! And I cannot wait to see what the Devs do with the game going into the future, assuming we survive 2020 of course.

I'll preface this review by saying that I got this game to satisfy my love for Noir and everything prohibition era true-crime. This game certainly lived up to that for me. Reminded me slightly of the Mafia game trilogy but if it was focused on actually managing your rackets. I'm usually not a big strategy gamer but this was easy enough for me to understand and enjoy. If you want another XCOM game i wouldn't really say that this is for you as the battles are such a small part of the overall gameplay. 
The tutorial is voiceacted which i really appreciate because sometimes strategy game tutorials can get super longwinded and contain mountains of text before even beginning the game. 

Some of the things that need improvement: 
I did have some problems with some of the voice acting as it felt like it ranged alot in quality. Some bosses had great voices while others not so much... 
I feel like there are some balancing issues with some combat abilities but i don't doubt that those will soon be fixed now that the game is released. 
Furthermore some parts of the UI needs a little bit of detail work, some icons look very similar and are hard to tell apart. Factions are color coded which is really hard to see the difference on, would be generally nicer with symbols for each faction instead or something similar. 
Also the political game against other main factions is not thoroughly explained as sometimes other bosses will request things from you or declare war but at other times you can completely crush them without speaking a word to them. I assume this is not how the game is intended to work and therefore I don't see this as a major problem as long as they adjust it and can present the intended Gang War & Sitdown mechanics. 
When you reach late game it becomes quite hard to keep track of all your rackets, it would be great if there would be future possibilities of merging your rackets into larger ones. Even after just taking over one or two neighborhoods it can get rather overwhelming to keep track of it all. 

Other than a few bumps here and there I think the game is completely playable without any game breaking bugs. I love how they've presented the setting with the music, art and general vibe. It is a immersive mafia management game without feeling like you're just sitting in front of a spreadsheet just crunching numbers. The sidequest and rpg aspect of it all is a cute touch that makes you bond alot more with the quirky characters. I hope to see more of it as time goes by and people add their own mods to it.

As an avid fan of XCOM (as well as Chimera Squad) and other Paradox grand strategies (specifically Stellaris, CKIII, EUII) I opted to pre purchase this game with high hopes. There is a strong foundation here, and I have faith the game will reach my expectations some day.

At this time however, this should be released as early access with clear goals. It does not live up to the game description nor the price tag. Unfortunately, it's really not even close.

Reasons to wait:
1. The AI is awful. There is no competitive or strategic combat here. Enemies will waste a turn unnecessarily running, healing themselves while at full health, or just straight up passing the turn. There are limited environments, limited units (classes), and abilities. Given the small number of combat variables I kinda expected some twist or highly challenging battles.
2. At it's core, it's bland right now. It's a rinse and repeat. You choose to run around completing missions, with 1 or 2 narrative options that have no in game bearing. You capture rackets (acquire property) to grow the empire and slowly out compete the other gangs. There are 5 rackets, and there are 4ish upgrades to each one, many that repeat from business to business (resulting in a grand total of 15 or so customizations).
3. Zero narrative and diplomacy. Your dialogue options all lead to the same results (fight or don't fight). Any 'treaties' or diplomacy is static, very small bonuses for agreeing not to attack each other. That's it. No negotiation.
4. Bugs. I've been trapped, unable to open/close doors and had to reload. I've had rackets/businesses just disappear (if they were captured by someone, where is my alert??). Normally I wouldn't mind reloading my game once in awhile, but to just outright lose part of my empire with no notification is just game breaking for me.

Underneath all these concerns there is a great game, I really think so. I will will check in periodically, and watching upcoming patches to address my concerns. It is my hope that I can change this review to a recommend.

81434163.review:
Very rare for me to write a review but this I think deserves one.

Foreword - This is a Paradox title.... expect things to be heavily supported and patched as we move forwards.

Pro's

Setting - Both visuals and sound create an excellent ambience and the character models and speech really play into that era too. 

Gameplay - This is a mix-up of the original gangsters, omerta and a little port royal for the strategic and business side of it. However the combat side is a different kettle of fish, it is I would say a lite version of XCOM, more similar to something like vigilantes, where it is turn based but not as in-depth as XCOM. For me the balance of these two areas works perfectly, I am not going to get bored of being bogged down in long drawn out fights the way XCOM can be and the risk of permadeath for gangsters you have invested a significant amount of time into their development, really adds to the tension at times.

Story/Missions - Having a good time going through some of my gangsters stories and missions as well as the more mainline ones, well-written and quite funny at times.

Cons

Bugs - For me so far, nothing game breaking or really particularly annoying thankfully. Upon death, people coats tend to instantly change to white. When firing a two handed weapon (Shotgun, rifle, machine gun) even though the AP cost says 1, it ends your turn. I have a feeling these are meant to cost 2 AP as they are noticeably more powerful. (to beat this i just switch to my secondary, fire it off and then switch to main and fire it).

Depth - There's a lot more than you may realise to fine-tuning and optimising your flourishing empire, than is highlighted in the tutorial. You are guided to a certain extent but then left to figure out the intricacies yourself, this may put some people off as it may be a bit daunting for newcomers to the genre.

Summary

Overall I have been pleasantly surprised with this after reading some of the reviews and the poor scores given. I would definitely recommend this as is and it can only get better with future support and DLC!

Empire of Sin is a turn-based strategy and management game with basic RPG elements. 

The turn-based battles are like in many similar games. Your character has 2 AP's and most actions cost 1. Initiative decides in which order characters act. Every character has special abilities you unlock through leveling them up. A basic skill tree lets you decide which ability you want to unlock. To learn the new ability your character needs a few days/weeks. 

So, how are these turn-based battles compared to other games?
For 40€/USD I expected these battles to be deep and tactical. They are not. They are just basic overall. The AI acts stupid and is not dangerous at all. Most battles seem like a joke and even though you get shot and hurt, it doesn't get dangerous. I expect the fights to be a chore later in the game. 
It's just too easy and nothing compared to the average TBS game (let alone XCOM). This is the most basic and untactical a turn-based strategy game can get.
Also, the accuracy of shots seems arbitrary. Standing 2 tiles away from the target, it shows an accuracy of 25%. Moving closer, it shows 56%. Even then: Standing in front of the target and I don't even have an accuracy of 50%? There are countless examples of how absurd the accuracy is overall. It doesn't feel right. Spoiler: Most shoots (mine, not the enemies') hit the target even though I get an accuracy of 26% or something. Even considering the different types of weapons (Shotgun, pistol, machine gun), it's just ridiculous. 

Story-wise it's pretty interesting. The voice acting is good enough but nothing special and the writing is okay. The movements of characters in cutscenes are monotonous. Every character has like 2 different movements and most of the time they don't fit to what they say. It seems cheap. Paired with the graphics (which aren't good and also seem like they went for something better but couldn't achieve it and just went with how bad it looks) it looks comically most of the time. 

So, how about the management aspect of the game? 
I didn't play that long yet but it's very detailed and probably the biggest and best aspect of the game. You can do every little thing with your businesses and interact with every other gang.
You can go and attack some other gangs, destroy their buildings, take them, or just rob them. You can talk with bosses, negotiate with them, or just ignore them. Diplomacy is the key to a successful business. And then there's also the police. 
Every boss and all of your characters have their personality. They are loyal to different gangs and have different characteristics. 
This all seems very good. I did not play long enough to give a final judgment about that part of the game yet but i expect it to be the main attraction of this game. 

Overall the game feels very clunky and cheap considering it costs 40USD/€. I definitely can't recommend it for that price. It's overpriced. Similar games of the genre are WAY cheaper and do it better (TBS games at least). There aren't many games that combine turn-based fights with management like Empire of Sin does but looking at it as a TBS-game (considering at least half of the game consists of that) it's just not good enough. 
Wait for a sale. I don't expect them to change the TBS-part of the game. They need to completely revamp it probably. 
Even if you're just (or mainly) into the management part of the game I don't think it's worth full price now. It definitely doesn't have the quality of other games with a price tag like that.

81422974.review:
I found it quite enjoyable. It is a mix of Xcom 2 style combat and squad management along with sim game empire management. Instead of flying mission to mission like in Xcom, you play real time in a huge open world. You find missions around the map by hitting up opposing warehouses, bars, brothels, etc. or enter into street shootouts with thugs. There is quite a lot of depth in the character management as each boss and gangster has many traits that make them unique when you start out, and they also acquire traits and skills throughout the game.

The combat itself can definitely use an "Autofight" mechanic as it can get repetitive over time. I hope this is something that comes in a patch. Otherwise, it is your typical turn based combat with abilities, positioning, items, perks, etc., all playing out as you overtake property. 

The empire management is deep enough on the surface and has a lot of facets. You buy different properties and need to manage your alcohol production and distribution. You can enter into deals with opposing gangs for protection, trade, and other stuff. I see a lot of people complaining that despite the many options here that they find this part to be too easy to succeed at by just doing whatever you want and still making money. However, I found it quite challenging to do that when playing on the harder difficulty setting. If you play at the default setting, dont expect a serious challenge...

There are also RPG mechanics at play as you decide how to deal with other gangs as well as your own henchmen. I havent played enough yet to have a really thorough overview of this, but it looks promising enough so far.

Overall, I am happy with this game even if it does blend all the genres and execute its ideas as perfectly as I had hoped it would. There are already expansion packs in development that will hopefully add depth to the game. A lot of the other issues such as repetition, game balance, and combat AI can hopefully be ironed out with patches (A major day 1 patch is already available). Most people can agree that whether you like it or not, the base is there for a great game to be developed over time. If youre on the fence, perhaps come back in 6 months once some DLC has fleshed out the mechanics and patches have addressed some of the issues. However, I do feel this is an already enjoyable game as it stands and will continue to play until then.

However, it's not great yet, and it's not even a finished product. It absolutely feels like a game in (early, genuine) beta, or early access. It does not feel like a finished product.

If you enjoy turn based games, you'll probably like this. If you enjoy the aesthetic, you'll probably like this. But at the moment it is just too clunky and wonky for me to recommend this game to anyone who doesn't have excess money. There are far, far better games you can get for this price tag, as much as I'd like to recommend it.

I do think the game will receive polish and be okay. But right now everything from the animations to the graphics to the gameplay just feels really rough.

I want to add a little bit more via edit, so here we go:

There are two major factors that led to me hitting "Do not recommend" instead of "Recommend". They are:

1. When entering buildings for combat your mobsters are just randomly placed. Even though each building has a door/proper entrance, you're just randomly teleported, usually into a bad position with little cover. It's very weird and jarring, and I'm not sure if this is a bug or intentional -- why are my mobsters, walking into a racket through the front door, spawning in the back of a brewery?

2. The animations and effects are almost painful. They just aren't there yet -- it makes the game feel so "beta." As a few examples:

- When characters talk, their lips barely move. It's like they didn't even try to sync lips, which leaves me confused why they bothered using 3D models at all. Budget games can absolutely EXCEL using 2d arts and stills, with a little bit of animation, to sell their cinematics, and this is one such game that ought to.

- One of my characters has an ability that's sort of like a berserk. I can't control her on her turn, and she just unloads a full clip into everyone. It's pretty cool! Except the sound effects loop over each other, clip through each other, and the firing effect doesn't match up with the sound at all. It's very grating.

- The combat has no 'oomph.' When I blast three mobsters with a shotgun, I feel like it ought to LOOK like I just one-hit 3 mobsters with a shotgun, y'know? I'm not necessarily talking about gore, just appropriate impact.

Also, you have no ability to customize your crew. I know this may seem minor, but I'd love to have a variety of outfits, hairstyles, etc. to go through, rather than my boss always looking the same. It's kind of silly, but there's a roleplay element to turn based games that I always enjoy, and the lack of customization prevents me from enjoying that as much as I'd like, particularly because, going in, I was very much looking forward to the roleplay idea of being my own mob boss.

Since this feels very negative, I'd like to share a few Pros of the game:

- It's aesthetically pretty nice.

- The music is stellar.

- It has good bones.

TLDR: Cool game, WAY too easy, and currently very buggy
Edit: While less buggy after more play, more of the fundamental flaws started to show. Yes, I had some great moments, like when I accidentally started a battle that had 20+ individuals fighting in two separate wars, but then it was bogged down by this games biggest flaw: Its AI. When you are fighting the AI, it's bad, because it makes the game too easy when they just run towards you like orcs and get ground to paste by your overwatch or put in easy positions to be shot. But when the AI fights each other, as happened in that massive street battle that should have been epic, it's deficiencies truly show. Turn after turn, instead of shooting or doing anything helpful, the AI would just run across 3 enemies with a full turn of movement, and what should have been a fast-paced, 5 turn max epic shootout turned into a comical 20 turn display of incompetent AI. The game is close to something good, it really is, but until the AI is fixed, I can't recommend it at any price, let alone $40. 
Another fix is that I think the boss characters are way OP, and while a relatively fun boss to fight (compared to the standard fodder), I think a more X-com-y system could be better. Keep the bosses sidelined, maybe with a penalty or cooldown or something for using them, and instead focus on the mobsters you hire maybe leading a small group of standard mob. Add an armory and recruiter to the safehouse to gather and improve these mob members, treat them like manpower in a war. I think that would make battles much more interesting, where the player can actually loose something, but also would only work with an improved AI. 

I've been watching this game for a while now, and have been pretty excited for it to finally come out. When I first opened the game, I had 2 great hours, admittedly with many QOL improvements desperately needed, but towards the end of that time I started getting bugs that resulted in a hard-lock crash. The game isn't very graphically intense, so this shouldn't happen in a $40 release game. 
Main Pros: 
Great persistent world with lots (maybe even too much, honestly) going on constantly, with interlocking systems that all require attention
Decent X-Com style combat system
Consequential decisions in who you interact with, how you interact with your gangsters, and which missions you decide to complete
Cons: 
Extremely easy, as your boss character is so OP that they can often clear an entire room in one or two turns
Buggy, with weird crashes and sound breaks after not long in game
QOL improvements I really need: 
A "zoom to" button for your mobsters, I had trouble finding them after hiring
Clearer UI for some of the businesses, some important buttons seemed hidden to me
There are some already discovered exploits that need to be fixed, including a really easy infinite money exploit

I wanted to like this game. By the description it sounded like a game I would fall in love with and sink hundreds of hours into. "It will be incredibly replayable" is what was promised. Unfortunately that turned out to be false for several reasons, and so rather than give a pros and cons list I intend to make my review a reason why it lacks replayability.

1. Economy system is shallow.

(Booze->distribution) +Casino(+-rng income)+brothel income=Cash

These values can be changed in two methods, upgrades or conquering more locations. Due to the time it takes for upgrades and the cost, conquering can be done cheaper and faster and one can almost ignore upgrades altogether.

Money then has two purposes buy gear or hire gangsters. That’s the entire economic system, so there is no reason to play tall or shift playstyle, as it would not effect gameplay.

2. Diplomacy is a bust. There is negligible benefits of playing friendly. The only benefit is maybe nonaggression pacts, however losing rackets doesn’t actually matter, as there is the “enders game” victory condition where when you kill a boss you take all their territory including territory you lost to them. War is always preferable to peace

3. Lack of gangster customization and variety. Due to the notoriety system, gangsters will always start the same every playthrough. Your starting gangsters are out of 5 so you will play with the same gangsters almost all the time. On top of that their unique perks may affect their combat a little, but play very little role in terms of the campaign map.

4. Lack of map variety. The hideouts, speakeasys etc are all the same and recycled. It is super repetitive.

The time period is cool, the musical score is fantastic, but it tries to mix rpg elements, tactical elements and 4x elements, and unfortunately doesn’t make it.

Edit Notes: Felt the need to come back and say its also very buggy. This game is what I would expect in an alpha or early access.

81412975.review:
First impression after 30 minutes: This is going to be a lot of fun.

No problems installing, auto detection of hardware and correct settings all went smooth. The music is a nice ambiance and fitting for the time period: so far a selection of 1920's light jazz and swing music. It just flows in the background and keeps a nice soothing tempo that blends it all together. 

There's a broad selection of 14 bosses to choose from, each with their own quirks and special ability. Though from what I can tell so far it's mostly a style choice since the meat of the game is going to be relatively the same with each as the goal is to "take over the city" no matter who you pick. You have some options for customizing the game length, size of the city, number of gangs as your enemy and several difficulty settings. The tutorial seems to have covered all the basics required to learn in about 30 minutes while hinting at more depth to discover through game play.

I can't tell how long the game is overall (yet), and quite frankly it might not matter since you can customize that by altering the city size and number of enemies. I get the feeling it's meant to be a few hours and then do it again with someone else for a different flavor.

Overall, a good first impression. no bugs encountered so far. I'll spend another hour playing and then edit in an update before I hit the 2 hour mark (the max play time before you can refund if things go wrong)
----------------------------

EDIT 1 hour later: There's more depth here than it first appears and it's a playstyle that's a unique blend. You rule your empire and explore the city in real time, everything around you is going on while you make your decisions and wander the streets with your squad. The other factions are busy interacting with each other and as you encounter them you can choose to negotiate or attack. The game only slows down for combat and once you engage it seamlessly transitions into turn based tactical choices with each character going in order of initiative. It's not "your turn / their turn" and if more than one faction is nearby other gangsters can enter the fight as your enemy or ally.

In the last hour I've taken over a speakeasy and a brewery then killed the boss of that faction so he can't retaliate. Bought an abandoned building and turned it into a casino. Then negotiated peace with two other factions while they agreed to give me parts of their enemies territories if I helped them with their gang wars. Making friends and enemies as casually as sipping a brandy.

There's a surreal quality to the calm undertones of running an empire while jumping in and out of brutal street warfare, curb stomping an enemy to prove a point while making business decisions with your next breath as you expand through either negotiations or combat on the whims of wherever your heart takes you.

I don't want to gush with praise too much as it's still pretty early in the game, but so far it's a casual blend of tycoon management with a light layer of RPG conversations and humorously over-stylized combat.

I'm not refunding this and the $40 asking price for the game is worth the money to me. I'll edit this again after I've put some real hours into it.
----------------------

EDIT 20 hours later: The game has some flaws, there are numerous graphics bugs and some quirky design choices, but at least for me it's been nothing game breaking. (I can see some other people having issues)

I would note: When I installed this I also had to reboot to install some windows module that came with it, I do wonder how many people ignored the windows update. But I can only speak from my own experience.

The gameplay doesn't change much beyond the first couple hours other than a little more management options as you get more notoriety and some variables in mobster side stories and combat options as you recruit a few more of them. But then you could say that about most games. In response to people whining that: you just keep doing the same things; yea and? 

Shooters: you go from area to area shooting people. We could be talking about Chess: OMG you just keep moving the pieces around!

If you just want to boil a game down to it's core gameplay loop all of them are repetitive, it's a question of whether you enjoy that loop or not.

This isn't a big AAA game from a studio with 100's of people working on it. It's a small indy game that just wanted to create a stylish tycoon game with a 1920's prohibition theme. So much of the hate thrown at this game comes from people who created their own expectations or have no concept of the actual time period this is set in.

For those having a worse time with bugs than me: the devs have been very active in collecting reports and working on solutions, but again I can't comment on things that aren't effecting me and what I've seen have been minor.

I've been playing quite a bit these last few days and reading the forums and other reviews. I really don't understand the hate, there appears to be a concentrated effort from trolls to just aggressively attack this game, often with made up lies. I've seen complaints about microtransactions (there aren't any) or nonstop whining that it doesn't match certain gangster movies… that are set in other time periods… and the list goes on.

Every time I think about whether I should revise my review I just have to ask myself one question: Am I having fun? And the answer is still yes. And that's all I really ask for from a game to recommend it, give me some fun and entertainment for my money.

I'm not saying the game can't be improved, but that will just make it even better in the long run. In the mean time I'm still enjoying it, warts and all.
---

Bottom line: It's a $40 indy game that has very casual tycoon management, a light RPG story layer and a minimalist tactical combat approach that reminds me of Mutant Year Zero (which was itself an XCOM variant but with free roam/ambush mechanics)

I guess I just don't expect a game to be perfect, I just want it to be fun and I'm still enjoying this quite a bit.
---

If you want to read my full review you can check it out here: https://turnbasedlovers.com/review/empire-of-sin-2/

Empire of Sin, a game developed by Romero Studios and published by Paradox Interactive, is a hybrid strategy turn-based tactical RPG where you take the role of one of fourteen historical gang bosses in Chicago seeking to gain control of the city’s underworld and fighting off other gangsters – all while staying one step ahead of the law. 

Empire of Sin has a bit of a free-form style. What you are doing at any given moment is driven by what you, as a player believes is important. The game provides some suggestions, in the form of a robust quest system, but it is ultimately you that is pushing towards achieving your overall goal: becoming the kingpin of Chicago. There are three major aspects that you will be managing in pursuit of this: your criminal empire, combat, and relationships with other factions. 

The biggest flaw is that the game feels more competent than truly special. All of the systems are very functional and effective and generally fun, but they play it a little bit too safe. Class abilities are very similar to what you would expect for a close X-Com 2 spin off, and some appear to essentially have been copied from X-Com 2. The diplomatic system feels like Europa Universalis IV with a bit of a mobster spin, and the economic system is functional but not really surprising or exciting in any way. Maybe it is too much to expect from a Paradox title, but I would have preferred some more risks or attempts to stand out. Instead it is functional and fun, but not exceptional.

Empire of Sin is fun. You are constantly given interesting stuff to do, and the fact that they have set up an almost simulation-style world that progresses and changes even without your active intervention is something I haven’t really seen in a game focused as much as this one on tactical turn-based combat. Nothing really pops out as particularly new, but it is engaging and the game had no problem maintaining my interest for extended sessions. Everything fits together very well in a seamless sort of way that shows a lot of care from the design and conceptualization side of things.  

Empire of Sin is a good game and if the idea of playing a game where you are a mob boss, fighting in the streets of Chicago for dominance while being heavily involved in the diplomatic, economic, and tactical aspects of these fights appeals to you then I can definitely recommend it. Unfortunately, the reviewer copy included some pretty unfortunate bugs that were frustrating enough that I was not able to play the game as comprehensively as I would have liked, but I am looking forward to these bugs being squashed so I can truly explore some of the finer points of strategy in Empire of Sin. 

Pros
[list]
[*]One of the most impressive and innovative interfaces I have seen
[*]Interlocking parts work very well together in a way that is smooth and elegant
[*]Great style, with fun music, distinct neighborhoods, and nice historical touches
[/list]
Cons
[list]
[*]Combat is a bit loose with unthematic optimal actions and exploits that should have been fixed
[*]Low degree of variety in enemy types can result in combat getting a bit dull as the game continues
[*]Nothing truly innovative from a mechanical sense. If the game was pushed just a little more it might have stood out as exceptional rather than just good to very good 
[*]Game features a number of extremely frustrating bugs on release. 
[/list]

Looking through the individual gangsters to find the right fit for what your boss needs has some entertainment to it, but the different tiers of those gangsters seems largely arbitrary. Yes the higher tier options typically have higher stats but their traits often make them a worse choice anyway, or a lower tier a better choice. The need to locate or earn the trust of their friends before you can recruit them starts out as a charming aspect but will quickly frustrate you as you're repeatedly only given the same options despite different actions.

The randomized events that happen throughout the game are repetitive due to lack of variety and can be significant. You're given choices but lack the ability to review your contributing stats, which change and seem to have modifiers that are either invisible or tough to locate. An example might be given 3 options, one of which requires a monetary investment, one requires having a specific trait (and so may not be available at all if you don't have it), or performing a skill check. Your boss's skills can pretty quickly reach over 100 so it would be natural to assume success, but fails do still happen on those checks.

All of the above could be tolerated and I've been playing the game despite those factors. What I can't excuse, though, are the situations where the game stops working as intended. Bugs that either force you to reload a previous save: combat bugs where something happens to trigger a character out of turn which then makes them need to act without actually being able to act, so you're stuck on a turn that you can't end. Or a racket becoming such that you can't attack it and so end up with a minor faction that just never expires because one of their rackets can't be attacked.

I've spent probably 15 to 20 hours on the current game I'm in, there's still plenty to do but it's all the same at this point and I've already hit bugs that would make winning, whatever that looks like, likely impossible I don't see the reason to keep going. The other 40ish hours of play time were spent wrapping my head around getting my empire to work properly with the strange economy of the game.

Ah yes, woke (or whitewashed, depending on how you look at it) Chicago in the 1920s. A time when feminism meant lots of women in the police force and as guards in major gangs. A time when homosexuality was so widely accepted, anyone could develop a gay romance with anyone and loudly proclaim it to everyone they know. A time when the police didn't even need to be bribed to do nothing, the faction exists in game pretty much for show. Gangs all embraced diversity, black gangs hiring plenty of white gangsters and white gangs doing the same with black gangsters. A time when Italians, Irishmen, Chinese, and more all lived in perfect harmony to loot Chicago without prejudice and the only issue with moving outside of your neighborhood was the other, very diverse gangs feeling threatened by the competition. 

Jokes aside, this is actually a pretty fun game for what it is, and the issues are things that are easily patchable, such as AI behaviors and balance issues. The key is not to expect any evidence that it was "heavily researched," there's none to be found despite the advertising. This game bears zero resemblance to history, and I don't expect that to change based on the fact that the devs actively implemented mechanics that make it less historical to "represent" diversity without also representing the uphill battle that would have come with it in the 1920s. Much of the advertising about "history" is not to be taken seriously. 

A quick rundown of issues that should be easy enough to patch:
-Mid and late game snowballing is insane. The game is basically over by the early mid or late early game. 
-AI is pretty non-aggressive when it comes to expansion into low-difficulty thug rackets
-Trading is pretty exploitable, especially weapons because many weapons are overpriced
-Necessity of regular combat is somewhat grindy

Some things that are really fun:
+Early game: at higher difficulty levels, you really do feel the pressure of multiple, much more powerful gangs nearby. You need to expand without becoming a threat
+AI is not afraid to war with you or each other if they have the upper hand and see the target as easier to attack than befriend
+The strategic side of combat feels good: the neighborhood and taxi system makes it feel like a gang war, where the "front" is all around you and you could get hit from any direction. 
+The extent to which this game is ahistorical is honestly almost amusing. Serious meme potential. I won't deny it does have some charm, if you come into it expecting it.

As far as the tactical combat, it is satisfactory. I won't put it down as a particular highlight of the game, but it isn't disappointing either. 

Ultimately, I suggest one shouldn't come into this game with any particular expectations, and I think most will find the experience pleasant overall. That said, refusing to buy simply based on how wildly different from what was advertised is reasonable as well. To suggest this game was "researched" at all is a joke, mostly just memes and maybe 2 or 3 somewhat lesser known real gangs.
